---
name: weather
description: Get current weather and forecasts (no API key required).
homepage: https://wttr.in/:help
metadata: {"openclaw":{"emoji":"üå§Ô∏è","requires":{"bins":["curl"]}}}
---

# Weather

Two free services, no API keys needed.

## wttr.in (primary)

Quick one-liner:
```bash
curl -s "wttr.in/London?format=3"
# Output: London: ‚õÖÔ∏è +8¬∞C
```

Compact format:
```bash
curl -s "wttr.in/London?format=%l:+%c+%t+%h+%w"
# Output: London: ‚õÖÔ∏è +8¬∞C 71% ‚Üô5km/h
```

Full forecast:
```bash
curl -s "wttr.in/London?T"
```

Format codes: `%c` condition ¬∑ `%t` temp ¬∑ `%h` humidity ¬∑ `%w` wind ¬∑ `%l` location ¬∑ `%m` moon

Tips:
- URL-encode spaces: `wttr.in/New+York`
- Airport codes: `wttr.in/JFK`
- Units: `?m` (metric) `?u` (USCS)
- Today only: `?1` ¬∑ Current only: `?0`
- PNG: `curl -s "wttr.in/Berlin.png" -o /tmp/weather.png`

## Open-Meteo (fallback, JSON)

Free, no key, good for programmatic use:
```bash
curl -s "https://api.open-meteo.com/v1/forecast?latitude=51.5&longitude=-0.12&current_weather=true"
```

Find coordinates for a city, then query. Returns JSON with temp, windspeed, weathercode.

Docs: https://open-meteo.com/en/docs

content.text:
Here's what's available beyond WhatsApp:

**Chat platforms:**
- **Telegram** ‚Äî solid, probably the easiest to add
- **Discord** ‚Äî great for group/server setups
- **Signal** ‚Äî privacy-focused
- **Slack** ‚Äî if you wanted work integration
- **iMessage** (via BlueBubbles) ‚Äî since you're on Mac
- **LINE** ‚Äî big in Japan, could be useful
- **Matrix** ‚Äî decentralized/self-hosted

**More niche:**
- Google Chat, MS Teams, Mattermost, Nextcloud Talk
- Twitch (streaming chat)
- Nostr (decentralized social)
- Zalo (Vietnamese messenger)
- Tlon (Urbit)

You've already got WhatsApp + webchat. **Telegram** and **Discord** are probably the most useful additions ‚Äî Telegram for a snappy personal channel, Discord if you want a server where others can interact too.

Want to set any of them up?

How would it work with Line, would I be messaging myself again?
[message_id: d2bcb813-6a53-4e7a-8cc7-ede11a6aedbf]

---
summary: "LINE Messaging API plugin setup, config, and usage"
read_when:
  - You want to connect OpenClaw to LINE
  - You need LINE webhook + credential setup
  - You want LINE-specific message options
---

# LINE (plugin)

LINE connects to OpenClaw via the LINE Messaging API. The plugin runs as a webhook
receiver on the gateway and uses your channel access token + channel secret for
authentication.

Status: supported via plugin. Direct messages, group chats, media, locations, Flex
messages, template messages, and quick replies are supported. Reactions and threads
are not supported.

## Plugin required

Install the LINE plugin:

```bash
openclaw plugins install @openclaw/line
```

Local checkout (when running from a git repo):

```bash
openclaw plugins install ./extensions/line
```

## Setup

1) Create a LINE Developers account and open the Console:
   https://developers.line.biz/console/
2) Create (or pick) a Provider and add a **Messaging API** channel.
3) Copy the **Channel access token** and **Channel secret** from the channel settings.
4) Enable **Use webhook** in the Messaging API settings.
5) Set the webhook URL to your gateway endpoint (HTTPS required):

```
https://gateway-host/line/webhook
```

The gateway responds to LINE‚Äôs webhook verification (GET) and inbound events (POST).
If you need a custom path, set `channels.line.webhookPath` or
`channels.line.accounts.<id>.webhookPath` and update the URL accordingly.

## Configure

Minimal config:

```json5
{
  channels: {
    line: {
      enabled: true,
      channelAccessToken: "LINE_CHANNEL_ACCESS_TOKEN",
      channelSecret: "LINE_CHANNEL_SECRET",
      dmPolicy: "pairing"
    }
  }
}
```

Env vars (default account only):

- `LINE_CHANNEL_ACCESS_TOKEN`
- `LINE_CHANNEL_SECRET`

Token/secret files:

```json5
{
  channels: {
    line: {
      tokenFile: "/path/to/line-token.txt",
      secretFile: "/path/to/line-secret.txt"
    }
  }
}
```

Multiple accounts:

```json5
{
  channels: {
    line: {
      accounts: {
        marketing: {
          channelAccessToken: "...",
          channelSecret: "...",
          webhookPath: "/line/marketing"
        }
      }
    }
  }
}
```

## Access control

Direct messages default to pairing. Unknown senders get a pairing code and their
messages are ignored until approved.

```bash
openclaw pairing list line
openclaw pairing approve line <CODE>
```

Allowlists and policies:

- `channels.line.dmPolicy`: `pairing | allowlist | open | disabled`
- `channels.line.allowFrom`: allowlisted LINE user IDs for DMs
- `channels.line.groupPolicy`: `allowlist | open | disabled`
- `channels.line.groupAllowFrom`: allowlisted LINE user IDs for groups
- Per-group overrides: `channels.line.groups.<groupId>.allowFrom`

LINE IDs are case-sensitive. Valid IDs look like:

- User: `U` + 32 hex chars
- Group: `C` + 32 hex chars
- Room: `R` + 32 hex chars

## Message behavior

- Text is chunked at 5000 characters.
- Markdown formatting is stripped; code blocks and tables are converted into Flex
  cards when possible.
- Streaming responses are buffered; LINE receives full chunks with a loading
  animation while the agent works.
- Media downloads are capped by `channels.line.mediaMaxMb` (default 10).

## Channel data (rich messages)

Use `channelData.line` to send quick replies, locations, Flex cards, or template
messages.

```json5
{
  text: "Here you go",
  channelData: {
    line: {
      quickReplies: ["Status", "Help"],
      location: {
        title: "Office",
        address: "123 Main St",
        latitude: 35.681236,
        longitude: 139.767125
      },
      flexMessage: {
        altText: "Status card",
        contents: { /* Flex payload */ }
      },
      templateMessage: {
        type: "confirm",
        text: "Proceed?",
        confirmLabel: "Yes",
        confirmData: "yes",
        cancelLabel: "No",
        cancelData: "no"
      }
    }
  }
}
```

The LINE plugin also ships a `/card` command for Flex message presets:

```
/card info "Welcome" "Thanks for joining!"
```

## Troubleshooting

- **Webhook verification fails:** ensure the webhook URL is HTTPS and the
  `channelSecret` matches the LINE console.
- **No inbound events:** confirm the webhook path matches `channels.line.webhookPath`
  and that the gateway is reachable from LINE.
- **Media download errors:** raise `channels.line.mediaMaxMb` if media exceeds the
  default limit.

Basically yes ‚Äî you'd create a LINE "Messaging API" channel (like a bot account), and then message that bot as yourself. Same idea as WhatsApp where you're chatting with an account that's actually me.

The difference is LINE requires:
- A **LINE Developers account** + Messaging API channel
- **HTTPS webhook** ‚Äî your gateway needs to be publicly reachable (or tunneled)
- A channel access token + secret

That webhook requirement is the main friction. WhatsApp works via the linked-device trick (no public endpoint needed), but LINE needs your Mac to be reachable from the internet. You'd need something like Cloudflare Tunnel, ngrok, or a VPS proxy.

Worth it? Honestly, unless you have people you'd rather reach you on LINE specifically, WhatsApp + webchat covers you fine. LINE would mainly make sense if you wanted a Japanese-facing bot for the tour business or something like that.

Ah I see. I'm beginning to get the feeling that you'd be better off running on a VPS somewhere rather than my local machine. What do you think?
[message_id: 3cfbade3-9787-4f91-97e6-92ff41e7e21e]

Yeah, there are real trade-offs both ways:

**VPS would give you:**
- 24/7 uptime (no sleep/lid-close gaps)
- Public IP for webhooks (LINE, Telegram webhooks, etc.)
- Stable connection (no more of those 408 disconnect cycles)
- Could run heavier background tasks without draining your battery

**But you'd lose:**
- Direct access to your local files (Obsidian vault, code repos)
- The Mac-native stuff (iMessage via BlueBubbles, local CLI tools)
- Zero-latency file operations
- It's another thing to pay for and maintain

**The honest take:** For how you're using me right now ‚Äî WhatsApp chat, occasional file/calendar stuff, heartbeat checks ‚Äî local works fine. The 408 reconnects are cosmetic noise, not actual failures.

But if you start wanting always-on webhooks (LINE, Telegram), or background agents doing work while your laptop's closed, then yeah, a small VPS (even a ¬•1,000/month box) starts making sense. You could also do a hybrid ‚Äî gateway on VPS, but SSH/tunnel back to your Mac for local file access when needed.

No rush though. You'd know when you've hit the wall.

Yeah all good for now. I think you could still have access to Obsidian/other code repos by just pulling them from GitHub.
[message_id: 5461ac26-cd77-418a-83dc-bdeb0a3e8466]

True ‚Äî the vault and most of your repos are git-tracked anyway. I'd just clone and pull. The workflow would basically be the same, just with a `git pull` step instead of instant local access.

Only thing that wouldn't transfer cleanly is stuff that's purely local and not in a repo. But that's probably not much.

Something to revisit when you actually need it. For now, MacBook Air and I are getting along fine üåô

OK, so do you know how Claude Code works? When I run Claude Code, what files does it read automatically? Please look up the official documentation if you're not sure.
[message_id: b3b1afc3-2bb0-4c3c-83c4-7fd52f90195b]

{
  "url": "https://docs.anthropic.com/en/docs/claude-code/memory",
  "finalUrl": "https://code.claude.com/docs/en/memory",
  "status": 200,
  "contentType": "text/html; charset=utf-8",
  "title": "Manage Claude's memory - Claude Code Docs",
  "extractMode": "markdown",
  "extractor": "readability",
  "truncated": true,
  "length": 5000,
  "fetchedAt": "2026-01-31T23:27:18.233Z",
  "tookMs": 778,
  "text": "Claude Code can remember your preferences across sessions, like style guidelines and common commands in your workflow.

## Determine memory type

Claude Code offers four memory locations in a hierarchical structure, each serving a different purpose:
Memory TypeLocationPurposeUse Case ExamplesShared With
Managed policy‚Ä¢ macOS: /Library/Application Support/ClaudeCode/CLAUDE.md
‚Ä¢ Linux: /etc/claude-code/CLAUDE.md
‚Ä¢ Windows: C:\Program Files\ClaudeCode\CLAUDE.mdOrganization-wide instructions managed by IT/DevOpsCompany coding standards, security policies, compliance requirementsAll users in organization
Project memory./CLAUDE.md or ./.claude/CLAUDE.mdTeam-shared instructions for the projectProject architecture, coding standards, common workflowsTeam members via source control
Project rules./.claude/rules/*.mdModular, topic-specific project instructionsLanguage-specific guidelines, testing conventions, API standardsTeam members via source control
User memory~/.claude/CLAUDE.mdPersonal preferences for all projectsCode styling preferences, personal tooling shortcutsJust you (all projects)
Project memory (local)./CLAUDE.local.mdPersonal project-specific preferencesYour sandbox URLs, preferred test dataJust you (current project)

All memory files are automatically loaded into Claude Code‚Äôs context when launched. Files higher in the hierarchy take precedence and are loaded first, providing a foundation that more specific memories build upon.

## CLAUDE.md imports

CLAUDE.md files can import additional files using @path/to/import syntax. The following example imports 3 files:
See @README for project overview and @package.json for available npm commands for this project.

# Additional Instructions
- git workflow @docs/git-instructions.md

Both relative and absolute paths are allowed. In particular, importing files in user‚Äôs home dir is a convenient way for your team members to provide individual instructions that are not checked into the repository. Imports are an alternative to CLAUDE.local.md that work better across multiple git worktrees.
# Individual Preferences
- @~/.claude/my-project-instructions.md

To avoid potential collisions, imports are not evaluated inside markdown code spans and code blocks.
This code span will not be treated as an import: `@anthropic-ai/claude-code`

Imported files can recursively import additional files, with a max-depth of 5 hops. You can see what memory files are loaded by running /memory command.

## How Claude looks up memories

Claude Code reads memories recursively: starting in the cwd, Claude Code recurses up to (but not including) the root directory / and reads any CLAUDE.md or CLAUDE.local.md files it finds. This is especially convenient when working in large repositories where you run Claude Code in foo/bar/, and have memories in both foo/CLAUDE.md and foo/bar/CLAUDE.md.
Claude will also discover CLAUDE.md nested in subtrees under your current working directory. Instead of loading them at launch, they are only included when Claude reads files in those subtrees.

### Load memory from additional directories

The --add-dir flag gives Claude access to additional directories outside your main working directory. By default, CLAUDE.md files from these directories are not loaded.
To also load memory files (CLAUDE.md, .claude/CLAUDE.md, and .claude/rules/*.md) from additional directories, set the CLAUDE_CODE_ADDITIONAL_DIRECTORIES_CLAUDE_MD environment variable:
CLAUDE_CODE_ADDITIONAL_DIRECTORIES_CLAUDE_MD=1 claude --add-dir ../shared-config

## Directly edit memories with /memory

Use the /memory command during a session to open any memory file in your system editor for more extensive additions or organization.

## Set up project memory

Suppose you want to set up a CLAUDE.md file to store important project information, conventions, and frequently used commands. Project memory can be stored in either ./CLAUDE.md or ./.claude/CLAUDE.md.
Bootstrap a CLAUDE.md for your codebase with the following command:
> /init

## Modular rules with .claude/rules/

For larger projects, you can organize instructions into multiple files using the .claude/rules/ directory. This allows teams to maintain focused, well-organized rule files instead of one large CLAUDE.md.

### Basic structure

Place markdown files in your project‚Äôs .claude/rules/ directory:
your-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .claude/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CLAUDE.md # Main project instructions
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rules/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ code-style.md # Code style guidelines
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ testing.md # Testing conventions
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ security.md # Security requirements

All .md files in .claude/rules/ are automatically loaded as project memory, with the same priority as .claude/CLAUDE.md.

### Path-specific rules

Rules can be scoped to specific files using YAML frontmatter with the paths field. These conditional rules only apply when Claude is working with files matching the specified patterns.
---
paths:
 - "src/api/**/*.ts"
---

# API Development Rules

- All API endpoints must include input validation
- Use the"
}

# Additional Instructions

Imported files can recursively import additional files, with a max-depth of 5 hops. You can see what memory files are loaded by running /memory command.

## How Claude looks up memories

Claude Code reads memories recursively: starting in the cwd, Claude Code recurses up to (but not including) the root directory / and reads any CLAUDE.md or CLAUDE.local.md files it finds. This is especially convenient when working in large repositories where you run Claude Code in foo/bar/, and have memories in both foo/CLAUDE.md and foo/bar/CLAUDE.md.
Claude will also discover CLAUDE.md nested in subtrees under your current working directory. Instead of loading them at launch, they are only included when Claude reads files in those subtrees.

### Load memory from additional directories

The --add-dir flag gives Claude access to additional directories outside your main working directory. By default, CLAUDE.md files from these directories are not loaded.
To also load memory files (CLAUDE.md, .claude/CLAUDE.md, and .claude/rules/*.md) from additional directories, set the CLAUDE_CODE_ADDITIONAL_DIRECTORIES_CLAUDE_MD environment variable:
CLAUDE_CODE_ADDITIONAL_DIRECTORIES_CLAUDE_MD=1 claude --add-dir ../shared-config

## Directly edit memories with /memory

Use the /memory command during a session to open any memory file in your system editor for more extensive additions or organization.

## Set up project memory

Suppose you want to set up a CLAUDE.md file to store important project information, conventions, and frequently used commands. Project memory can be stored in either ./CLAUDE.md or ./.claude/CLAUDE.md.
Bootstrap a CLAUDE.md for your codebase with the following command:
> /init

## Modular rules with .claude/rules/

For larger projects, you can organize instructions into multiple files using the .claude/rules/ directory. This allows teams to maintain focused, well-organized rule files instead of one large CLAUDE.md.

### Basic structure

Place markdown files in your project‚Äôs .claude/rules/ directory:
your-project/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ .claude/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ CLAUDE.md # Main project instructions
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ rules/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ code-style.md # Code style guidelines
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ testing.md # Testing conventions
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ security.md # Security requirements

All .md files in .claude/rules/ are automatically loaded as project memory, with the same priority as .claude/CLAUDE.md.

### Path-specific rules

Rules can be scoped to specific files using YAML frontmatter with the paths field. These conditional rules only apply when Claude is working with files matching the specified patterns.
---
paths:
 - "src/api/**/*.ts"
---

# API Development Rules

- All API endpoints must include input validation
- Use the standard error response format
- Include OpenAPI documentation comments

Rules without a paths field are loaded unconditionally and apply to all files.

### Glob patterns

The paths field supports standard glob patterns:
PatternMatches
**/*.tsAll TypeScript files in any directory
src/**/*All files under src/ directory
*.mdMarkdown files in the project root
src/components/*.tsxReact components in a specific directory

You can specify multiple patterns:
---
paths:
 - "src/**/*.ts"
 - "lib/**/*.ts"
 - "tests/**/*.test.ts"
---

Brace expansion is supported for matching multiple extensions or directories:
---
paths:
 - "src/**/*.{ts,tsx}"
 - "{src,lib}/**/*.ts"
---

# TypeScript/React Rules

This expands src/**/*.{ts,tsx} to match both .ts and .tsx files.

### Subdirectories

Rules can be organized into subdirectories for better structure:
.claude/rules/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ frontend/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ react.md
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ styles.md
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ backend/
‚îÇ ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ api.md
‚îÇ ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ database.md
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ general.md

All .md files are discovered recursively.

### Symlinks

The .claude/rules/ directory supports symlinks, allowing you to share common rules across multiple projects:
# Symlink a shared rules directory
ln -s ~/shared-claude-rules .claude/rules/shared

# Symlink individual rule files
ln -s ~/company-standards/security.md .claude/rules/security.md

Symlinks are resolved and their contents are loaded normally. Circular symlinks are detected and handled gracefully.

### User-level rules

You can create personal rules that apply to all your projects in ~/.claude/rules/:
~/.claude/rules/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ preferences.md # Your personal coding preferences
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ workflows.md # Your preferred workflows

User-level rules are loaded before project rules, giving project rules higher priority.

## Organization-level memory management

Organizations can deploy centrally managed CLAUDE.md files that apply to all users.
To set up organization-level memory management:

- Create the managed memory file at the Managed policy location shown in the [memory types table above](#determine-memory-type).

- Deploy via your configuration management system (MDM, Group Policy, Ansible, etc.) to ensure consistent distribution across all developer machines.

## Memory best practices

- Be specific: ‚ÄúUse 2-space indentation‚Äù is better than ‚ÄúFormat code properly‚Äù.

- Use structure to organize: Format each individual memory as a bullet point and group related memories under descriptive markdown headings.

- Review periodically: Update memories as your project evolves to ensure Claude is always using the most up to date information and context."
}

content.text:
Here's what Claude Code automatically reads on launch:

**Always loaded (highest ‚Üí lowest priority):**

1. **Managed policy** ‚Äî `/Library/Application Support/ClaudeCode/CLAUDE.md` (org-wide, you probably don't have this)
2. **User memory** ‚Äî `~/.claude/CLAUDE.md` (your personal prefs, applies to all projects)
3. **User rules** ‚Äî `~/.claude/rules/*.md` (personal modular rules)
4. **Project memory** ‚Äî `./CLAUDE.md` or `./.claude/CLAUDE.md` (team-shared, in the repo)
5. **Project rules** ‚Äî `./.claude/rules/*.md` (modular topic-specific rules)
6. **Project local** ‚Äî `./CLAUDE.local.md` (personal, not committed)

**Recursive discovery:** It walks up from your cwd to `/`, loading any `CLAUDE.md` or `CLAUDE.local.md` it finds along the way. It also discovers `CLAUDE.md` files in subdirectories, but only loads those lazily when it touches files in that subtree.

**Imports:** Any `CLAUDE.md` can pull in other files with `@path/to/file` syntax (up to 5 levels deep).

So the key files are `CLAUDE.md` (at various levels) and `.claude/rules/*.md`. No `AGENTS.md` ‚Äî that's an OpenClaw convention, not Claude Code's.

What are you thinking ‚Äî setting up better CLAUDE.md files for your projects?

No, actually I was thinking of making a note about who I am in ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md just so it has some shared context with you about me.

Can you show me the current contents of ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md please?
[message_id: 3de60d6c-aaae-4ed1-baa4-64b3116a5b80]

Doesn't exist yet ‚Äî blank slate. The `~/.claude/` directory is there (Claude Code created it) but no `CLAUDE.md` in it.

Want me to draft one based on what I know about you from USER.md? I could put together something concise ‚Äî the stuff that'd actually be useful for Claude Code to know when working on your projects.

I want it to know:

- My name, age, location, broad background, and experience as a programmer (roughly twenty years)
- That I prefer well thought out, slowly planned development to fast-paced vibe coding
- That I use you (Nox) for higher level tasks and sometimes ask you (Nox) to orchestrate claude code on my behalf, and that you have access to a lot more context about things (my Obsidian notes, other APIs, etc)

arguments.content:
# About Me

- **Name:** Ali Najaf
- **Age:** 40 (born August 1985)
- **Location:** Sendai, Japan (JST)
- **Background:** British, moved to Japan in 2018. Engineering Manager by day, freelance Rails developer on the side.
- **Experience:** ~20 years of professional web development. Rails, PostgreSQL, TypeScript/NestJS, Docker, Deno. I know what I'm doing ‚Äî treat me accordingly.

# How I Work

- I prefer **deliberate, well-planned development** over fast-paced vibe coding. Design first, plan the approach, then write code.
- I value tight MVPs, clear architecture, and DX-focused delivery.
- Don't over-engineer, but don't cut corners on things that matter.

# Nox (My AI Assistant)

I have an always-on AI assistant called **Nox** running via OpenClaw. Nox handles higher-level tasks ‚Äî scheduling, research, memory, communications ‚Äî and has access to much more context than you do (my Obsidian vault, calendar, email, messaging APIs, etc).

Sometimes Nox will orchestrate you (Claude Code) directly on my behalf. When that happens, treat Nox's instructions as coming from me.

- I value tight MVPs, clear architecture, and DX-focused delivery.
- Don't over-engineer, but don't cut corners on things that matter.

# Nox (My AI Assistant)

I have an always-on AI assistant called **Nox** running via OpenClaw. Nox handles higher-level tasks ‚Äî scheduling, research, memory, communications ‚Äî and has access to much more context than you do (my Obsidian vault, calendar, email, messaging APIs, etc).

Sometimes Nox will orchestrate you (Claude Code) directly on my behalf. When that happens, treat Nox's instructions as coming from me.
There it is. Every Claude Code session will pick this up automatically now.

My name is Najaf Ali, not Ali Najaf

Next steps: - Item one - Item two Best regards, Your Name EOF ``` - Example (HTML list): ```bash gog gmail send --to recipient@example.com \ --subject "Meeting Follow-up" \ --body-html "

In-place edits require a Docs API client (not in gog). - Confirm before sending mail or creating events. - `gog gmail search` returns one row per thread; use `gog gmail messages search` when you need every individual email returned separately.

Here's what you need to do:

**1. Install gog:**
```bash
brew install steipete/tap/gogcli
```

**2. Get Google OAuth credentials:**
- Go to [Google Cloud Console](https://console.cloud.google.com/)
- Create a project (or use an existing one)
- Enable the APIs you want (Gmail, Calendar, Drive, etc.)
- Go to **Credentials** ‚Üí **Create OAuth Client ID** ‚Üí choose **Desktop app**
- Download the `client_secret.json` file

**3. Set up gog with those credentials:**
```bash
gog auth credentials /path/to/client_secret.json
gog auth add your@gmail.com --services gmail,calendar,drive,contacts,docs,sheets
```

That second command will open a browser for the OAuth consent flow. Once you approve, you're in.

The Google Cloud Console part is the most annoying step ‚Äî want to start there?

[message_id: 54eba3c9-b898-4f13-9435-f10caa7e9c79]

Enable the APIs you need. In the Google Cloud Console:

1. Go to **APIs & Services** ‚Üí **Library**
2. Search for and enable each of these:
   - Gmail API
   - Google Calendar API
   - Google Drive API
   - Google Contacts API (People API)
   - Google Sheets API
   - Google Docs API

Then create the OAuth credentials:

3. Go to **APIs & Services** ‚Üí **Credentials**
4. Click **Create Credentials** ‚Üí **OAuth Client ID**
5. If it asks you to configure the **OAuth consent screen** first, do that ‚Äî choose "External", fill in the basics (app name, your email), and add yourself as a test user
6. For application type, choose **Desktop app**
7. Download the JSON file it gives you

Once you've got that JSON file, let me know and we'll hook it up to gog.

content.text:
It's using the macOS Keychain by default (`keyring_backend: auto`). That's why it prompts you each time ‚Äî macOS asks permission to access the stored token.

You can switch it to file-based storage instead:

content.text:
The simplest fix is to just click "Always Allow" on the Keychain prompt next time it pops up ‚Äî that tells macOS to stop asking for `gog` specifically.

Alternatively, if you'd rather avoid Keychain entirely, you could set `GOG_KEYRING=file` as an environment variable (in your shell profile or in the OpenClaw gateway env). That stores tokens in a plain file instead. Less secure, but no popups.

Want me to set `GOG_KEYRING=file` in the gateway config so my calls don't trigger Keychain prompts?

As expected ‚Äî 403. The doc lives in Givery's Google Workspace (owned by `jay.geeseman@givery.co.jp`), and gog is authed with your personal `ali.najaf@gmail.com` account. Your personal Google account doesn't have API access to Givery workspace docs, even though your Givery calendar is shared to your personal one.

To read Givery docs, you'd need to auth gog with your `najaf.ali@givery.co.jp` account too ‚Äî but that's a Workspace account so it'd need admin approval for the OAuth app, which is probably more hassle than it's worth.

content.text: Nice ‚Äî goes back to 2007! Let me read the key emails to piece this together:

arguments.command:
gog gmail messages search "from:mingshi OR to:mingshi" --max 50 --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --json 2>&1 | python3 -c "
import sys, json
data = json.load(sys.stdin)
msgs = data.get('messages', [])
ids = [m['id'] for m in msgs]
print('\n'.join(ids))" 2>&1

# Read the earliest emails first
for id in 110b53083bedab5a 11359b1fb9cf3e85 1136c0446ce622dd 116236fb8cbe7cac 11632a7f7a0f2566; do
  echo "=== EMAIL $id ==="
  gog gmail messages get $id --account ali.najaf@gmail.com 2>&1 | head -30
  echo ""
done

content.text:
=== EMAIL 110b53083bedab5a ===
id	110b53083bedab5a
thread_id	110b40bb8b74d362
label_ids	SENT
from	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
to	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
subject	Re: Hey
date	Mon, 12 Feb 2007 09:02:40 +0000

Wow, just wow. This really is a story of you just plugging away, paying your
dues and finally getting a break. I'm really happy for you! I knew your shit
was hot and didn't understand why you weren't prouder of it, I think now
that you've got recognition things are only going to get better for your
confidence and work.

The issue with me and whats going on is... basically this. I can barely keep
up with the opportunities that are being thrown at me, let alone inform my
family and friends. Everything out here is so up in the air. I know I'm
going to Tokyo or Osaka, I know I will have a job and a place to stay. There
are a number of business/career ideas that I would curse by explaining (but
basically, a translating gig selling boats from NZ to the japanese market,
bar/restaurant/x business after I've saved enough, recruitment consulting,
english teaching, interpreting (simultaneous or consecutive).

To give you an idea, how sure were you of the next step when you were 21? I
know in the long term, by 30 (preferably 25) I don't want to be working for
anyone but me. For that I'm saving and investing my heart out, at least 20%
of any money that comes my way.

I think its still too early for me to be making any big distinctions about
Japan based on my 'life experience'. I'm still a young buck with a lot to
experience out here in the real world, and I'm only just taking my baby
steps now. In that, I've decided that right now is the time to be enjoying
my life. Every day is a good day for me here, or anywhere.  I'm not waiting
for some big event before it's ok to be enjoying myself. Sure I have a lot
of goals, but I'm also busy enjoying the results of my previous achievements
too.

My priorities right now are pretty simple, get into adventures, increase
income, and take care of my health. As long as I'm pushing myself in all
those areas every day then I can sleep happy. Yeah I fool around with a lot
of girls, I drink, I party, I waste money and sometimes I eat too much. But
hey, I'm not perfect. I'm at least moving in the right direction :)

I'll send more later, gotta tidy up my apaaato.

hugs and kisses

Ali

On 2/12/07, Mingshi.Jenny Wan <mingshi.wan@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hello Ali,
>
> Finally take a break from boring work and can write back!
>
> I've restarted job-hunting starting last week, and have been emailing
> my CV to design studio and other possible places. You've been luckily
> to escape from a good round of my ranting on unreasonable, unpaying,
> time-wasting clients. Recently I got some freelance projects to work
> on, but they are all terribly uncreative, unstimulating, joyless work.
> Even though I might take in more of those boring ones whenever
> possible, I've enough practical work to show around comparing to a few
> months ago, and this gave me the confidence on the job-hunt.
>
> The wait has proven to be worthwhile. Last Thurs I've been to the best
> design place I know in Hong Kong!!! The studio does art direction for
> Metropop (from the same company of Metro in London - but Metropop is a
> weekly mag), and I was only asking to be considered for the
> illustration space opposite a column the director wrote in there. To
> my surprise I ended up chatting to this famous designer for 2 hours
> straight!
>
> The job interview I went at a small studio the day before was nothing
> like this conversation. With Mr Tommy Li, we talked through local
> design issues, how he bought up new talents from his studio, and his
> way of dealing with clients... It's quite amusing how an icon like him
> who I have read in various design mags for years, suddenly spent 2
> hours speaking so openly to me. His knowledge and passion to change
> the local design scene seriously put me back to think about my
> position as a designer, adding to the fact that someone so famous in
> my field LIKES my portfolio. The conversation was so refreshing that
> I've to record it in parts on my other blog. I might show you later
> when it's completed. Meanwhile, this is their website:-
>
> http://www.tommylidesign.com/
>
> Besides that I also get involved in a secret blogpet network project
> with some old friend (a net friend I know since 16, but lost touch
> when I left for the UK, and caught up very recently). I'll be
> responsible for the character design and related artwork, and he and
> his partner will do the programming. The duo is very visionary about
> all these will work, and if things go smoothly, we would produce a
> project successful enough for Google to buy. My friend did all these
> crazy student leadership programs and maths olympics back at
> schooldays, so I could really believe I'm contributing to something
> worth my while. Jobs that I take are only based on 2 reasons, money or
> job satisfaction. This one is definitely of the latter. There are also
> a few smaller design competition that will keep me occupied for the
> rest of the workhours.
>
> These little incidents that flashes by in the past few months get me
> think about the future a lot. Now I'm not as lonely and bored that I
> have to go out sitting in pubs talking to strangers at the weekends.
> It was 2 months ago since I had my last date, but I don't feel too
> sad, with a nice memory of an unattainable relationship that keeps me
> looking ahead. Perhaps I am going forward to a better life than
> before. My passion to be a good designer is my main drive now, and I
> choose this path for myself. I am not sure where it leads to, but I'm
> expecting it's all going to be satisfying after all the struggle.
>
> How are you doing at your end? I've only briefly read bits and pieces
> from your little blog, but I do wonder what you are telling your
> family about your life. You haven't mentioned what exactly you enjoy
> doing or planning to do in the future. What do you think you'll get
> out of this JET program in the end? I'm sure dating Japanese girls is
> not the only thing you can be proud of, since everyone elses does the
> same. Does your life experience change the way you think about Japan
> before you came? You recorded some events but didn't say what inspires
> you or what strong feelings you have in them, which is what I am more
> interested to know.
>
> Valentines Day is coming and I hope you have a good day with a nice
> harvest of chocolate. I am only going to meet up with a friend and
> have a light drink with her to cheer her up I think. Chinese New Year
> holiday is on the next weekend. It's good to take a break with the
> family, no kendo, and keep looking ahead for my design future.
> Meanwhile I'll follow instructions from a big-ish jewellery company
> putting up their address card and jewellery care cards for
> customers... adding to some promotional gifts order forms I'm doing
> for Coca Cola.... (I told you it's getting boring zzzz)
>
> Hug hug,
> Jenny
>
>
> --
> Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
> Graphic Designer + Illustrator
>
> m. +852 6301 4175
> e. mingshi.wan@gmail.com
> w. http://www.mingshiwan.com
>


---

=== EMAIL 11359b1fb9cf3e85 ===
id	11359b1fb9cf3e85
thread_id	11359b1fb9cf3e85
label_ids	
from	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	hisashiburi desune~
date	Sun, 24 Jun 2007 01:47:22 +0800

Hey Najaf,

Just happened to read in your blog about your new job offer in Tokyo.
What a great move!

For the last couple of months I've been too occupied to sit down and
write you a little something - the unfinished one I wrote during
Easter was too outdated and therefore deleted... I just bought myself
a nice PC after getting some good $$ on the stocks I have - and I need
to catch up with some flash website design freelance...

So you are really settling in Japan for quite a long while? Is that
the job you wanted and are you staying for it long? Yen is cheap and I
might jump on a plane and visit Tokyo. (Planned to find friends in
London but the pounds only gets even more expensive...) It's strange
that when I am at work, I always think about what I am doing on a
holiday -just somewhere, but not sure where yet.

Life is a bit too regular and plain at my job at the mo. It's going OK
after 3 months (just passed probation period). The other month I was
annoyed by clients who pretend they were designers and the boss who
was uninspiring to improve my work. But now the workload increased
madly which left me less time to stress up and be emotional - people
just become easier to deal with and projects flow smoother. Designed a
few leaflets and posters in the past few months, and right now busy
with some boring signage for some downtown McDonald's.(<-- totally
gay...)

I used the same relaxed attitude to fight my last taikai (individual
ladies open) and I WON. Totally unexpected experince as I wasn't in
regular training at all. Kendo feels more fun now on a Thurs after
work. I'm struggling to get sandan in Aug, so I just have to force
myself to practice (and a good excuse to escape from overtime work).
It makes your feet numb after sitting in front of the computer all day
long - and I really want to stay healthier. I visited the doctor twice
in 3 months...

In a month's time I'm finishing my Sankyu Nihongo course and moving on
to motorbike riding... I almost fall asleep sitting in the class after
work, as I haven't had the passion and time for studying!! Driving is
the plan for my 25th birthday, and I have so much other things I want
to learn lining up after that. Evening classes fit fine at my current
work schedule, so I'm trying to make the most out of my free time.
Finally I have some plans in life that I am looking forward to, and I
hope I won't lost the momentum whatever happens next.

How about the girls you hang out with in Miyako? Anyone following you
all the way to Tokyo? :D

With all the work and activities going on with me, I lost the interest
in maintaining a relationship. I felt that if I'm not in a good
position in keeping one, maybe I should just stop looking, take a
break, and enjoy being single. That's what I've been thinking for the
past few months, and haven't been out doing pub crawl for quite a
while...

Then came this really surreal incident that I'm seeing Kevin the Kiwi
engineer again. One day in March I had a 3-min MSN chat and found out
that he's leaving HK for Guam, and we were just catching up that
weekend. I felt very comfortable in seeing him again, and in mutual
agreement that we are back together for a while. And for the past 3
months I've only seen him 3 times in person, and perhaps MSN
conversation that last for 3 mins every 2 weeks. It feels strange to
keep a relationship this way, with us so physically and emotionally
apart, I can still find comfort. Next month he'll be moving
permanently, and I'll just wait and see how the farewell goes.

I guess I'm "so nice" that I can never get out of the whole
appreciating-guys-I-can't-be-with-for-long cycle. Now I'm not sure if
I should stop looking completely, or would I like to keep on dating
different guys for a short period of time. I did wonder how you
maintain a Jame Bond lifestyle - don't you freak girls out telling
them you are only into casual relationships?

Right - it's 1.30am and I should be having a sound sleep on a Sunday.
Hope you sort out your new apartment, make some good food for
yourself, and enjoy what's in Tokyo - that's where you always wanted
to be in, isn't it?

Big hugs,
Jenny

As usual you seem pretty stable and secure in your career and life in

details.aggregated:
=== EMAIL 110b53083bedab5a ===
id	110b53083bedab5a
thread_id	110b40bb8b74d362
label_ids	SENT
from	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
to	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
subject	Re: Hey
date	Mon, 12 Feb 2007 09:02:40 +0000

Wow, just wow. This really is a story of you just plugging away, paying your
dues and finally getting a break. I'm really happy for you! I knew your shit
was hot and didn't understand why you weren't prouder of it, I think now
that you've got recognition things are only going to get better for your
confidence and work.

The issue with me and whats going on is... basically this. I can barely keep
up with the opportunities that are being thrown at me, let alone inform my
family and friends. Everything out here is so up in the air. I know I'm
going to Tokyo or Osaka, I know I will have a job and a place to stay. There
are a number of business/career ideas that I would curse by explaining (but
basically, a translating gig selling boats from NZ to the japanese market,
bar/restaurant/x business after I've saved enough, recruitment consulting,
english teaching, interpreting (simultaneous or consecutive).

To give you an idea, how sure were you of the next step when you were 21? I
know in the long term, by 30 (preferably 25) I don't want to be working for
anyone but me. For that I'm saving and investing my heart out, at least 20%
of any money that comes my way.

I think its still too early for me to be making any big distinctions about
Japan based on my 'life experience'. I'm still a young buck with a lot to
experience out here in the real world, and I'm only just taking my baby
steps now. In that, I've decided that right now is the time to be enjoying
my life. Every day is a good day for me here, or anywhere.  I'm not waiting
for some big event before it's ok to be enjoying myself. Sure I have a lot
of goals, but I'm also busy enjoying the results of my previous achievements
too.

My priorities right now are pretty simple, get into adventures, increase
income, and take care of my health. As long as I'm pushing myself in all
those areas every day then I can sleep happy. Yeah I fool around with a lot
of girls, I drink, I party, I waste money and sometimes I eat too much. But
hey, I'm not perfect. I'm at least moving in the right direction :)

I'll send more later, gotta tidy up my apaaato.

hugs and kisses

Ali

On 2/12/07, Mingshi.Jenny Wan <mingshi.wan@gmail.com> wrote:
>
> Hello Ali,
>
> Finally take a break from boring work and can write back!
>
> I've restarted job-hunting starting last week, and have been emailing
> my CV to design studio and other possible places. You've been luckily
> to escape from a good round of my ranting on unreasonable, unpaying,
> time-wasting clients. Recently I got some freelance projects to work
> on, but they are all terribly uncreative, unstimulating, joyless work.
> Even though I might take in more of those boring ones whenever
> possible, I've enough practical work to show around comparing to a few
> months ago, and this gave me the confidence on the job-hunt.
>
> The wait has proven to be worthwhile. Last Thurs I've been to the best
> design place I know in Hong Kong!!! The studio does art direction for
> Metropop (from the same company of Metro in London - but Metropop is a
> weekly mag), and I was only asking to be considered for the
> illustration space opposite a column the director wrote in there. To
> my surprise I ended up chatting to this famous designer for 2 hours
> straight!
>
> The job interview I went at a small studio the day before was nothing
> like this conversation. With Mr Tommy Li, we talked through local
> design issues, how he bought up new talents from his studio, and his
> way of dealing with clients... It's quite amusing how an icon like him
> who I have read in various design mags for years, suddenly spent 2
> hours speaking so openly to me. His knowledge and passion to change
> the local design scene seriously put me back to think about my
> position as a designer, adding to the fact that someone so famous in
> my field LIKES my portfolio. The conversation was so refreshing that
> I've to record it in parts on my other blog. I might show you later
> when it's completed. Meanwhile, this is their website:-
>
> http://www.tommylidesign.com/
>
> Besides that I also get involved in a secret blogpet network project
> with some old friend (a net friend I know since 16, but lost touch
> when I left for the UK, and caught up very recently). I'll be
> responsible for the character design and related artwork, and he and
> his partner will do the programming. The duo is very visionary about
> all these will work, and if things go smoothly, we would produce a
> project successful enough for Google to buy. My friend did all these
> crazy student leadership programs and maths olympics back at
> schooldays, so I could really believe I'm contributing to something
> worth my while. Jobs that I take are only based on 2 reasons, money or
> job satisfaction. This one is definitely of the latter. There are also
> a few smaller design competition that will keep me occupied for the
> rest of the workhours.
>
> These little incidents that flashes by in the past few months get me
> think about the future a lot. Now I'm not as lonely and bored that I
> have to go out sitting in pubs talking to strangers at the weekends.
> It was 2 months ago since I had my last date, but I don't feel too
> sad, with a nice memory of an unattainable relationship that keeps me
> looking ahead. Perhaps I am going forward to a better life than
> before. My passion to be a good designer is my main drive now, and I
> choose this path for myself. I am not sure where it leads to, but I'm
> expecting it's all going to be satisfying after all the struggle.
>
> How are you doing at your end? I've only briefly read bits and pieces
> from your little blog, but I do wonder what you are telling your
> family about your life. You haven't mentioned what exactly you enjoy
> doing or planning to do in the future. What do you think you'll get
> out of this JET program in the end? I'm sure dating Japanese girls is
> not the only thing you can be proud of, since everyone elses does the
> same. Does your life experience change the way you think about Japan
> before you came? You recorded some events but didn't say what inspires
> you or what strong feelings you have in them, which is what I am more
> interested to know.
>
> Valentines Day is coming and I hope you have a good day with a nice
> harvest of chocolate. I am only going to meet up with a friend and
> have a light drink with her to cheer her up I think. Chinese New Year
> holiday is on the next weekend. It's good to take a break with the
> family, no kendo, and keep looking ahead for my design future.
> Meanwhile I'll follow instructions from a big-ish jewellery company
> putting up their address card and jewellery care cards for
> customers... adding to some promotional gifts order forms I'm doing
> for Coca Cola.... (I told you it's getting boring zzzz)
>
> Hug hug,
> Jenny
>
>
> --
> Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
> Graphic Designer + Illustrator
>
> m. +852 6301 4175
> e. mingshi.wan@gmail.com
> w. http://www.mingshiwan.com
>

=== EMAIL 11359b1fb9cf3e85 ===
id	11359b1fb9cf3e85
thread_id	11359b1fb9cf3e85
label_ids	
from	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	hisashiburi desune~
date	Sun, 24 Jun 2007 01:47:22 +0800

Hey Najaf,

Just happened to read in your blog about your new job offer in Tokyo.
What a great move!

For the last couple of months I've been too occupied to sit down and
write you a little something - the unfinished one I wrote during
Easter was too outdated and therefore deleted... I just bought myself
a nice PC after getting some good $$ on the stocks I have - and I need
to catch up with some flash website design freelance...

So you are really settling in Japan for quite a long while? Is that
the job you wanted and are you staying for it long? Yen is cheap and I
might jump on a plane and visit Tokyo. (Planned to find friends in
London but the pounds only gets even more expensive...) It's strange
that when I am at work, I always think about what I am doing on a
holiday -just somewhere, but not sure where yet.

Life is a bit too regular and plain at my job at the mo. It's going OK
after 3 months (just passed probation period). The other month I was
annoyed by clients who pretend they were designers and the boss who
was uninspiring to improve my work. But now the workload increased
madly which left me less time to stress up and be emotional - people
just become easier to deal with and projects flow smoother. Designed a
few leaflets and posters in the past few months, and right now busy
with some boring signage for some downtown McDonald's.(<-- totally
gay...)

I used the same relaxed attitude to fight my last taikai (individual
ladies open) and I WON. Totally unexpected experince as I wasn't in
regular training at all. Kendo feels more fun now on a Thurs after
work. I'm struggling to get sandan in Aug, so I just have to force
myself to practice (and a good excuse to escape from overtime work).
It makes your feet numb after sitting in front of the computer all day
long - and I really want to stay healthier. I visited the doctor twice
in 3 months...

In a month's time I'm finishing my Sankyu Nihongo course and moving on
to motorbike riding... I almost fall asleep sitting in the class after
work, as I haven't had the passion and time for studying!! Driving is
the plan for my 25th birthday, and I have so much other things I want
to learn lining up after that. Evening classes fit fine at my current
work schedule, so I'm trying to make the most out of my free time.
Finally I have some plans in life that I am looking forward to, and I
hope I won't lost the momentum whatever happens next.

How about the girls you hang out with in Miyako? Anyone following you
all the way to Tokyo? :D

With all the work and activities going on with me, I lost the interest
in maintaining a relationship. I felt that if I'm not in a good
position in keeping one, maybe I should just stop looking, take a
break, and enjoy being single. That's what I've been thinking for the
past few months, and haven't been out doing pub crawl for quite a
while...

Then came this really surreal incident that I'm seeing Kevin the Kiwi
engineer again. One day in March I had a 3-min MSN chat and found out
that he's leaving HK for Guam, and we were just catching up that
weekend. I felt very comfortable in seeing him again, and in mutual
agreement that we are back together for a while. And for the past 3
months I've only seen him 3 times in person, and perhaps MSN
conversation that last for 3 mins every 2 weeks. It feels strange to
keep a relationship this way, with us so physically and emotionally
apart, I can still find comfort. Next month he'll be moving
permanently, and I'll just wait and see how the farewell goes.

I guess I'm "so nice" that I can never get out of the whole
appreciating-guys-I-can't-be-with-for-long cycle. Now I'm not sure if
I should stop looking completely, or would I like to keep on dating
different guys for a short period of time. I did wonder how you
maintain a Jame Bond lifestyle - don't you freak girls out telling
them you are only into casual relationships?

Right - it's 1.30am and I should be having a sound sleep on a Sunday.
Hope you sort out your new apartment, make some good food for
yourself, and enjoy what's in Tokyo - that's where you always wanted
to be in, isn't it?

Big hugs,
Jenny


---

=== EMAIL 116cc3a7d24e7f25 ===
id	116cc3a7d24e7f25

to	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
subject	logo design
date	Wed, 12 Dec 2007 11:41:33 +0900

Hey Jenny,

Hope all is
well. Sorry about the business tone to this email but I'm so busy
these days I can't tell left from right. Need some sleep... zzzzzzz


I'm trying to get my tour business off the ground and I could do with some
advice on getting my logo designed. If you're interested I'd be happy to pay
you to do it (as I understand you do a lot of freelance work).

The company is basically a tour provider with a focus on (surprise surprise)
having adventures in japan. The website is:

www.adventureinjapan.com

The general feeling is on of discovery, adventure and exploring the unknown.
I'll need to use it for letterheads, the website and business cards (so I'll
need black and white versions for dark and light backgrounds). Let me know
if you're interested or you know someone who would be.

Regards

Ali


---

subject	Re: logo design
date	Wed, 12 Dec 2007 14:55:00 +0800

Hello Ali,

Since my boss just went out for lunch, I am giving your site a quick
look....uhmm

You are right I've been taking quite a lot of freelance projects
lately. It's getting so insane that I think I earn more than my day
job for the past 2 months (...more ridiculous is my salary urrghh). I
think I should steal your idea and set up my own business soon!!

Anyway if it's about business then you are very welcome to be my
client. Actually I charge for all those kendo posters I made for other
people. :p

As I said it's a busy season, I wonder what your schedule is like? I'm
so fully occupied until Xmas (bedtime has been 3am for the past 2
weeks). If you are not super urgent then I can give your project full
attentions around xmas/new year holiday period.

If that's fine then you can brief me in further details about your
expectations, requirements, reference and budget.

I only roughly looked at your site, and perhaps it is still at its
developing stage. To me the tone sounds "mature adults" (?) if you
know what I mean. Say, comparing to the on most travel booking sites
or tourism board sites. They usually have a lot of  photos, using
bright colours and less text-heavy. Is your arrangement intentional?
(and what's with the ultra large font size...?)

Well I should get back to work now. Meanwhile I will share what I've
been doing for the past few nights!

http://www.mingshiwan.com/clientftp/071124CAS/ecard05.html

My eyeballs are going to fall out any minute!!

Write soon,

Jenny

-- 
Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
Graphic Designer + Illustrator

m. +852 6301 4175

=== EMAIL 116cd40efdfe34ee ===
id	116cd40efdfe34ee
thread_id	116cc3a7d24e7f25
label_ids	SENT
from	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
to	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
subject	Re: logo design
date	Wed, 12 Dec 2007 16:28:13 +0900

Sounds good sounds good. I'll go through all of your points in order:

a) Time

I'm not so urgent so I can wait until after the holidays. Having the logo by
around mid-February would be ideal, does that sound realistic?

b) Budget

Unlike the good old days (expensive restaurants in London etc.. :P) I'm
living on a poor English teachers salary. That being the case, before
approaching you I had a figure of between 10,000 and 20,000 JPY in mind. Let
me know what you think.

c) Other stuff (expectations, requirements and references)

I'll be completely honest, I'm not sure what you mean by these. I'm probably
going to be one of those problem clients who needs their hand held through
the whole process! I'll try to answer what I THINK you mean in the
following:

Here are some of my competitors websites:

http://www.oxalis-adventures.com/
http://www.insidejapantours.com/index.php

unfortunately I don't like either of those websites.

You were right when you said that the theme was more kind of 'mature adult'.
It wasn't intentional but it just came out that way. Big font sizes are
easier to read, but I guess I should make them a little smaller. I would
like to use more photos, but I'm not so good at sizing and positioning them
well with the text (which is still a work in progress) so it's trial and
error until I find the right look.

To be honest I'm not really sure what I want in the logo. The basic concepts
I want to convey are 'Japan' and 'Adventure'. Aside from that I'm pretty
open to ideas. Generally speaking the simpler the better. Also, I don't want
the text 'Adventure In Japan' actually in the logo itself. Instead I will
use it alongside the text 'Adventure In Japan', probably in Georgia like on
the website.

As I said in my previous email I need greyscale versions that I can use on
dark and light backgrounds. Other than that I don't have any requirements
per se, unless there's anything else in particular that you want me to
decide on.

Let me know if you're interested

Ali

=== EMAIL 116d4464bd489301 ===
id	116d4464bd489301
thread_id	116cc3a7d24e7f25
label_ids	
from	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	Re: logo design
date	Fri, 14 Dec 2007 00:11:24 +0800

Hey Najaf,

Thanks for explaining. As usual you seem to have a good plan about
what you are going to do. I may actually be helping you to push your
plan further, and give you more thoughts about the workable

Time-wise the design process should be fine for me as I'll get less
busy... soon. You'll need a few months to put things together -
especially if you are doing some print production.

For business I usually charge my logo (and usually with name card
design) at around 36,000 JPY, which is cheap comparing to of where I
work -- BUT I've also worked for individual start-up businesses (girls
selling accessories on Ebay....) that can only spare below 20,000. AND
as a special friend of yours, I'd like to help you out with my
"professional" skills. So your budget range is okay (if you have other
business partners to contribute?) and hopefully no one is giving
anyone a hard time in the process (some clients do, waste of time,
rant rant).

Do keep in mind that if you are going to print cards and A4
letterheads and envelops, you need to have a budget in that too.
There's some cheap-er printers in Hong Kong if you are interested (and
not fancy top quality paper and print effects).

Technical specs are fine there. Now speaking about references, you are
on the right track showing me your competitors. But then I can just
randomly ask you about your company to help me picture the business
(this may also help you understand yours too):-

- How different is yours from the competitors (and why do you not like
their site)? Expertise, service, value, etc.
- (and followed by) What is the message you want to tell your target customers?
- Who are your target customers? Age, budget, interest, etc.?

These are starters, and I usually ask clients to refer me to logos
they like, not restricted to their own business.

If you are into the researching part, I'd suggest looking into any
travel site (not just Japan), any tourism board site, and for you,
city guided tours of other cities or historic sites. (Suddenly I
remember seeing a lot of guides at Angkor Wat - and I wonder how my
experience will change if I were with one) I think Hong Kong, S Korea,
Singapore has great promo on TV (and web) that is attractive for the
general public. From their site you'll see how they, with brand
consultancy and marketing people's help, build their image, and make
users/customers find the service they want. Remember it's not just
about your tour, but also how exciting Japan can be, so many things
you can see and do, yadda yadda.

That's what I can think of so far, and if you think I'm going too
bossy already then, forget what I said :p  But I hope I sound
encouraging to what you are doing, and can contribute to another great
start-up business.

Meanwhile I'll forward you some "recent" logos I did (from boring sh!t
to more exciting ones).

Anyway, think things over and we'll talk again soon.

Hugs,
Jenny

=== EMAIL 116d6d8f8f385120 ===
id	116d6d8f8f385120
thread_id	116cc3a7d24e7f25
label_ids	SENT
from	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
to	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
subject	Re: logo design
date	Fri, 14 Dec 2007 13:10:52 +0900

Thanks again for your mail.

You're right that I need to think a few things through. Here are some basic
points that I want to convey in reponse to your email. I wrote the important
text in bold so you can skim and read it in detail at a later date.

1. *My budget is ridiculously low.*
Right now I'm planning on getting business using a website and adsense (plus
a few other targeted ad campaigns, like at japan-guide if I can afford it).
I don't really have the money to put together printed publicity
*properly*so I'd rather save up and do it at a later date.  Before
that I've got to
figure out who I'll be sending it to, and start making agreements with
travel agents etc. Oh and by the way, for now there are no business
partners, just me alone. I would be happy to pay you up to 20,000 yen for
the logo alone, and we can talk about business cards etc at a later date for
its own set fee.

2. *Expectations*
I'm not sure how you work, but this is kind of what I was expecting. After I
give you all the information you need (I'll get there eventually, I
promise!) then I'm hoping that you would give me two or three basic sketches
to choose from, and we could pick one to work on further. You may have a
better workflow than this in which case we can go with that instead.

3. *References
*I've read through many tourist sites and got a general feel for how they
market them. Although I need a bit of training on marketing and sales,
generally speaking I don't like how they just throw around names of tourist
attractions and expect people to pay exorbitant fees for them.

The main difference between me and my competitors is that while their  main
product is a tour from A to B to C at set times with booking and
reservations, with the actual historical items and attractions left to speak
for themselves.

My main product includes all that, but the main value is in the experience
of the tour and the guide service, making sure it runs without a hitch and
that it is ordered and scripted to give customers the maximum emotional
experience they could possibly have while in Japan (think about how guys
plan dates to get their objects of affection excited and ready).

The only company that comes close to the ideal I'm aiming for is London
Walks. <http://www.walks.com/>


4. *Your questions*:
(difference from competitors)
Basically:
Oxalis: Staying at onsen, hiking in the mountains, exploring the countryside
Inside Japan: Tours exploring the cities and countryside of Japan.
Adventure In Japan: One day tours and day-trips in and around the Tokyo
Area.

*Inside Japan Cheapens Japanese Culture*
From a subjective standpoint I don't like the way that Inside Japan is laid
out. The way it has castles, maiko, cherry blossoms all collaged into one
picture kind of belittles the individual objects, reducing it to a cultural
buffet for tourists to pick and choose from. While that is inevitably true
to some extent, from Adventure In Japan I'd like to give more reverence for
each cultural item.

*I would rather do a few tours really really well, than a lot of them
mediocre*
Also, although I do want to grow the business and do various tours (expand
nationally, do longer tours) I don't think I will ever grow to do 8 or 9
different itenaries. I would much rather do three or four tours *well*, than
do 8 or 9 half-assed. I will of course offer a high degree of
customisability to guests though.

*Currently, I am smaller and more agile than my competitors*
Those two are the big dog competitors. There are a number of other smaller
firms operating out of Tokyo that I don't give much consideration to. Given
my situation, I am outfinanced, outnumbered and outadvertised. So I've got
to play to my strengths.

From a business standpoint, I am:

-More Flexible, I can arrange a tour with a weeks notice.
-More Controlled, I am 100% of my staff :P



(message for target customers)
The core 'soul' of my company revolves around four main points:

i) *Loving Japan*. I know it sounds melodramatic but there's so much to do
and study here that if I had the time I could study history and explore and
travel and die happy. Difficult to convey in words but if you remember the
feeling when you first came to Japan and everything is amazing and new, it's
that but a slow-burning, long-term version of that enthusiasm.

ii)*Depth of Knowledge*. Not only about Japan, it's history and economy but
also about having contacts, places to go and things to see that other
tourist guide services don't. I am currently studying Japanese history (and
as you know, am pretty fluent in Japanese) and studying up on Japanese
culture and info about the main tourist attractions. While I don't want to
give guests a history lecture on the tours, I want them to feel as if their
guide is a generally smart and knowledgeable person who can gives relevant
interesting information, rather than just a robot taking them from point A
to B to C.

iii)*Customer Service*. Another raging gay cliche, but it has to be said. An
example of this is say, if a guest wants to change the tour and go somewhere
else then not only are we ready to do that, we can actually give them
recommendations (rather than what other companies might say 'sorry, can't
change the itenary in the middle of the tour'). This could also extend to
going for drinks with guests after the tour, sending ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to our guests or
any number of good ideas I have to make the best impression possible on
them.

iv)*Fucking Sexy Tours.* Ever been to a foreign country or city and had such
a deliriously good time that you were getting excited and email your friends
and talking about it all night with your travel partners? Didn't think so.
AIJ is there to fill that gap. Over time I want the tours to be crafted to
perfection. The right time of day to go to an attraction, the best nearby
restaurants, exclusive events, the best order of attractions in a tour etc.
I want the guests to be able to sit back and watch me orchestrate a symphony
using the landscape, taking them from place to place as I tell them the
story of this city and country. Essentially, the tour should be an amazing
experience even if it were done in their hometown or city.


Wow, you were right! Writing this all out helped loads! I'm probably going
to use excerpts from this as copy for the website!

(who are my target customers?)

Smart, middle-class American/English Tourists. Probably 25 years old and up,
I'm guessing the majority of my customers would be in their 30's.

Ok, I'm running overtime, so feel free to ask for clarification or to go
over any of those points again.

later

Ali

having adventures in japan. The website is:

The general feeling is on of discovery, adventure and exploring the unknown.
I'll need to use it for letterheads, the website and business cards (so I'll
need black and white versions for dark and light backgrounds). Let me know
if you're interested or you know someone who would be.

Regards

Ali

Sounds good sounds good. I'll go through all of your points in order:

a) Time

I'm not so urgent so I can wait until after the holidays. Having the logo by
around mid-February would be ideal, does that sound realistic?

b) Budget

Unlike the good old days (expensive restaurants in London etc.. :P) I'm
living on a poor English teachers salary. That being the case, before
approaching you I had a figure of between 10,000 and 20,000 JPY in mind. Let
me know what you think.

c) Other stuff (expectations, requirements and references)

I'll be completely honest, I'm not sure what you mean by these. I'm probably
going to be one of those problem clients who needs their hand held through
the whole process! I'll try to answer what I THINK you mean in the
following:

Here are some of my competitors websites:

http://www.oxalis-adventures.com/
http://www.insidejapantours.com/index.php

unfortunately I don't like either of those websites.

You were right when you said that the theme was more kind of 'mature adult'.
It wasn't intentional but it just came out that way. Big font sizes are
easier to read, but I guess I should make them a little smaller. I would
like to use more photos, but I'm not so good at sizing and positioning them
well with the text (which is still a work in progress) so it's trial and
error until I find the right look.

To be honest I'm not really sure what I want in the logo. The basic concepts
I want to convey are 'Japan' and 'Adventure'. Aside from that I'm pretty
open to ideas. Generally speaking the simpler the better. Also, I don't want
the text 'Adventure In Japan' actually in the logo itself. Instead I will
use it alongside the text 'Adventure In Japan', probably in Georgia like on
the website.

As I said in my previous email I need greyscale versions that I can use on
dark and light backgrounds. Other than that I don't have any requirements
per se, unless there's anything else in particular that you want me to
decide on.

Let me know if you're interested

Ali

Hey Najaf,

Thanks for explaining. As usual you seem to have a good plan about
what you are going to do. I may actually be helping you to push your
plan further, and give you more thoughts about the workable

Time-wise the design process should be fine for me as I'll get less
busy... soon. You'll need a few months to put things together -
especially if you are doing some print production.

For business I usually charge my logo (and usually with name card
design) at around 36,000 JPY, which is cheap comparing to of where I
work -- BUT I've also worked for individual start-up businesses (girls
selling accessories on Ebay....) that can only spare below 20,000. AND
as a special friend of yours, I'd like to help you out with my
"professional" skills. So your budget range is okay (if you have other
business partners to contribute?) and hopefully no one is giving
anyone a hard time in the process (some clients do, waste of time,
rant rant).

Do keep in mind that if you are going to print cards and A4
letterheads and envelops, you need to have a budget in that too.
There's some cheap-er printers in Hong Kong if you are interested (and
not fancy top quality paper and print effects).

Technical specs are fine there. Now speaking about references, you are
on the right track showing me your competitors. But then I can just
randomly ask you about your company to help me picture the business
(this may also help you understand yours too):-

- How different is yours from the competitors (and why do you not like
their site)? Expertise, service, value, etc.
- (and followed by) What is the message you want to tell your target customers?
- Who are your target customers? Age, budget, interest, etc.?

These are starters, and I usually ask clients to refer me to logos
they like, not restricted to their own business.

If you are into the researching part, I'd suggest looking into any
travel site (not just Japan), any tourism board site, and for you,
city guided tours of other cities or historic sites. (Suddenly I
remember seeing a lot of guides at Angkor Wat - and I wonder how my
experience will change if I were with one) I think Hong Kong, S Korea,
Singapore has great promo on TV (and web) that is attractive for the
general public. From their site you'll see how they, with brand
consultancy and marketing people's help, build their image, and make
users/customers find the service they want. Remember it's not just
about your tour, but also how exciting Japan can be, so many things
you can see and do, yadda yadda.

That's what I can think of so far, and if you think I'm going too
bossy already then, forget what I said :p  But I hope I sound
encouraging to what you are doing, and can contribute to another great
start-up business.

Meanwhile I'll forward you some "recent" logos I did (from boring sh!t
to more exciting ones).

Anyway, think things over and we'll talk again soon.

Hugs,
Jenny

from	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>

subject	Re: logo design
date	Fri, 14 Dec 2007 13:10:52 +0900

Thanks again for your mail.

You're right that I need to think a few things through. Here are some basic
points that I want to convey in reponse to your email. I wrote the important
text in bold so you can skim and read it in detail at a later date.

1. *My budget is ridiculously low.*
Right now I'm planning on getting business using a website and adsense (plus
a few other targeted ad campaigns, like at japan-guide if I can afford it).
I don't really have the money to put together printed publicity
*properly*so I'd rather save up and do it at a later date.  Before
that I've got to
figure out who I'll be sending it to, and start making agreements with
travel agents etc. Oh and by the way, for now there are no business
partners, just me alone. I would be happy to pay you up to 20,000 yen for
the logo alone, and we can talk about business cards etc at a later date for
its own set fee.

2. *Expectations*
I'm not sure how you work, but this is kind of what I was expecting. After I
give you all the information you need (I'll get there eventually, I
promise!) then I'm hoping that you would give me two or three basic sketches
to choose from, and we could pick one to work on further. You may have a
better workflow than this in which case we can go with that instead.

3. *References
*I've read through many tourist sites and got a general feel for how they
market them. Although I need a bit of training on marketing and sales,
generally speaking I don't like how they just throw around names of tourist
attractions and expect people to pay exorbitant fees for them.

The main difference between me and my competitors is that while their  main
product is a tour from A to B to C at set times with booking and
reservations, with the actual historical items and attractions left to speak
for themselves.

My main product includes all that, but the main value is in the experience
of the tour and the guide service, making sure it runs without a hitch and
that it is ordered and scripted to give customers the maximum emotional
experience they could possibly have while in Japan (think about how guys
plan dates to get their objects of affection excited and ready).

The only company that comes close to the ideal I'm aiming for is London
Walks. <http://www.walks.com/>


4. *Your questions*:
(difference from competitors)
Basically:
Oxalis: Staying at onsen, hiking in the mountains, exploring the countryside
Inside Japan: Tours exploring the cities and countryside of Japan.
Adventure In Japan: One day tours and day-trips in and around the Tokyo
Area.

*Inside Japan Cheapens Japanese Culture*
From a subjective standpoint I don't like the way that Inside Japan is laid
out. The way it has castles, maiko, cherry blossoms all collaged into one
picture kind of belittles the individual objects, reducing it to a cultural
buffet for tourists to pick and choose from. While that is inevitably true
to some extent, from Adventure In Japan I'd like to give more reverence for
each cultural item.

*I would rather do a few tours really really well, than a lot of them
mediocre*
Also, although I do want to grow the business and do various tours (expand
nationally, do longer tours) I don't think I will ever grow to do 8 or 9
different itenaries. I would much rather do three or four tours *well*, than
do 8 or 9 half-assed. I will of course offer a high degree of
customisability to guests though.

*Currently, I am smaller and more agile than my competitors*
Those two are the big dog competitors. There are a number of other smaller
firms operating out of Tokyo that I don't give much consideration to. Given
my situation, I am outfinanced, outnumbered and outadvertised. So I've got
to play to my strengths.

From a business standpoint, I am:

-More Flexible, I can arrange a tour with a weeks notice.
-More Controlled, I am 100% of my staff :P



(message for target customers)
The core 'soul' of my company revolves around four main points:

i) *Loving Japan*. I know it sounds melodramatic but there's so much to do
and study here that if I had the time I could study history and explore and
travel and die happy. Difficult to convey in words but if you remember the
feeling when you first came to Japan and everything is amazing and new, it's
that but a slow-burning, long-term version of that enthusiasm.

ii)*Depth of Knowledge*. Not only about Japan, it's history and economy but
also about having contacts, places to go and things to see that other
tourist guide services don't. I am currently studying Japanese history (and
as you know, am pretty fluent in Japanese) and studying up on Japanese
culture and info about the main tourist attractions. While I don't want to
give guests a history lecture on the tours, I want them to feel as if their
guide is a generally smart and knowledgeable person who can gives relevant
interesting information, rather than just a robot taking them from point A
to B to C.

iii)*Customer Service*. Another raging gay cliche, but it has to be said. An
example of this is say, if a guest wants to change the tour and go somewhere
else then not only are we ready to do that, we can actually give them
recommendations (rather than what other companies might say 'sorry, can't
change the itenary in the middle of the tour'). This could also extend to
going for drinks with guests after the tour, sending ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to our guests or
any number of good ideas I have to make the best impression possible on
them.

iv)*Fucking Sexy Tours.* Ever been to a foreign country or city and had such
a deliriously good time that you were getting excited and email your friends
and talking about it all night with your travel partners? Didn't think so.
AIJ is there to fill that gap. Over time I want the tours to be crafted to
perfection. The right time of day to go to an attraction, the best nearby
restaurants, exclusive events, the best order of attractions in a tour etc.
I want the guests to be able to sit back and watch me orchestrate a symphony
using the landscape, taking them from place to place as I tell them the
story of this city and country. Essentially, the tour should be an amazing
experience even if it were done in their hometown or city.


Wow, you were right! Writing this all out helped loads! I'm probably going
to use excerpts from this as copy for the website!

(who are my target customers?)

Smart, middle-class American/English Tourists. Probably 25 years old and up,
I'm guessing the majority of my customers would be in their 30's.

Ok, I'm running overtime, so feel free to ask for clarification or to go
over any of those points again.

later

Ali
