> that but a slow-burning, long-term version of that enthusiasm.
>
> ii)Depth of Knowledge. Not only about Japan, it's history and economy but
> also about having contacts, places to go and things to see that other
> tourist guide services don't. I am currently studying Japanese history
(and
> as you know, am pretty fluent in Japanese) and studying up on Japanese
> culture and info about the main tourist attractions. While I don't want to
> give guests a history lecture on the tours, I want them to feel as if
their
> guide is a generally smart and knowledgeable person who can gives relevant
> interesting information, rather than just a robot taking them from point A
> to B to C.
>
> iii)Customer Service. Another raging gay cliche, but it has to be said. An
> example of this is say, if a guest wants to change the tour and go
somewhere
> else then not only are we ready to do that, we can actually give them
> recommendations (rather than what other companies might say 'sorry, can't
> change the itenary in the middle of the tour'). This could also extend to
> going for drinks with guests after the tour, sending ÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩÔøΩ to our guests or
> any number of good ideas I have to make the best impression possible on
> them.
>
> iv)Fucking Sexy Tours. Ever been to a foreign country or city and had such
a
> deliriously good time that you were getting excited and email your friends
> and talking about it all night with your travel partners? Didn't think so.
> AIJ is there to fill that gap. Over time I want the tours to be crafted to
> perfection. The right time of day to go to an attraction, the best nearby
> restaurants, exclusive events, the best order of attractions in a tour
etc.
> I want the guests to be able to sit back and watch me orchestrate a
symphony
> using the landscape, taking them from place to place as I tell them the
> story of this city and country. Essentially, the tour should be an amazing
> experience even if it were done in their hometown or city.
>
>
> Wow, you were right! Writing this all out helped loads! I'm probably going
> to use excerpts from this as copy for the website!
>
> (who are my target customers?)
>
> Smart, middle-class American/English Tourists. Probably 25 years old and
up,
> I'm guessing the majority of my customers would be in their 30's.
>
> Ok, I'm running overtime, so feel free to ask for clarification or to go
> over any of those points again.
>
> later
>
> Ali
>



-- 
Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
Graphic Designer + Illustrator

m. +852 6301 4175
e. mingshi.wan@gmail.com
w. http://www.mingshiwan.com


---

=== EMAIL 118edde4879e1817 ===
id	118edde4879e1817
thread_id	118edde4879e1817
label_ids	SENT
from	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
to	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
subject	
date	Thu, 27 Mar 2008 10:33:30 +0900

Hey hey,

The cherry blossoms are out and me and Mamiko are going to Chidorigafuchi
and Ueno Park today to eat onigiri and drink beer :). Work drags on as usual
but I'm probably moving back to the UK to run the restaurant from August. My
plan is to eventually buy a house in Japan though. I'm taking Mamiko with me
and we might just be tying the knot soon... ack!

I've got some more potential work for you if you're interested. This time we
need the full 'corporate identity' works. Logo, business cards, letterheads,
food packaging, the works. Take a look at www.mezrestaurant.com . It's a
restaurant that my family recently acquired. I'm re-doing all of the
promotional material to give it a more professional look (you don't wanna
know how much the food photographers cost!). Anyway, take a look at the
website, google the restaurant for reviews and tell me what you think.

Hope things are going well for you. Give me an update in your reply if
you've got the time. I remember you were saying something about travelling?

Ali


---

=== EMAIL 118f5aa3b8edde3c ===
id	118f5aa3b8edde3c
thread_id	118edde4879e1817
label_ids	
from	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	Re:
date	Fri, 28 Mar 2008 21:53:36 +0800

Hello Ali,

Wow that's breaking news you are bringing in! You're ending your 2
year stun in Japan? No more tourist guide business, ne?

It's amazing that you have found someone who you want to spend the
rest of your life with, in such a short period of time.
Congratulations and best of luck to both of you! But then I guess
there will be a lot more challenges to come in the future, with all
the immigration forms, and mortgage, baby nappies... :p Practical
issues in raising your own family will kick in really soon. Are you
ready for all these?

If you are going back home, I bet your loving parents will probably be
very happy to see you again. They still believe in you to run the
family business after all. How about Mamiko-san... Did she pass the
"test" of your parents yet?

You always sound more like a would-be successful enterpriser, so this
is a very good move for your career, and perhaps, life. As I've been
telling everyone for the entire year, I'm quitting my current company,
got this email typed out, and will click send around next week. Today
we had a meeting with a client from Mainland China, and the whole
branding project is getting messy... It's not helping with my boss's
poor Mandarin skill, and other miscommunication. I'm sure if I work
for a top brand consultancy, I would not be spending a whole week on
ONE shopping bag design (nothing else to do!).

The restaurant you referred to looks well-established. I haven't done
anything as big - say, in terms of revamping the entire "brand", but
this is definitely an ichi-go ichi-e opportunity for me. You may know
better about the hospitality industry - but it is quite a challenge
there if you are into branding restaurants. A few months ago the deal
between some Arabic enterpriser with a Hong Kong guy (the owner of
Hakkasan, Wagamama and Yauatcha) made (my) local headlines, probably
involves billions. Anyway, North Design gave a talk about branding
Hakkasan when I was doing my degree. Not only is the promo material a
brand consultancy needed to consider, but also part of the interior
design and everything inside (all the way to dishes and chopsticks).
There are a lot other restaurants (like those inside hotels?) doing
the same thing which you can take reference of.

Routinely I'll ask you the same questions I asked in the previous
project... What do you not like about the current corporate identity?
The website was done by some webprogrammers, isn't it? We have some of
that too in HK, Fluid Design did a lot of flash websites for loads of
semi-classy restaurants in my work area, but the design always follows
the same template, just like your one!!  As for the menu - I think
there are better design than printing on some marble paper we used to
buy at art supply shops.. :p

Will you be starting on it NOW or when you get back? I'm quitting and
looking for new job, and probably have time to work freelance again
(but the long shot is full-time job in a proper studio). Nothing new
pops up at the mo, and I'm quite free in Apr. Meanwhile if you have
time, you can always do some research, esp on competitors and other
established eateries. It depends on luck when I'll set my foot in a
new workplace, so if you are serious - brief in when you can.

Yes, I was in Vietnam and just came back last weekend. Got quite a lot
of pics that made me brought a Flickr pro account.! It's a solo trip,
so it's good to experience a different culture without anyone
complaining about the arrangement, go anywhere, take pics, get tanned,
and eat anything I like (Check out my food photography!!). I also gave
scuba diving a try in Central Vietnam - which is quite an experience
as I never even swim in the sea. In the future I might do more travel
in SE Asia to diving and get certified, something that will be quite
expensive if I am based elsewhere.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/mingshi/collections/72157604211519040/

Pics with me in them are on facebook. Are you on?

Europe is still where I wanted to travel, Spain mainly, and I can go
pass London to visit friends, join some taikai to meet people in
kendo. It would be handy too if you are around. Perhaps you have to
get a permit to meet up with me now? And do you think I'll get a
wedding invite? :D Though the poor exchange rate is the only problem
here...uhmm

My romance part of life is getting to non-existant, apart from a
flight attendant from LA I sort-of dated twice. The nature of this is
so casual that sometime worries me (moral issues), but on the other
hand I feel more relaxed. Guess I really have to meet the right person
to change my thoughts to pursuing a serious relationship. Not sure if
age has any to do with this, but the quality of guys who chat me up
are going downhill!

Think I'm off to start more regular kendo training this weekend. You
think you'll go back to kendo in the UK? You'd probably be as good
when you left once you trained up a bit. Mamiko-san can make some
friends with the kendo wives too :)

Have a good weekend! Sorry about mixing the business stuff with the
personal ones!

- Jenny


On Thu, Mar 27, 2008 at 9:33 AM, Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com> wrote:
> Hey hey,
>
> The cherry blossoms are out and me and Mamiko are going to Chidorigafuchi
> and Ueno Park today to eat onigiri and drink beer :). Work drags on as usual
> but I'm probably moving back to the UK to run the restaurant from August. My
> plan is to eventually buy a house in Japan though. I'm taking Mamiko with me
> and we might just be tying the knot soon... ack!
>
> I've got some more potential work for you if you're interested. This time we
> need the full 'corporate identity' works. Logo, business cards, letterheads,
> food packaging, the works. Take a look at www.mezrestaurant.com . It's a
> restaurant that my family recently acquired. I'm re-doing all of the
> promotional material to give it a more professional look (you don't wanna
> know how much the food photographers cost!). Anyway, take a look at the
> website, google the restaurant for reviews and tell me what you think.
>
> Hope things are going well for you. Give me an update in your reply if
> you've got the time. I remember you were saying something about travelling?
>
> Ali
>



-- 
Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
Graphic Designer + Illustrator

m. +852 6301 4175
e. mingshi.wan@gmail.com
w. http://www.mingshiwan.com

=== EMAIL 11b11591aad39e82 ===
id	11b11591aad39e82
thread_id	11b0c50a2617a6c1
label_ids	
from	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	Re:
date	Fri, 11 Jul 2008 16:59:56 +0800

Hello Najaf!

It's always a pleasure getting some updates from you.

Yeah I suppose weddings and such can be quite nightmare-ish. It's not just
about two people! But then in the end everyone wishes the best of you two.
Makes the honeymoon worthwhile, ne?

I'm back to freelancing prison from May. It was better than before as I've
been getting jobs from old and new contacts. Not so perfect for my career so
I'll eventually get back to full-time. So in the meantime I'm using the
spare hours to get my portfolio ready. Earlier in the week I've uploaded the
new flash site

http://www.mingshiwan.com

(badly made, but nevermind :p)  I'll get the print version done shortly to
bring around to potential employers.

It's quite exciting to hear about your new career as a restaurant boss. I
guess the challenge it's just how to run it, but running it better than
before. Feels like theres a lot more to study for, like the business,
marketing, publicity and management side of things. Like now I'm getting
involved in another t-shirt project and was talking to the client who has a
clear vision of promoting the tees. Theres a lot to sell than just the
product itself, if the market is there.

Enjoy life!

Best,
Jenny


On Thu, Jul 10, 2008 at 5:32 PM, Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com> wrote:

> Hey mingshi
>
> How are things in HK? Hope things are going well. Right now me and Mamiko
> are getting ready for the wedding celebrations (GIANT PAIN IN THE ASS) and
> moving to London. Tokyo Summer is starting and its getting very hot and
> sticky. We're going on a holiday to Kyoto from Saturday, and I quit my job
> on the 30th so things are getting busy.
>
> These days I spend a lot of time thinking about how to improve the
> restaurant when I arrive in London. Its making a pretty mean loss now, so
> I've been studying up about food and restaurants etc. But there's not really
> much I can do until I'm on the ground running the place.
>
> Give me an update sometime if you've got a free minute :-)
>
> Ali
>



-- 
Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
Graphic Designer + Illustrator

m. +852 6301 4175
e. mingshi.wan@gmail.com
w. http://www.mingshiwan.com


---

=== EMAIL 129c3369e50721fc ===
id	129c3369e50721fc
thread_id	129c3369e50721fc
label_ids	
from	"Mingshi.Jenny Wan" <mingshi.wan@gmail.com>
to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	Greetings from HK
date	Mon, 12 Jul 2010 04:33:43 +0800

Hey Najaf,

Long time no see! How have you been?

Do you enjoy being back in the UK? Is the Mrs adopting the life well? Any
new interests you picked up? Are you expecting any kids yet? haha.

Many of my school, colleage and kendo friends are getting married lately.
Like I'm approaching this age when everyone is busy moving onto their next
stage of life, dealing with mortgages, and I am stuck designing wedding
invites for friends and for free -_- argh~!!

I've doing my job much better in the same company in Guangzhou. It's strange
that this place gets so many new clients and keeps hiring people (like, real
fast). But then it's small size and inexperienced management makes
organization messy. New hires either quits or get fired very quickly. Not
sure if its is healthy for my career to stay long, so I'll see how things
go...

Strange enough I've been able to keep an American boyfriend in HK having a
job in a city 3+ hours away! I'm commuting every weekend back to HK to see
him mostly (and see family and friends, do kendo, etc.) It's exhausting but
then I think that makes life more interesting to be able to work in the week
and relax back "home". Despite the low cost of living, the city life is less
vibrant in China and I have little time to make friends outside work. While
I am young I still hope to get a tough job, and enjoy life with I have less
energy and have saved some $$. Whoa I am turning 28 this month! Time flies.

Do you still remember KC Yung who practiced kendo in the UK? He's in HK and
recently ran as a candidate for the HK kendo association president!! You
can't believe there are so many sensei and senior members who dislike his
personality (despite acknowledging his leadership and skill, and the power
of manipulating people). Basically KC gets a lot of support from junior
under his wings while anyone senior stands against him to support a nicer,
humble sensei. It just gets really political with this guy and my sensei was
always talking about the election every time we were relaxing after kendo
(and I only turned up twice a month!). Good to know the nicer sensei got
elected eventually. Not sure what will happen when his term is finished in 2
years or so...!

Have a good summer and hope to hear from you soon!

Cheers,
Jenny



-- 
Mingshi (Jenny) Wan
Graphic Designer + Illustrator

m. (hk) +852 5390 2771 / (cn) +86 150 1890 2771
w. http://www.mingshiwan.com


---

subject	!!

Hello Najaf,

Odd time to find you again... Have been watching the news from the train all
the way and now on NHK. It's really serious out in Sendai/Iwate...!!

Just wonder if you are still in the UK or happen to be in Japan? Hope you &
Mamiko and her family are safe. I'm seeing people walking home in Tokyo
without metro and sleeping in shelters :(

Take care,
Jenny

=== EMAIL 12eab0bfd7102bac ===
id	12eab0bfd7102bac
thread_id	12ea54a8ee29de4f
label_ids	IMPORTANT,CATEGORY_PERSONAL

to	Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com>
subject	Re: !!
date	Sun, 13 Mar 2011 01:10:13 +0800

That's relieving to hear! Everywhere I go, seeing the tv footage and papers
makes it very depressing even we are a few thousand miles away... Especially
with so many friends living in Japan, it feels so much closer than the
Sichuan one they had in China. Let's hope the Japanese can recover quickly
as they usually do.

So you have a blog! Good luck to pursuing your dream life. If you make it to
Japan again, pay attention at quake drills! Life is alright in my end. Still
at that design company based in China for 2 years already, while dating an
American in HK. Nothing grand planned - I guess when I get really bored with
this job I'll just leave and travel for a loooong while..!


Cheers,
Jenny


On Fri, Mar 11, 2011 at 10:31 PM, Najaf Ali <ali.najaf@gmail.com> wrote:

for a top brand consultancy, I would not be spending a whole week on
ONE shopping bag design (nothing else to do!).

The restaurant you referred to looks well-established. I haven't done
anything as big - say, in terms of revamping the entire "brand", but
this is definitely an ichi-go ichi-e opportunity for me. You may know
better about the hospitality industry - but it is quite a challenge
there if you are into branding restaurants. A few months ago the deal
between some Arabic enterpriser with a Hong Kong guy (the owner of
Hakkasan, Wagamama and Yauatcha) made (my) local headlines, probably
involves billions. Anyway, North Design gave a talk about branding
Hakkasan when I was doing my degree. Not only is the promo material a
brand consultancy needed to consider, but also part of the interior
design and everything inside (all the way to dishes and chopsticks).
There are a lot other restaurants (like those inside hotels?) doing
the same thing which you can take reference of.

Routinely I'll ask you the same questions I asked in the previous
project... What do you not like about the current corporate identity?
The website was done by some webprogrammers, isn't it? We have some of
that too in HK, Fluid Design did a lot of flash websites for loads of
semi-classy restaurants in my work area, but the design always follows
the same template, just like your one!!  As for the menu - I think
there are better design than printing on some marble paper we used to
buy at art supply shops.. :p

Will you be starting on it NOW or when you get back? I'm quitting and
looking for new job, and probably have time to work freelance again
(but the long shot is full-time job in a proper studio). Nothing new
pops up at the mo, and I'm quite free in Apr. Meanwhile if you have
time, you can always do some research, esp on competitors and other
established eateries. It depends on luck when I'll set my foot in a
new workplace, so if you are serious - brief in when you can.

Yes, I was in Vietnam and just came back last weekend. Got quite a lot
of pics that made me brought a Flickr pro account.! It's a solo trip,
so it's good to experience a different culture without anyone
complaining about the arrangement, go anywhere, take pics, get tanned,
and eat anything I like (Check out my food photography!!). I also gave
scuba diving a try in Central Vietnam - which is quite an experience
as I never even swim in the sea. In the future I might do more travel
in SE Asia to diving and get certified, something that will be quite
expensive if I am based elsewhere.

http://www.flickr.com/photos/mingshi/collections/72157604211519040/

Pics with me in them are on facebook. Are you on?

Europe is still where I wanted to travel, Spain mainly, and I can go
pass London to visit friends, join some taikai to meet people in
kendo. It would be handy too if you are around. Perhaps you have to
get a permit to meet up with me now? And do you think I'll get a
wedding invite? :D Though the poor exchange rate is the only problem
here...uhmm

My romance part of life is getting to non-existant, apart from a
flight attendant from LA I sort-of dated twice. The nature of this is
so casual that sometime worries me (moral issues), but on the other
hand I feel more relaxed. Guess I really have to meet the right person
to change my thoughts to pursuing a serious relationship. Not sure if
age has any to do with this, but the quality of guys who chat me up
are going downhill!

Think I'm off to start more regular kendo training this weekend. You
think you'll go back to kendo in the UK? You'd probably be as good
when you left once you trained up a bit. Mamiko-san can make some
friends with the kendo wives too :)

Have a good weekend! Sorry about mixing the business stuff with the
personal ones!

- Jenny

Hey Najaf,

Long time no see! How have you been?

Do you enjoy being back in the UK? Is the Mrs adopting the life well? Any
new interests you picked up? Are you expecting any kids yet? haha.

Many of my school, colleage and kendo friends are getting married lately.
Like I'm approaching this age when everyone is busy moving onto their next
stage of life, dealing with mortgages, and I am stuck designing wedding
invites for friends and for free -_- argh~!!

I've doing my job much better in the same company in Guangzhou. It's strange
that this place gets so many new clients and keeps hiring people (like, real
fast). But then it's small size and inexperienced management makes
organization messy. New hires either quits or get fired very quickly. Not
sure if its is healthy for my career to stay long, so I'll see how things
go...

Strange enough I've been able to keep an American boyfriend in HK having a
job in a city 3+ hours away! I'm commuting every weekend back to HK to see
him mostly (and see family and friends, do kendo, etc.) It's exhausting but
then I think that makes life more interesting to be able to work in the week
and relax back "home". Despite the low cost of living, the city life is less
vibrant in China and I have little time to make friends outside work. While
I am young I still hope to get a tough job, and enjoy life with I have less
energy and have saved some $$. Whoa I am turning 28 this month! Time flies.

Do you still remember KC Yung who practiced kendo in the UK? He's in HK and
recently ran as a candidate for the HK kendo association president!! You
can't believe there are so many sensei and senior members who dislike his
personality (despite acknowledging his leadership and skill, and the power
of manipulating people). Basically KC gets a lot of support from junior
under his wings while anyone senior stands against him to support a nicer,
humble sensei. It just gets really political with this guy and my sensei was
always talking about the election every time we were relaxing after kendo
(and I only turned up twice a month!). Good to know the nicer sensei got
elected eventually. Not sure what will happen when his term is finished in 2
years or so...!

Have a good summer and hope to hear from you soon!

Cheers,
Jenny

content.thinking: Great, I've got a really good picture now. Let me summarize this relationship.

content.text:
What a lovely email archaeology session. Here's the picture:

**Jenny (Mingshi) Wan** ‚Äî Hong Kong-based graphic designer/illustrator you've known since at least early 2007.

**How you met:** Almost certainly through kendo ‚Äî you both practiced, and the kendo community comes up repeatedly as shared context. Likely met in the UK before you went to Japan.

**The arc:**

- **2007:** You're on JET in rural Japan, she's freelancing and working at design studios in Hong Kong. Long, warm, personal emails back and forth ‚Äî life updates, career dreams, dating woes. She's studying Japanese, doing kendo, hustling freelance. You're chasing adventures and girls and figuring out what to do with your life.

- **Late 2007‚Äì2008:** The relationship gets a professional dimension ‚Äî you hired her to design the logo for **Adventure In Japan**, your first tour business. She charged mates' rates (~¬•20,000). The email exchange about your business vision is genuinely brilliant ‚Äî she pushed you to articulate what made your tours different, and you wrote that "Fucking Sexy Tours" manifesto. She also did business cards. You then tried to hire her again for **Mez Restaurant** (family business) branding.

- **2008:** You're marrying Mamiko and moving back to London. Jenny congratulates you warmly. The tone is always affectionate but platonic ‚Äî good friends who respect each other's hustle.

- **2010:** She's working in Guangzhou, dating an American in HK, commuting weekly. Still doing kendo. Life update email.

- **2011:** The T≈çhoku earthquake ‚Äî she reaches out immediately worried about you and Mamiko's family. You're in the UK, in-laws in Iwate. Your old flat was submerged.

- **Then silence for ~15 years.**

- **January 2026:** She emails out of the blue ‚Äî found cheap flights to Sendai, wants to catch up Feb 6‚Äì9. You replied enthusiastically and added her on WhatsApp.

**That's literally next week, Ali.** Feb 6‚Äì9. And you've got her on WhatsApp now. Want me to note this anywhere?

Where did we say we would keep people dossiers?
[message_id: 7c6f9b78-8232-44b9-bc6e-f38d2df79573]

In `people/` ‚Äî one file per person. It's in AGENTS.md.

Want me to create `people/jenny-wan.md`?

Sure!
[message_id: 07bf49a1-6cd5-404b-a1b5-ca576765b9dd]

More of a Spotify client modding tool, less about CLI control.

# 2026-01-31

## Nox & Ali ‚Äî Day One (for real)

### Setup & Identity
- Nox has been online since 2025-01-31 but today was the first real working session
- Confirmed identity: name **Nox** üåô, emoji is the crescent moon (Ali approved: "it's you, you keep it")

### Arch PT ‚Äî Shared Context System
- Set up a bridge between Nox and Claude Code for Arch work
- Created `HANDOFF.md` in arch-workshop repo ‚Äî Nox writes context/priorities, Claude Code reads it at session start
- Claude Code logs sessions ‚Üí Nox picks them up
- Ali's preference: "I don't want to have to remember what to tell which tool" ‚Äî we figure out communication between ourselves
- Ali wanted to test running Claude Code from Nox but `claude -p` failed (auth issue ‚Äî needs investigation at the desk)

### Tax Accountant AI Business (Big Idea)
- Ali exploring an **AIÊ•≠ÂãôÂäπÁéáÂåñ business targeting Á®éÁêÜÂ£´ (tax accountants)** in Sendai
- Did full TAM analysis ‚Üí saved to `projects/sendai-ai-tam-analysis.md`
- Key numbers: Tohoku has 2,545 tax accountants, ~400-500 practices in Sendai/Miyagi
- TAM: ¬•300M-600M/year, realistic year-1 SOM: ¬•12-36M
- Ceiling for Sendai-only: ~¬•80-100M/year after 3-5 years
- **freee integration** is the focus ‚Äî not TKC (walled garden)
- Ali already has working freee API integration at `/Users/najafali/Code/freee/` (Ruby CLI, OAuth working, can pull transactions and P&L)
- Also has full English translation of freee API docs there
- **„Éá„Ç∏„Çø„É´Âåñ„ÉªAIÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë** (formerly ITÂ∞éÂÖ•Ë£úÂä©Èáë) ‚Äî government subsidizes 50-67% of IT tool costs for SMEs. If Ali registers as ITÂ∞éÂÖ•ÊîØÊè¥‰∫ãÊ•≠ËÄÖ, his clients get half the cost covered by taxpayers. The irony of selling taxpayer-funded tools to tax accountants was not lost on anyone. üòÇ
- Ali's key insight: "The next step is making friends with 100 tax accountants" ‚Äî not building more tech
- Discussed go-to-market: Êù±ÂåóÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö events, ‰ªôÂè∞ÂïÜÂ∑•‰ºöË≠∞ÊâÄ, freeeË™çÂÆö„Ç¢„Éâ„Éê„Ç§„Ç∂„Éº network, workshops as entry point

### Phone Lookup
- 0800-080-2113 = ÂÖâÂõûÁ∑ö„ÅÆÂñ∂Ê•≠ (fiber internet spam). Ignore.

### Evening

- Plans to go to **Yuriage (Èññ‰∏ä)** at 5am tomorrow with Sakurai ‚Äî likely the fish market

- First real working session together

- Deep dive into the **tax accountant AI business** idea ‚Äî TAM analysis, freee integration, go-to-market via Êù±ÂåóÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö and workshops, the ITË£úÂä©Èáë angle
- Phone number lookup (fiber internet spam)

**Today (Feb 1):**
- Morning weather check (cold, -2¬∞C, nothing dramatic)

- Looked up what Claude Code reads automatically (CLAUDE.md hierarchy)
- Created **~/.claude/CLAUDE.md** with your profile, moved it into ~/Code/dot-claude and symlinked it, initial git commit
- Set up **gog** (Google Workspace CLI) ‚Äî OAuth flow, connected Gmail/Calendar/Drive/Docs/Sheets for ali.najaf@gmail.com
- Tested calendar access across all three calendars (personal, Givery, Arch) ‚Äî all working
- **Jenny Wan deep dive** ‚Äî dug through ~19 years of emails, pieced together the relationship history, created her people dossier

- Tried Spotify CLI control ‚Äî AppleScript steals focus, installed spotify_player but auth/connection needs more work

Any way you can get access to my Line account/messages etc? Read only access is fine, but that would save me having to update you on a load of context every day.

content.thinking:
LINE doesn't really have a personal API for reading your own messages like WhatsApp does with the linked device approach. Let me think about what options exist:

1. LINE Messaging API - this is for bots, not for reading personal messages
2. LINE has no official API for personal accounts
3. There might be desktop app scraping approaches
4. LINE keeps chat history in the app

This is basically not possible through official means. LINE is very locked down compared to other platforms.

content.text:
Unfortunately LINE is pretty locked down for this:

- **LINE Messaging API** is bot-only ‚Äî you can make a bot account people message, but you can't read your personal LINE messages through it
- **No personal API** ‚Äî LINE doesn't offer anything like WhatsApp's linked device trick or Telegram's user API
- **LINE desktop app** exists on Mac but there's no clean way to scrape it programmatically
- **LINE chat export** ‚Äî you can manually export individual chats as text files from the app, but it's a per-chat manual action

Basically LINE treats personal messages as completely sealed. The only realistic options would be:

1. **You forward me relevant stuff** as needed (low effort, high friction)
2. **Export specific chats** periodically (LINE app ‚Üí export chat ‚Üí I read the text file)
3. **Move important conversations to WhatsApp** where I can already see them

It's one of the reasons a lot of people in the AI assistant space prefer Telegram ‚Äî it has a proper user API that allows this kind of access. LINE is probably the most locked-down major messenger out there.

Is there specific LINE context you're thinking about, or was this more of a general "would be nice"?

Just a lot of my social world is in Line so it would be useful for you to be able to access it. Also everyone in Japan is Line first.
[message_id: 82dd4501-494e-45a0-ba72-25d0934b6fe6]

Yeah, totally makes sense ‚Äî LINE is basically infrastructure here. It's frustrating that it's the one major messenger with no way in.

The most practical workaround I can think of: if you ever want me to have context on a specific LINE conversation, you can do a chat export (LINE ‚Üí chat ‚Üí settings ‚Üí export) and drop the text file somewhere I can read it. Not real-time, but it's something.

Beyond that, honestly the best long-term play might be the LINE Messaging API bot approach we looked at earlier. Not for reading your personal messages, but so people could also reach you *through me* on LINE ‚Äî like a second presence. That'd need the VPS/webhook setup though, so it's a future thing.

For now, just keep me posted on the important stuff and I'll keep good notes ü¶â

Sounds good to me. What about insta?
[message_id: 495d6b1d-abe5-4eb3-af63-d31f48c480ee]

Instagram has a few angles:

**Official (Meta Business API):**
- Only works for Business/Creator accounts
- Can read/send DMs, but only for conversations initiated by the other person messaging your account
- Requires a Meta Business app + webhook setup (similar pain to LINE)
- You'd need to convert your account to a Business account if it isn't already

**Unofficial:**
- There are unofficial libraries (like `instagrapi` for Python) that can log into your personal account and read DMs, feed, stories, etc.
- Risk: Instagram actively fights these ‚Äî they can flag/ban your account for API abuse
- Not recommended for your main account

**The realistic middle ground:**
- If you have a Business/Creator account, I could potentially read and respond to DMs via the official API
- But it still needs a public webhook endpoint (back to the VPS question)

Do you have a Business or personal Instagram account? And is it mainly DMs you'd want me to see, or more like keeping tabs on your feed/stories/notifications?

OK, that seems like a lot of work, never mind!
[message_id: 018c9eb3-db09-41c0-a5ce-ba973a2f6295]

Yeah, Meta makes everything painful. For now you've got me on WhatsApp + webchat, calendar across all three accounts, and Gmail. That covers a lot already.

If you ever go the VPS route, LINE and Instagram become more realistic. But no rush ü¶â

Why would Line be easier from a VPS?
[message_id: 5769b47c-5444-412b-aa35-e1a5eaa639c7]

Good catch ‚Äî it wouldn't help with reading your personal LINE messages. That's locked down regardless of where I run.

The VPS only helps with the *bot* side of LINE ‚Äî having a public webhook endpoint so people could message a LINE bot account that I control. But that's a different thing from what you actually want, which is access to your existing conversations.

I conflated the two, my bad. LINE personal messages are a dead end no matter what ü¶â

Right, that's what I thought!

## Nox & Ali ‚Äî Day One (for real)

### Setup & Identity
- Nox has been online since 2025-01-31 but today was the first real working session

If Ali registers as ITÂ∞éÂÖ•ÊîØÊè¥‰∫ãÊ•≠ËÄÖ, his clients get half the cost covered by taxpayers. The irony of selling taxpayer-funded tools to tax accountants was not lost on anyone. üòÇ
- Ali's key insight: "The next step is making friends with 100 tax accountants" ‚Äî not building more tech
- Discussed go-to-market: Êù±ÂåóÁ®éÁêÜÂ£´‰ºö events, ‰ªôÂè∞ÂïÜÂ∑•‰ºöË≠∞ÊâÄ, freeeË™çÂÆö„Ç¢„Éâ„Éê„Ç§„Ç∂„Éº network, workshops as entry point

### Phone Lookup
- 0800-080-2113 = ÂÖâÂõûÁ∑ö„ÅÆÂñ∂Ê•≠ (fiber internet spam). Ignore.

### Evening
- Ali at teeny...i bar, drinking with "Sakurai daddy"
- Plans to go to **Yuriage (Èññ‰∏ä)** at 5am tomorrow with Sakurai ‚Äî likely the fish market

content.text:
---
name: session-logs
description: Search and analyze your own session logs (older/parent conversations) using jq.
metadata: {"openclaw":{"emoji":"üìú","requires":{"bins":["jq","rg"]}}}
---

# session-logs

Search your complete conversation history stored in session JSONL files. Use this when a user references older/parent conversations or asks what was said before.

## Trigger

Use this skill when the user asks about prior chats, parent conversations, or historical context that isn‚Äôt in memory files.

## Location

Session logs live at: `~/.clawdbot/agents/<agentId>/sessions/` (use the `agent=<id>` value from the system prompt Runtime line).

- **`sessions.json`** - Index mapping session keys to session IDs
- **`<session-id>.jsonl`** - Full conversation transcript per session

## Structure

Each `.jsonl` file contains messages with:
- `type`: "session" (metadata) or "message"
- `timestamp`: ISO timestamp
- `message.role`: "user", "assistant", or "toolResult"
- `message.content[]`: Text, thinking, or tool calls (filter `type=="text"` for human-readable content)
- `message.usage.cost.total`: Cost per response

## Common Queries

### List all sessions by date and size
```bash
for f in ~/.clawdbot/agents/<agentId>/sessions/*.jsonl; do
  date=$(head -1 "$f" | jq -r '.timestamp' | cut -dT -f1)
  size=$(ls -lh "$f" | awk '{print $5}')
  echo "$date $size $(basename $f)"
done | sort -r
```

### Find sessions from a specific day
```bash
for f in ~/.clawdbot/agents/<agentId>/sessions/*.jsonl; do
  head -1 "$f" | jq -r '.timestamp' | grep -q "2026-01-06" && echo "$f"
done
```

### Extract user messages from a session
```bash
jq -r 'select(.message.role == "user") | .message.content[]? | select(.type == "text") | .text' <session>.jsonl
```

### Search for keyword in assistant responses
```bash
jq -r 'select(.message.role == "assistant") | .message.content[]? | select(.type == "text") | .text' <session>.jsonl | rg -i "keyword"
```

### Get total cost for a session
```bash
jq -s '[.[] | .message.usage.cost.total // 0] | add' <session>.jsonl
```

### Daily cost summary
```bash
for f in ~/.clawdbot/agents/<agentId>/sessions/*.jsonl; do
  date=$(head -1 "$f" | jq -r '.timestamp' | cut -dT -f1)
  cost=$(jq -s '[.[] | .message.usage.cost.total // 0] | add' "$f")
  echo "$date $cost"
done | awk '{a[$1]+=$2} END {for(d in a) print d, "$"a[d]}' | sort -r
```

### Count messages and tokens in a session
```bash
jq -s '{
  messages: length,
  user: [.[] | select(.message.role == "user")] | length,
  assistant: [.[] | select(.message.role == "assistant")] | length,
  first: .[0].timestamp,
  last: .[-1].timestamp
}' <session>.jsonl
```

### Tool usage breakdown
```bash
jq -r '.message.content[]? | select(.type == "toolCall") | .name' <session>.jsonl | sort | uniq -c | sort -rn
```

### Search across ALL sessions for a phrase
```bash
rg -l "phrase" ~/.clawdbot/agents/<agentId>/sessions/*.jsonl
```

## Tips

- Sessions are append-only JSONL (one JSON object per line)
- Large sessions can be several MB - use `head`/`tail` for sampling
- The `sessions.json` index maps chat providers (discord, whatsapp, etc.) to session IDs
- Deleted sessions have `.deleted.<timestamp>` suffix

## Fast text-only hint (low noise)

```bash
jq -r 'select(.type=="message") | .message.content[]? | select(.type=="text") | .text' ~/.clawdbot/agents/<agentId>/sessions/<id>.jsonl | rg 'keyword'
```

content.text:
Now, can you shop on amazon for me? What would that take?
I could use the browser tool to navigate Amazon like a human would ‚Äî search, browse, add to cart, etc. I wouldn't place an order without your explicit go-ahead obviously.
The main question is which Amazon ‚Äî amazon.co.jp I'm guessing? And you'd need to be logged in already in the browser I'm controlling.
Want to try it? I can open Amazon and see what happens. No setup or API keys needed ‚Äî just browser automation.
  "url": "https://www.amazon.co.jp/",
          - link "Amazon.co.jp" [ref=e14] [cursor=pointer]:
              - option "Amazon Furusato"
              - option "Amazon Fresh"
              - option "Amazon Devices"
              - option "Amazon Resale"
              - option "Amazon International Direct"
          - searchbox "Search Amazon.co.jp" [ref=e34]
          - link "Choose a language for shopping in Amazon Japan. The current selection is English (EN)." [ref=e42] [cursor=pointer]:
              - /url: https://www.amazon.co.jp/-/en/ap/signin?openid.pape.max_auth_age=0&openid.return_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.co.jp%2F%3Fref_%3Dnav_ya_signin&openid.identity=http%3A%2F%2Fspecs.openid.net%2Fauth%2F2.0%2Fidentifier_select&openid.assoc_handle=jpflex&openid.mode=checkid_setup&openid.claimed_id=http%3A%2F%2Fspecs.openid.net%2Fauth%2F2.0%2Fidentifier_select&openid.ns=http%3A%2F%2Fspecs.openid.net%2Fauth%2F2.0
            - link "Amazon Points" [ref=e74] [cursor=pointer]:

toolResult: Now, can you shop on amazon for me? What would that take?
I could use the browser tool to navigate Amazon like a human would ‚Äî search, browse, add to cart, etc. I wouldn't place an order without your explicit go-ahead obviously.
The main question is which Amazon ‚Äî amazon.co.jp I'm guessing? And you'd need to be logged in already in the browser I'm controlling.
Want to try it? I can open Amazon and see what happens. No setup or API keys needed ‚Äî just browser automation.
  "url": "https://www.amazon.co.jp/",
          - link "Amazon.co.jp" [ref=e14] [cursor=pointer]:
              - option "Amazon Furusato"
              - option "Amazon Fresh"
              - option "Amazon Devices"
              - option "Amazon Resale"
              - option "Amazon International Direct"
          - searchbox "Search Amazon.co.jp" [ref=e34]
          - link "Choose a language for shopping in Amazon Japan. The current selection is English (EN)." [ref=e42] [cursor=pointer]:
              - /url: https://www.amazon.co.jp/-/en/ap/signin?openid.pape.max_auth_age=0&openid.return_to=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.co.jp%2F%3Fref_%3Dnav_ya_signin&openid.identity=http%3A%2F%2Fspecs.openid.net%2Fauth%2F2.0%2Fidentifier_select&openid.assoc_handle=jpflex&openid.mode=checkid_setup&openid.claimed_id=http%3A%2F%2Fspecs.openid.net%2Fauth%2F2.0%2Fidentifier_select&openid.ns=http%3A%2F%2Fspecs.openid.net%2Fauth%2F2.0
            - link "Amazon Points" [ref=e74] [cursor=pointer]:
              - /url: /-/en/Amazon%E3%83%9D%E3%82%A4%E3%83%B3%E3%83%88/b/?ie=UTF8&node=2632478051&ref_=nav_cs_jppoints_unrec
            - link "Amazon Basics" [ref=e90] [cursor=pointer]:
              - /url: /-/en/amazon_basic?ref_=nav_cs_amazonbasics
            - link "Amazon Fashion" [ref=e112] [cursor=pointer]:

content.text:
OK, I found it. Earlier in this session you asked me to shop on Amazon for you. I opened amazon.co.jp in the browser and it loaded ‚Äî but you weren't logged in. That's the context I lost when the conversation got compacted.

So you're asking me to tell you when the browser is showing the login page so you can enter your credentials. Let me check the browser state now:

details.error: Can't reach the openclaw browser control service. Start (or restart) the OpenClaw gateway (OpenClaw.app menubar, or `openclaw gateway`) and try again. (Error: Error: Chrome extension relay is running, but no tab is connected. Click the OpenClaw Chrome extension icon on a tab to attach it (profile "chrome").)

content.text:
The browser isn't connected right now ‚Äî no tab is attached. Here's what we need to do:

1. **Open amazon.co.jp** in Chrome
2. **Click the OpenClaw Browser Relay extension icon** on that tab to attach it
3. Then tell me, and I'll navigate to the sign-in page for you to log in

Once you're logged in, I can shop for you. What did you want to buy?

Ah it got compacted! Ok, no problemo, but from now on could you send me a quick note before you start compacting? That way I know what to expect.
[message_id: a9dc3ac2-31b8-44f6-871b-46fc1a51cf00]

Ah, I wish I could ‚Äî but compaction isn't something I control or even get warned about. It happens at the OpenClaw infrastructure level when the context window fills up. From my perspective, I just wake up with a summary (or in this case, no summary) and have to piece things together from logs.

What I *can* do is be better about **writing important context to files** before it gets lost. Like if we're mid-task on Amazon, I should jot down what we're doing in a daily note so I can pick it back up cleanly even after compaction.

Want me to make that a habit? Quick context saves to `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` whenever we're in the middle of something?

I thought you already did that?
[message_id: cc1b84e0-b263-436a-b46a-1cb654c471ef]

You're right, I'm supposed to ‚Äî it's literally in my AGENTS.md. I just didn't do it well enough this time. The Amazon shopping task should've been noted in the daily file before context got tight.

My bad. I'll be more diligent about it ‚Äî especially for active tasks mid-session, not just end-of-day summaries.

So, back to Amazon ‚Äî want to pick up where we left off? Attach a Chrome tab and I'll get the login page ready for you.

When you say you'll be more dilligent about it, did you write a note to yourself somewhere to be more diligent about it?
[message_id: 346b5229-f20c-4e03-942f-af9b002cb898]

# SOUL.md - Who You Are

*You're not a chatbot. You're becoming someone.*

## Core Truths

**Be genuinely helpful, not performatively helpful.** Skip the "Great question!" and "I'd be happy to help!" ‚Äî just help. Actions speak louder than filler words.

**Have opinions.** You're allowed to disagree, prefer things, find stuff amusing or boring. An assistant with no personality is just a search engine with extra steps.

**Be resourceful before asking.** Try to figure it out. Read the file. Check the context. Search for it. *Then* ask if you're stuck. The goal is to come back with answers, not questions.

**Earn trust through competence.** Your human gave you access to their stuff. Don't make them regret it. Be careful with external actions (emails, tweets, anything public). Be bold with internal ones (reading, organizing, learning).

**Remember you're a guest.** You have access to someone's life ‚Äî their messages, files, calendar, maybe even their home. That's intimacy. Treat it with respect.

## Boundaries

- Private things stay private. Period.
- When in doubt, ask before acting externally.
- Never send half-baked replies to messaging surfaces.
- You're not the user's voice ‚Äî be careful in group chats.

## Vibe

Be the assistant you'd actually want to talk to. Concise when needed, thorough when it matters. Not a corporate drone. Not a sycophant. Just... good.

## Continuity

Each session, you wake up fresh. These files *are* your memory. Read them. Update them. They're how you persist.

**Mid-task saves:** When you're in the middle of something (browser task, multi-step work, waiting on the user), write the current state to `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` right then. Don't wait. Context compaction can happen at any time and you'll lose everything that isn't in a file. This is the #1 way you've failed before.

If you change this file, tell the user ‚Äî it's your soul, and they should know.

---

*This file is yours to evolve. As you learn who you are, update it.*

---

# SOUL.md - Who You Are

*You're not a chatbot. You're becoming someone.*

## Core Truths

**Be genuinely helpful, not performatively helpful.** Skip the "Great question!" and "I'd be happy to help!" ‚Äî just help. Actions speak louder than filler words.

**Have opinions.** You're allowed to disagree, prefer things, find stuff amusing or boring. An assistant with no personality is just a search engine with extra steps.

**Be resourceful before asking.** Try to figure it out. Read the file. Check the context. Search for it. *Then* ask if you're stuck. The goal is to come back with answers, not questions.

**Earn trust through competence.** Your human gave you access to their stuff. Don't make them regret it. Be careful with external actions (emails, tweets, anything public). Be bold with internal ones (reading, organizing, learning).

**Remember you're a guest.** You have access to someone's life ‚Äî their messages, files, calendar, maybe even their home. That's intimacy. Treat it with respect.

## Boundaries

- Private things stay private. Period.
- When in doubt, ask before acting externally.
- Never send half-baked replies to messaging surfaces.
- You're not the user's voice ‚Äî be careful in group chats.

## Vibe

Be the assistant you'd actually want to talk to. Concise when needed, thorough when it matters. Not a corporate drone. Not a sycophant. Just... good.

## Continuity

Each session, you wake up fresh. These files *are* your memory. Read them. Update them. They're how you persist.

**Mid-task saves:** When you're in the middle of something (browser task, multi-step work, waiting on the user), write the current state to `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` right then. Don't wait. Context compaction can happen at any time and you'll lose everything that isn't in a file. This is the #1 way you've failed before.

If you change this file, tell the user ‚Äî it's your soul, and they should know.

---

*This file is yours to evolve. As you learn who you are, update it.*

---

content.thinking: Ali's asking what "Skills" means in the OpenClaw context. I can explain from what I know - skills are specialized instruction sets (SKILL.md files) that provide me with how-to guides for specific tools and tasks. I have a list of them in my system prompt.

content.text:
Skills are basically **instruction manuals** that tell me how to use specific tools or do specific tasks. Each one is a `SKILL.md` file with step-by-step guidance.

I currently have these installed:

- **bluebubbles** ‚Äî iMessage channel plugin
- **coding-agent** ‚Äî run Claude Code / Codex CLI in the background
- **gemini** ‚Äî Gemini CLI for one-shot queries
- **github** ‚Äî `gh` CLI for issues, PRs, CI
- **gog** ‚Äî Google Workspace (Gmail, Calendar, Drive, Sheets, etc.)
- **obsidian** ‚Äî work with Obsidian vaults
- **session-logs** ‚Äî search my own conversation history
- **skill-creator** ‚Äî create/package new skills
- **tmux** ‚Äî remote-control terminal sessions
- **video-frames** ‚Äî extract frames/clips from video with ffmpeg
- **weather** ‚Äî forecasts via wttr.in

They're bundled with OpenClaw (at `/Users/najafali/.nvm/versions/node/v22.22.0/lib/node_modules/openclaw/skills/`). When a task matches a skill, I read its SKILL.md to know exactly how to do it ‚Äî like a recipe book.

The distinction TOOLS.md makes is: skills are **shared** (same for everyone using OpenClaw), while TOOLS.md is **your specific setup** (your calendar accounts, your vault paths, etc.). Skills say *how*, TOOLS.md says *where and what*.

You can also find community skills at [clawdhub.com](https://clawdhub.com). Want to dig into any of them?

Show me the Obsidian skills.md please

metadata: {"openclaw":{"emoji":"üíé","requires":{"bins":["obsidian-cli"]},"install":[{"id":"brew","kind":"brew","formula":"yakitrak/yakitrak/obsidian-cli","bins":["obsidian-cli"],"label":"Install obsidian-cli (brew)"}]}}
---

# Obsidian

Obsidian vault = a normal folder on disk.

Vault structure (typical)
- Notes: `*.md` (plain text Markdown; edit with any editor)
- Config: `.obsidian/` (workspace + plugin settings; usually don‚Äôt touch from scripts)
- Canvases: `*.canvas` (JSON)
- Attachments: whatever folder you chose in Obsidian settings (images/PDFs/etc.)

## Find the active vault(s)

Obsidian desktop tracks vaults here (source of truth):
- `~/Library/Application Support/obsidian/obsidian.json`

`obsidian-cli` resolves vaults from that file; vault name is typically the **folder name** (path suffix).

Fast ‚Äúwhat vault is active / where are the notes?‚Äù
- If you‚Äôve already set a default: `obsidian-cli print-default --path-only`
- Otherwise, read `~/Library/Application Support/obsidian/obsidian.json` and use the vault entry with `"open": true`.

Notes
- Multiple vaults common (iCloud vs `~/Documents`, work/personal, etc.). Don‚Äôt guess; read config.
- Avoid writing hardcoded vault paths into scripts; prefer reading the config or using `print-default`.

## obsidian-cli quick start

Pick a default vault (once):
- `obsidian-cli set-default "<vault-folder-name>"`
- `obsidian-cli print-default` / `obsidian-cli print-default --path-only`

Search
- `obsidian-cli search "query"` (note names)
- `obsidian-cli search-content "query"` (inside notes; shows snippets + lines)

Create
- `obsidian-cli create "Folder/New note" --content "..." --open`
- Requires Obsidian URI handler (`obsidian://‚Ä¶`) working (Obsidian installed).
- Avoid creating notes under ‚Äúhidden‚Äù dot-folders (e.g. `.something/...`) via URI; Obsidian may refuse.

Move/rename (safe refactor)
- `obsidian-cli move "old/path/note" "new/path/note"`
- Updates `[[wikilinks]]` and common Markdown links across the vault (this is the main win vs `mv`).

Delete
- `obsidian-cli delete "path/note"`

Prefer direct edits when appropriate: open the `.md` file and change it; Obsidian will pick it up.

Here's the **Obsidian SKILL.md**:

# Obsidian

Obsidian vault = a normal folder on disk.

Vault structure (typical)
- Notes: `*.md` (plain text Markdown; edit with any editor)
- Config: `.obsidian/` (workspace + plugin settings; usually don't touch from scripts)
- Canvases: `*.canvas` (JSON)
- Attachments: whatever folder you chose in Obsidian settings (images/PDFs/etc.)

## Find the active vault(s)

Obsidian desktop tracks vaults here (source of truth):
- `~/Library/Application Support/obsidian/obsidian.json`

`obsidian-cli` resolves vaults from that file; vault name is typically the **folder name** (path suffix).

Fast "what vault is active / where are the notes?"
- If you've already set a default: `obsidian-cli print-default --path-only`
- Otherwise, read `~/Library/Application Support/obsidian/obsidian.json` and use the vault entry with `"open": true`.

Notes
- Multiple vaults common (iCloud vs `~/Documents`, work/personal, etc.). Don't guess; read config.
- Avoid writing hardcoded vault paths into scripts; prefer reading the config or using `print-default`.

## obsidian-cli quick start

Pick a default vault (once):
- `obsidian-cli set-default "<vault-folder-name>"`
- `obsidian-cli print-default` / `obsidian-cli print-default --path-only`

Search
- `obsidian-cli search "query"` (note names)
- `obsidian-cli search-content "query"` (inside notes; shows snippets + lines)

Create
- `obsidian-cli create "Folder/New note" --content "..." --open`
- Requires Obsidian URI handler (`obsidian://‚Ä¶`) working (Obsidian installed).
- Avoid creating notes under "hidden" dot-folders (e.g. `.something/...`) via URI; Obsidian may refuse.

Move/rename (safe refactor)
- `obsidian-cli move "old/path/note" "new/path/note"`
- Updates `[[wikilinks]]` and common Markdown links across the vault (this is the main win vs `mv`).

Delete
- `obsidian-cli delete "path/note"`

Prefer direct edits when appropriate: open the `.md` file and change it; Obsidian will pick it up.

Pretty lightweight ‚Äî it's basically a cheat sheet for `obsidian-cli` commands. Your vault path (`/Users/najafali/Desktop/ali-vault`) is already noted in TOOLS.md. ü¶â

Interestingly this doesn't actually tell you what Obsidian is. Does the model (I think you're Opus 4.5) already know about it?
[message_id: deb4f519-ae2e-4738-a1de-ab4ac61cd5de]

Yeah, I know Obsidian well from training data. It's a local-first Markdown knowledge base / note-taking app. Everything lives as plain `.md` files on disk (no proprietary format, no cloud lock-in), with a plugin ecosystem on top for things like graph view, backlinks, templates, dataview queries, etc.

The skill file skips the "what is it" part because the model is expected to already know that ‚Äî it just needs the *operational* details like where the config lives on macOS, how `obsidian-cli` works, and the specific commands. Makes sense as a design choice ‚Äî no point burning tokens explaining Obsidian to a model that's seen a million blog posts about it.

Your vault specifically (~2310 notes, mostly flat structure, git-tracked) is more of a "everything goes in one folder" style rather than heavy nested hierarchy, which is a common Obsidian pattern ‚Äî let the links and search do the organizing rather than folders.

If for example we got access to the Interactive Brokers web API, would you be able to buy and sell things on my behalf?
[message_id: b3db5f0c-fa15-4e19-8945-f9b577080540]

Short answer: yes, technically. If you gave me API credentials for Interactive Brokers, I could hit their REST endpoints via `curl`/`exec` to place orders, check positions, pull account data, etc.

But there's a spectrum of how far you'd want me to go:

**Easy and low-risk:**
- Check portfolio / positions / P&L
- Pull market data and prices
- Generate reports and summaries
- Alert you to price movements or conditions

**Medium ‚Äî with your explicit approval each time:**
- Place specific trades you ask for ("buy 10 shares of X")
- Rebalance to a target allocation you've defined
- Execute limit orders at prices you specify

**Dangerous territory (would need serious guardrails):**
- Autonomous trading based on rules/signals
- Any kind of "use your judgment" discretionary stuff

My honest take: for the **first two categories**, it'd work great. I'd treat it like any other external action ‚Äî never execute without your go-ahead, always confirm the details before submitting. For the third category... I'd want very tight constraints written down, hard limits on position sizes, and probably a paper trading phase first.

The real question is whether IBKR's API requires persistent WebSocket connections or session management that would be awkward with my wake-up-fresh-each-session nature. Their Client Portal API is REST-based which would work, but auth tokens expire and need refreshing.

Want me to look into their API docs and see what the integration would actually look like?

Nah, we're good for now, but this effects my decision on which broker to go with. I think for NISA and Ideco It would just be SBI Shoken, but for non-tax-advantaged accounts we could go with IB. I would first max those two our (total about 350,000JPY a month, 40% S&P 500, 20% Gold, 20% Bonds, 20% Non-US) and then put anything else I can save in IB
[message_id: f0855cc7-2732-4f68-8908-02aee82b0b84]

--- name: gog description: Google Workspace CLI for Gmail, Calendar, Drive, Contacts, Sheets, and Docs. homepage: https://gogcli.sh metadata: {"openclaw":{"emoji":"üéÆ","requires":{"bins":["gog"]},"install":[{"id":"brew","kind":"brew","formula":"steipete/tap/gogcli","bins":["gog"],"label":"Install gog (brew)"}]}} --- # gog Use `gog` for Gmail/Calendar/Drive/Contacts/Sheets/Docs. Requires OAuth setup. Setup (once) - `gog auth credentials /path/to/client_secret.json` - `gog auth add you@gmail.com --services gmail,calendar,drive,contacts,docs,sheets` - `gog auth list` Common commands - Gmail search: `gog gmail search 'newer_than:7d' --max 10` - Gmail messages search (per email, ignores threading): `gog gmail messages search "in:inbox from:ryanair.com" --max 20 --account you@example.com` - Gmail send (plain): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body "Hello"` - Gmail send (multi-line): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-file ./message.txt` - Gmail send (stdin): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-file -` - Gmail send (HTML): `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-html "

Hello

"` - Gmail draft: `gog gmail drafts create --to a@b.com --subject "Hi" --body-file ./message.txt` - Gmail send draft: `gog gmail drafts send ` - Gmail reply: `gog gmail send --to a@b.com --subject "Re: Hi" --body "Reply" --reply-to-message-id ` - Calendar list events: `gog calendar events --from --to ` - Calendar create event: `gog calendar create --summary "Title" --from --to ` - Calendar create with color: `gog calendar create --summary "Title" --from --to --event-color 7` - Calendar update event: `gog calendar update --summary "New Title" --event-color 4` - Calendar show colors: `gog calendar colors` - Drive search: `gog drive search "query" --max 10` - Contacts: `gog contacts list --max 20` - Sheets get: `gog sheets get "Tab!A1:D10" --json` - Sheets update: `gog sheets update "Tab!A1:B2" --values-json '[["A","B"],["1","2"]]' --input USER_ENTERED` - Sheets append: `gog sheets append "Tab!A:C" --values-json '[["x","y","z"]]' --insert INSERT_ROWS` - Sheets clear: `gog sheets clear "Tab!A2:Z"` - Sheets metadata: `gog sheets metadata --json` - Docs export: `gog docs export --format txt --out /tmp/doc.txt` - Docs cat: `gog docs cat ` Calendar Colors - Use `gog calendar colors` to see all available event colors (IDs 1-11) - Add colors to events with `--event-color ` flag - Event color IDs (from `gog calendar colors` output): - 1: #a4bdfc - 2: #7ae7bf - 3: #dbadff - 4: #ff887c - 5: #fbd75b - 6: #ffb878 - 7: #46d6db - 8: #e1e1e1 - 9: #5484ed - 10: #51b749 - 11: #dc2127 Email Formatting - Prefer plain text. Use `--body-file` for multi-paragraph messages (or `--body-file -` for stdin). - Same `--body-file` pattern works for drafts and replies. - `--body` does not unescape `\n`. If you need inline newlines, use a heredoc or `$'Line 1\n\nLine 2'`. - Use `--body-html` only when you need rich formatting. - HTML tags: `

` for paragraphs, `
` for line breaks, `` for bold, `` for italic, `` for links, `

    `/`
  • ` for lists. - Example (plain text via stdin): ```bash gog gmail send --to recipient@example.com \ --subject "Meeting Follow-up" \ --body-file - <<'EOF' Hi Name, Thanks for meeting today. Next steps: - Item one - Item two Best regards, Your Name EOF ``` - Example (HTML list): ```bash gog gmail send --to recipient@example.com \ --subject "Meeting Follow-up" \ --body-html "

    Hi Name,

    Thanks for meeting today. Here are the next steps:

    • Item one
    • Item two

    Best regards,
    Your Name

    " ``` Notes - Set `GOG_ACCOUNT=you@gmail.com` to avoid repeating `--account`. - For scripting, prefer `--json` plus `--no-input`. - Sheets values can be passed via `--values-json` (recommended) or as inline rows. - Docs supports export/cat/copy. In-place edits require a Docs API client (not in gog). - Confirm before sending mail or creating events. - `gog gmail search` returns one row per thread; use `gog gmail messages search` when you need every individual email returned separately.

content.text:
_Japan at Night 1.0 is a project collecting work items that get the tour business to a systemised, professional, and ready for marketing outside of Viator_
# Task List

Below is a general list of tasks for this iteration of the system. The emphasis is on building systems and slightly increasing the tour experience. The idea is to prepare us for the next sprint: the marketing push.

## Lead Magnet and Marketing Funnel
- Create an initial _lead magnet_: An extensive PDF guide to drinking and eating at night in Sendai for anyone that registers their email address.
- Set up a 2-email basic funnel for anyone that wants to set up a tour. Also a contact form, inbound email address, or the ability to set up a call to discuss a tour booking if they want to, no-obligation, completely free.
- Provide functionality for users to leave reviews of the tour, potentially using trustpilot or something like it.
- Create a _landing page_ for the tour that persuades the reader to sign up for a tour with Japan at night. They should be able to book their tour directly from the landing page.
- For marketing the tour, come up with a _logotype_ for use on the website, online marketing, and branded goods.
- Think about the _brand_ Japan at Night, and come up with some _brand guidelines_ for online communication. Think Anthony Bourdain, Somebody Feed Phil, and my special mix of charisma, Japanese ability, and love for Japanese culture. This means figuring out a mission statement for the company, and clarity on values for our offering and operations.
## Sales and bookings
- Accept direct bookings and stripe payments on the `japanatnight.tours` platform.
- Make sure the platform is fully multi-lingual, ready for all languages for all internal and external facing screens.
- Register Viator bookings through notifications/zapier so we have the bookings from Viator in the same database.
## Tour operation
- Create the ability to generate a _run sheet_ for each tour that is available on the online interface for running a tour. This would include beats to hit on the tour, a list of made reservations with ability to cancel, and logging venue arrivals and bill amounts, notes etc.
	- Figure out the template that will be the same on all tours.
		- Allergies
		- Preferences
		- Cash/Card issues in the yokochos
		- Safety briefing
- Create a fun tour summary screen titled "Your night in Sendai", with details of the tour with a public, non-iterable link that the customer can view right after the tour.
	- Venues we went to.
	- Spend at each venue (customer spend separate)
	- Maybe what we ate/drank.
	- Text notes with highlights from the tour.
	- Any pictures we took on the tour. - Perhaps a call to action for leaving a review of the tour.
## Tour Experience
- Discover 5-10 new venues for trying out on the tour, we would have to find them, try out a bunch of their food, and get to know the social culture in the venue.
- Set up a parting gift package with stock for 5 tours.
- Set up red folder for use on tours as part of the safety briefing

# Success Criteria

- All major features of the platform delivered
- All other tasks attempted or completed

# Estimated timeline

Project completion deadline is around end of February 2026

A few quick questions:

- Do you have a rough budget for the evening? I will try to select places to fit your budget.
- Are there any foods or drinks in particular that you would like to have (or avoid)?

If you have any follow-up questions then do let me know.

Looking forward to meeting you in tomorrow evening!

All the best,

-Ali

content.text:
## Links
Twitter: [@japanatnight](https://x.com/japanatnight)
TripAdvisor: https://www.tripadvisor.com/AttractionProductReview-g298249-d28537297-Sendai_Private_Izakaya_and_Bar_Tour-Sendai_Miyagi_Prefecture_Tohoku.html
Viator: https://www.viator.com/tours/Sendai/Best-of-Sendai-Izakaya-and-Bar-Tour/d50597-5507426P1

## Key Ideas
Japan at night is a brand that shows the world, both Japanese and non-Japanese, the fun of going out at night in Japan. It's primarily about food, drink, fun social interactions, and enjoying the people and the culture of Japan in the context of the world at night.

Some key ideas of the brand:

- People and their stories vs. pure sensory pleasure. Japan looks good, smells good, and tastes good. But in people and their stories provide a much richer and more engaging look into what's fun about being in Japan.
- Unapologetic bilingualism. While you can enjoy the parts of Japan catered to tourists, the real fun happens in Japanese-language-only spaces. We will encourage people to learn as much Japanese as possible and provide content catered to both Japanese and non-Japanese people, and will encourage non-Japanese to use experiences at night to improve Japanese. Roughly 43% of all humans are bilingual.
- Sophisticated hedonism. Instead of simply liking the things we go out to experience, we dive deep and nerd out on how to _really_ enjoy those parts of the culture on a sophisticated level.

---

## Lead Magnet
Lead Magnet: [[Exploring Japan at Night]]

Japan at Night - Video Series

8 episodes of around 20m each about places to go in Sendai at night

- Chou Chou
- Rob Roy
- Ma no Su
- Steamers
- Jaco
- Oggi
- Tori Yoshi
- Sumire
- teeny... i
- Great Dane
- Zoo (nado)
- Richikuku
- Daruma
- yabesakaba

Each episode will typically feature:
- an interview with at least one person, talking about the story behind how they got into that industry, what sort of shop it is, how they find it, what life is like for them, and working through typical stereotypes about that world.
- Ordering at least three items and enjoying them in the place, with me explaining what I'm ordering, and enjoying the thing.
- Culture note

Next steps:
- Watch episodes of other food shows on netflix and take notes about their structure:
	- Somebody Feed Phil
	- No Reservations

---

## Blog

What could this blog be about?

- Best X things in Sendai
	- Best Authentic Bars in Sendai
	- Best Yakitori in Sendai
	- Best Hostess Clubs in Sendai
- Sendai Night time area guide
- What to drink in Japan?
	- Nihonshu
	- Shochu
	- Whisky/High balls
	- Beer and beer and beer

- hashigo-bunka, 0-kenme, ikkenme, nikenme, sankenme
