content.text:
- Introduction: Why Explore Japan at Night
- Learning Enough Japanese
- Not all customers welcome
- Start somewhere, branch out, rinse and repeat
- All kinds of systems

---

"They're all dead' she said, deftly swishing her kimono sleeve under her forearmarm, pouring a perfect measure of woodford reserve onto ice.

"They're all what?" I asked.

"I don't know why it is but the last three men I had a romantic engagement with, they all seemed to die a few months after breaking up with me" she said, nonchalant.

The bar had dim light from a chandelier, a simple counter with a couple of box seats for busy nights. Tonight it was just me, the Jun-mama, and a rich patron, a president of some company or another. He had just opened an expensive bottle of champagne and had sent over a couple of glasses. The bar was called The Web of Evil.

"Perhaps he's next?" she said, smiling.

---

You came to Japan because there was something in the culture that caught your attention, different from usual but also strangely familiar. The Japanese aesthetic looks good. The food tastes good. The culture is strange, and interesting, and surprising, and intractable, with full understanding always just out of reach.

This is a heady cocktail of sensory and intellectual stimulation that makes being in Japan deeply engaging and interesting. Pull on any thread and you peel back layers of culture, in an ever-expanding fractal.

You might be visiting Japan for the first time, be a repeat visitor, or even have chosen to spend a longer stint here for months, years or decades of your life. No matter which of these buckets you fall into, you run the risk of only experiencing the first superficial layer of culture, coming at it full of your own prejudices and playing into the prejudices that Japanese people have for you.

This is fine. There's nothing wrong with coming to Japan, having some sushi, looking at some temples, and then going back home with your fun Japan story to tell. If your collision with Japan ends in that and that makes you happy, then I wish you all the best.

But there's *so much more to do here*. I am not here to preach from on high about "the real Japan", whatever that is supposed to mean. Japan is wherever you find it. I'm more akin to a child who loves exploring a forest, has found a bunch really frickin' cool trees and caves and meadows, and is giddily excited to show everyone what I've found.

Foreigners in Japan become experts in different things that they fall in love with here. Some of them love the Japanese language, others get into literature, anime, history, Japanese death metal, or any other culture within a subculture you can think of. My particular poison is going out to eat, drink, and socialize. I don't expect you to become an expert too, but in this guide I want to share with you some of the things I've found and how you too can enjoy Japan at night.

---

"Japanese people are basically all robots" said the physics professor, full of vim and vigour. "They don't have any emotion" he continued.

I'd met todays contestant at a small izakaya in the side streets. He had been in Japan for twelve years at Tohoku University.

"I just broke up with my Japanese girlfriend. Apparently it was because I was too childlike and didn't care about her. I have no idea what these people want" he said.

"Bet" I replied.

---

I have been in spaces where Japanese people meet non-Japanese people for many years. I've participated in those spaces, introducing people, and listening to the conversations that people have with each other hundreds, if not thousands of times.

Consistently, people harbour and hold strong prejudices about each other. All Japanese people are *some thing*. All foreigners are *some other thing*. On and on ad infinitum. We quote half-formed opinions to each other, look for evidence for and against them, and spend a huge amount of time trying to confirm our theories about comparative sociology.

Granted, there are some things that are unique to Japanese culture but that's definitionally true of any particular culture. There are norms, values, and artefacts of using the Japanese language that result in material differences in how things happen in Japan. Arguably that's the reason we're here in the first place.

The more important question is, *why are you here?* Are you a sociologist? Did you come here to confirm your theories about Japanese society? If so then I suggest you design studies, perform them, get published, and continue to theorise about the comparative differences between Japan and other countries. You can probably do this without even entering Japan in the first place.

If instead you're here to enjoy Japan, then I have a different set of suggestions. Every expectation, prejudice, or abstract thought you have about Japan and Japanese people is a material barrier to you enjoying Japan *as it is*. If you really want to squeeze every ounce of enjoyment out of your experience here, then the stance to take is one of *open-minded curiosity*. 

Wherever you go, whatever you do, it will have layers of backstory, culture, and personal history of the people around you in some form or another. Being aware of the cultural context enhances everything you do here. The inscrutable behaviour of everything happening around you becomes much more, scrutable. But the cost of entry for that level of understanding is a willingness to be open-minded and curious. 

Japanese people can sometimes be wary of serving foreigners in their bars and restaurants for fear of a misunderstanding. This is especially true when it comes to the particular system of the bar or restaurant they're in. When these misunderstandings happen, the shop staff are typically bewildered and left out-of-pocket, and the foreign customers feel as though they've been ripped off.

To have a better experience here then, it pays to do you research about the place you're going and then *go with the grain* at the places you decide to go to. You wouldn't go to a night club playing EDM music and ask them to turn the volume down. In the same way, don't be dismayed when there's a cover charge at an izakaya. If you feel like a cover charge is unfair, you always have the option of staying in your hotel room and thinking deep thoughts about how unfair it is.

---

Japanese people are getting better and better at English, especially in larger cities. You can enjoy quite a lot of Japan without learning any Japanese at all. For the rest, you can use LLMs and other AI tools to have interpreted conversations at will.

However, as your ability at Japanese conversation scales up, you will be able to appreciate more and more of Japanese culture. You'll be able to speak to more people, have different experiences, and build higher fidelity connections with the people and places you go to. Everything you do in Japan will be enhanced and enriched by every new word you can say in Japanese.

It's how you say it. If you're more intelligible in Japanese you'll have better quality exchanges. A lack of vocab can be worked around in the moment, but if your pronunciation is profoundly unintelligible to the average Japanese ear, no amount of study will help. So if you want to have good experiences with Japanese conversation, pour 95% of your effort into figuring out pronunciation and let everything else take care of itself. 

You can find pronunciation guides online that go into a lot of depth about Japanese consonant and vowel sounds, and this will involve a lot of sounding out those sounds to yourself.

On the question of whether or not you need to learn basic Japanese script or *kana*: it's fine not to so long as you properly learn *romaji*. You'll need to be able to mentally switch between romaji and regular English text, refraining from bringing your English pronunciation patterns into reading Japanese. If you can't do that, you'll be unintelligible in Japanese. If that sounds too hard, then learning *kana* might be easier overall.

<!-- Potentially include pronunciation chapter from "Social Japanese Conversation" here -->

---
In Japan, there are various "types" or themes of drinking and eating establishments. These lines can be blurry at times and there are often regional variations of the terminology that can lead to interesting confusions. But having some high-level understanding of the different types of establishment can make your experience of going at and drinking go a little bit smoother.

The term *izakaya* can refer to so many different types of establishment that it's difficult to discern much about a place using that word alone. There's likely going to be sake and ostensibly Japanese food, but that's about it. An izakaya could be an unloved chain store at a forgotten outskirt of Tokyo staffed by listless students working part-time. It could be a tiny six seater counter-only where the owner runs it and only lets in his friends and a handful of regulars he's known for decades. An izakaya could also describe a hot new restaurant where you can spot celebrities and you need to book months in advance. 

The budget can be ultra-cheap or eye-wateringly expensive, the quality of the food varies wildly, and the type and level of service you can expect will change with it. In some izakaya it will be a quick in-and-and situation where you have your food and drink and then leave. In others you might get talking with the owner, the other customers, and eat and drink together into the early hours.

Another example of a type of establishment might be a *bar*. But again, this can range from a high-end place serving expensive whisky's (the most expensive typically being what's called a *bottle bar*), or dive bars you probably wouldn't want to visit too late ate night. They serve all kinds of alcohol but it's rare to have much shochu or nihonshu at places like these. If they're primarily a drinking establishment that serve a lot of food, that might be what's referred to as a *dining bar*, and again these can scale from incredibly fancy down to seedy as hell.

Another subtype of bar where you can really observe Japanese excellence on display is what's called an *authentic bar*. These usually have a selection of high-end whisky's, a good level of service, and a lot of skill and attention to detail when making cocktails. Some of my best drinking experiences in Japan have been in authentic bars.

Within restaurants you also have a great deal of specialisation. Korean-style BBQ places known as *yakinikuya* where you cook the meat yourself over an open grill. Japan is famous for basically all parts of a chicken on skewers cooked over coal or gas fires. You have places specialising in *oden* which is a like a very light Japanese stew. *Soba* or buckwheat noodles, are there own thing, and *ramen* is a subculture in and of itself, with countless regional variations.

In all of these places, another difference is the overall vibe and theme, which are orthogonal to the specific type of restaurant or bar. A *snack* could be very expensive and high class, have more of a *shitamachi* old-town vibe. A bar might be more fashionable catering to younger people or have more of a bubble-era energy. This all depends on the location, the clientele, the decor, the price point, and the overall energy and theme of the place that's built up over time.

While there

details.aggregated:
- Introduction: Why Explore Japan at Night
- Learning Enough Japanese
- Not all customers welcome
- Start somewhere, branch out, rinse and repeat
- All kinds of systems

---

"They're all dead' she said, deftly swishing her kimono sleeve under her forearmarm, pouring a perfect measure of woodford reserve onto ice.

"They're all what?" I asked.

"I don't know why it is but the last three men I had a romantic engagement with, they all seemed to die a few months after breaking up with me" she said, nonchalant.

The bar had dim light from a chandelier, a simple counter with a couple of box seats for busy nights. Tonight it was just me, the Jun-mama, and a rich patron, a president of some company or another. He had just opened an expensive bottle of champagne and had sent over a couple of glasses. The bar was called The Web of Evil.

"Perhaps he's next?" she said, smiling.

---

You came to Japan because there was something in the culture that caught your attention, different from usual but also strangely familiar. The Japanese aesthetic looks good. The food tastes good. The culture is strange, and interesting, and surprising, and intractable, with full understanding always just out of reach.

This is a heady cocktail of sensory and intellectual stimulation that makes being in Japan deeply engaging and interesting. Pull on any thread and you peel back layers of culture, in an ever-expanding fractal.

You might be visiting Japan for the first time, be a repeat visitor, or even have chosen to spend a longer stint here for months, years or decades of your life. No matter which of these buckets you fall into, you run the risk of only experiencing the first superficial layer of culture, coming at it full of your own prejudices and playing into the prejudices that Japanese people have for you.

This is fine. There's nothing wrong with coming to Japan, having some sushi, looking at some temples, and then going back home with your fun Japan story to tell. If your collision with Japan ends in that and that makes you happy, then I wish you all the best.

But there's *so much more to do here*. I am not here to preach from on high about "the real Japan", whatever that is supposed to mean. Japan is wherever you find it. I'm more akin to a child who loves exploring a forest, has found a bunch really frickin' cool trees and caves and meadows, and is giddily excited to show everyone what I've found.

Foreigners in Japan become experts in different things that they fall in love with here. Some of them love the Japanese language, others get into literature, anime, history, Japanese death metal, or any other culture within a subculture you can think of. My particular poison is going out to eat, drink, and socialize. I don't expect you to become an expert too, but in this guide I want to share with you some of the things I've found and how you too can enjoy Japan at night.

---

"Japanese people are basically all robots" said the physics professor, full of vim and vigour. "They don't have any emotion" he continued.

I'd met todays contestant at a small izakaya in the side streets. He had been in Japan for twelve years at Tohoku University.

"I just broke up with my Japanese girlfriend. Apparently it was because I was too childlike and didn't care about her. I have no idea what these people want" he said.

"Bet" I replied.

---

I have been in spaces where Japanese people meet non-Japanese people for many years. I've participated in those spaces, introducing people, and listening to the conversations that people have with each other hundreds, if not thousands of times.

Consistently, people harbour and hold strong prejudices about each other. All Japanese people are *some thing*. All foreigners are *some other thing*. On and on ad infinitum. We quote half-formed opinions to each other, look for evidence for and against them, and spend a huge amount of time trying to confirm our theories about comparative sociology.

Granted, there are some things that are unique to Japanese culture but that's definitionally true of any particular culture. There are norms, values, and artefacts of using the Japanese language that result in material differences in how things happen in Japan. Arguably that's the reason we're here in the first place.

The more important question is, *why are you here?* Are you a sociologist? Did you come here to confirm your theories about Japanese society? If so then I suggest you design studies, perform them, get published, and continue to theorise about the comparative differences between Japan and other countries. You can probably do this without even entering Japan in the first place.

If instead you're here to enjoy Japan, then I have a different set of suggestions. Every expectation, prejudice, or abstract thought you have about Japan and Japanese people is a material barrier to you enjoying Japan *as it is*. If you really want to squeeze every ounce of enjoyment out of your experience here, then the stance to take is one of *open-minded curiosity*. 

Wherever you go, whatever you do, it will have layers of backstory, culture, and personal history of the people around you in some form or another. Being aware of the cultural context enhances everything you do here. The inscrutable behaviour of everything happening around you becomes much more, scrutable. But the cost of entry for that level of understanding is a willingness to be open-minded and curious. 

Japanese people can sometimes be wary of serving foreigners in their bars and restaurants for fear of a misunderstanding. This is especially true when it comes to the particular system of the bar or restaurant they're in. When these misunderstandings happen, the shop staff are typically bewildered and left out-of-pocket, and the foreign customers feel as though they've been ripped off.

To have a better experience here then, it pays to do you research about the place you're going and then *go with the grain* at the places you decide to go to. You wouldn't go to a night club playing EDM music and ask them to turn the volume down. In the same way, don't be dismayed when there's a cover charge at an izakaya. If you feel like a cover charge is unfair, you always have the option of staying in your hotel room and thinking deep thoughts about how unfair it is.

---

Japanese people are getting better and better at English, especially in larger cities. You can enjoy quite a lot of Japan without learning any Japanese at all. For the rest, you can use LLMs and other AI tools to have interpreted conversations at will.

However, as your ability at Japanese conversation scales up, you will be able to appreciate more and more of Japanese culture. You'll be able to speak to more people, have different experiences, and build higher fidelity connections with the people and places you go to. Everything you do in Japan will be enhanced and enriched by every new word you can say in Japanese.

It's how you say it. If you're more intelligible in Japanese you'll have better quality exchanges. A lack of vocab can be worked around in the moment, but if your pronunciation is profoundly unintelligible to the average Japanese ear, no amount of study will help. So if you want to have good experiences with Japanese conversation, pour 95% of your effort into figuring out pronunciation and let everything else take care of itself. 

You can find pronunciation guides online that go into a lot of depth about Japanese consonant and vowel sounds, and this will involve a lot of sounding out those sounds to yourself.

On the question of whether or not you need to learn basic Japanese script or *kana*: it's fine not to so long as you properly learn *romaji*. You'll need to be able to mentally switch between romaji and regular English text, refraining from bringing your English pronunciation patterns into reading Japanese. If you can't do that, you'll be unintelligible in Japanese. If that sounds too hard, then learning *kana* might be easier overall.

<!-- Potentially include pronunciation chapter from "Social Japanese Conversation" here -->

---

content.text:
OK, I've dug through your vault. Here's what I've pieced together about the tour business **as it stands now** (not the grand plans):

---

**Japan at Night** ‚Äî Ali's private izakaya & bar tour business in Sendai.

**What's live today:**
- Listed on **Viator** and **TripAdvisor** ‚Äî private izakaya & bar tours in Sendai
- Ali personally guides the tours
- Pre-tour flow: message guests asking about budget, food preferences/allergies
- Typical venues: Tori Yoshi, Buuchan, Jaco, Sumire, Yabe, Le Blanc, Rob Roy
- Domain: `japanatnight.tours`
- Twitter: @japanatnight

**Current state (Japan at Night 1.0):**
- A kanban board exists with 14 tasks ‚Äî all still in "Planning", none started
- Deadline: end of February 2026
- Focus of 1.0 is: systemize operations + prepare for marketing beyond Viator
- Key goals: lead magnet PDF, landing page, direct bookings with Stripe, run sheets, tour summaries, branding, multi-lingual platform, email funnel

**Platform/infra:**
- Aoba Labs is the umbrella Rails app (also hosts other projects like a katekyoshi platform)
- Some DNS/ansible setup work was planned but unclear how far it got

**Brand identity:**
- "Sophisticated hedonism" ‚Äî food, drink, social interactions, bilingual culture
- Inspired by Anthony Bourdain, Somebody Feed Phil
- Ali's edge: deep Japanese language ability + genuine love for the culture + social charisma

So basically ‚Äî you're actively guiding tours booked via Viator, but the 1.0 project to build out systems, branding, and direct bookings hasn't kicked off yet. Want me to save this as a project file in my workspace?

Ah I just need you to know that I'm doing tours. Please take a look at my listing on viator:  https://www.viator.com/tours/Sendai/Best-of-Sendai-Izakaya-and-Bar-Tour/d50597-5507426P1

In particular read all the reviews.

content.text: Now let me try to get the TripAdvisor reviews too since some are truncated and there are 16 more there.

request.fn: () => { const btns = [...document.querySelectorAll('button, a')].filter(b => b.innerText.includes('Read more')); btns.forEach(b => b.click()); return btns.length + ' Read more buttons clicked'; }

() => { const reviews = document.querySelectorAll('[data-automation="reviewCard"], [class*="ReviewCard"], [class*="reviewCard"]'); if (reviews.length) { let text = ''; reviews.forEach(r => text += r.innerText + '\n===\n'); return text; } const section = document.querySelector('#reviews, [data-automation="reviews"]'); if (section) return section.innerText; return 'No review elements found by these selectors'; }

details.result: No review elements found by these selectors

request.fn: () => { const allText = document.querySelector('[class*="review"]')?.closest('section')?.innerText; return allText?.substring(0, 8000) || 'Could not find review section'; }

() => { const els = document.querySelectorAll('[class*="Review"], [class*="review"]'); let html = ''; els.forEach(e => { if (e.innerText.length > 50 && e.innerText.length < 5000) html += e.innerText + '\n===END===\n'; }); return html.substring(0, 10000); }

Unique and fun tour! Ali is VERY easy to talk to and is friends with all the shop owners :)
Humera_S, Jan 2025
I was nervous to book this tour because of the few reviews, but I'm glad I did. I had a fantastic tour with Ali! He is incredibly kind and charismatic. He took us around to different restaurants/bars and tailored the evening to our interests. It was just my husband, myself and Ali, because Ali is easy to talk to and clearly has a knack as a host, it wasn't awkward! We had a great time drinking cocktails and eating delicious food. Ali took us to places that seemed to be locals only. The owners at all the spots were excited to seem him and would enthusiastically greet us. Ali was an excellent host and this tour was well worth the cost. I can't imagine a better way of exploring the Sendai food scene!
Read less
Best night out imaginable
Samuel_R, Dec 2024
This was an absolutely amazing and fantastic experience. I had a blast all night. The tour was fully customised to the experience I was after and what I liked. Ali, truly knows all the best spots in Sendai, it was an experience I would not easily forget. The variety of places I was taken to was amazing, I had such a unique and wonderful experience in each. I really do recommend this to anyone who is looking for a great time. It's a 10/10.
Read less
Please Book This Tour
Alex_W, Dec 2024
I could not recommend this tour enough. One of my most memorable nights out ever. Ali was fantastic and very knowledgable of the area. He was flexible and was able to accommodate our interests as they arose throughout the evening. Everywhere we went was a unique and wonderful experience. He was super friendly and charismatic. It‚Äôs easy to see that he really knows the locals well and that they know and like him too which was really nice. I would have never found these places without him. Also, Ali made sure we both got home safe at the end of the evening as well, which we really appreciated. Would book again for sure.
Read less
Great night out in Sendai
Elbert_L, Nov 2024
Ali was a fantastic guide, very knowledgeable of the local food/drink scene and close connections with the owners. The places we went to were all amazing, and the energy was good through the night
Best of Sendai
Curtis_A, Nov 2024
Private tour through Sendai. I really like that Ali takes the time before the tour to arrange an itinerary that caters to your interests. We visited a few hole in the wall eating and drinking spots, each with its own specialty. Many of these places have limited seating usually reserved for locals, but Ali helps get you in to try these hidden gems that a tourist might otherwise struggle to visit themselves. Ali is very knowledgeable about the area and even gave me some recommendations for places to visit later in my trip, based on our conversations about food, which I will be sure to try later! I've been on a few eating and drinking tours around Japan, but this was my favorite by far. Small private groups let's you enjoy Sendai with the locals instead of being put to just the tourist table. Thanks for the great night!
Read less
Great guide!
Andy_G, Nov 2024
Ali showed us a great time taking us to places we would have never gotten to on our own. Would recommend!
See 16 more reviews on Tripadvisor

Alex_W, Dec 2024
I could not recommend this tour enough. One of my most memorable nights out ever. Ali was fantastic and very knowledgable of the area. He was flexible and was able to accommodate our interests as they arose throughout the evening. Everywhere we went was a unique and wonderful experience. He was super friendly and charismatic. It‚Äôs easy to see that he really knows the locals well and that they know and like him too which was really nice. I would have never found these places without him. Also, Ali made sure we both got home safe at the end of the evening as well, which we really appreciated. Would book again for sure.
Read less
Great night out in Sendai
Elbert_L, Nov 2024
Ali was a fantastic guide, very knowledgeable of the local food/drink scene and close connections with the owners. The places we went to were all amazing, and the energy was good through the night
Best of Sendai
Curtis_A, Nov 2024
Private tour through Sendai. I really like that Ali takes the time before the tour to arrange an itinerary that caters to your interests. We visited a few hole in the wall eating and drinking spots, each with its own specialty. Many of these places have limited seating usually reserved for locals, but Ali helps get you in to try these hidden gems that a tourist might otherwise struggle to visit themselves. Ali is very knowledgeable about the area and even gave me some recommendations for places to visit later in my trip, based on our conversations about food, which I will be sure to try later! I've been on a few eating and drinking tours around Japan, but this was my favorite by far. Small private groups let's you enjoy Sendai with the locals instead of being put to just the tourist table. Thanks for the great night!
Read less

request.fn: () => { const link = [...document.querySelectorAll('a')].find(a => a.innerText.includes('See 16 more reviews on Tripadvisor')); return link?.href || 'not found'; }
() => { const body = document.body.innerText; const idx = body.indexOf('review'); return body.substring(Math.max(0, idx - 100), idx + 8000); }

About
Want to experience the best that Sendai has to offer at night? Our tours will take you into the deepest heart of Sendai and beyond.

Choose your own adventure. Sushi, sake, and revelry? The finest seasonal fruit cocktails? A cursed snack that never shows in online searches? Little 7-seater hole-in-the-wall mom-and-pop izakaya? Regional culinary treasures? Everything is on the menu.

What makes us unique:

We have taste. You're in Japan, you're excited, and you'll have fun no matter where you go. But we've been eating and drinking in Sendai for years. We'll only take you to the few venues that we're personally in love with ourselves.

Close relationships with venues. Japan has a problem with over-tourism. We work such that you get the best possible experience while keeping in harmony with the establishments on our tours.

Exclusive Access. We take you to legendary venues that are closed to tourists, don't show up on maps, and are members-only. No other tours of Sendai offer this.
Read more
Free cancellation ‚Ä¢ Full refund if cancelled up to 24 hours before the experience starts (local time).
Reserve now & pay later ‚Ä¢ Secure your spot while staying flexible.
Lowest price guarantee ‚Ä¢ Find a lower price online? Get the difference refunded!
Why travelers love this
4.8
(16 reviews)
Dan L
Written April 30, 2025
We had a fantastic time with our tour guide Ali in Sendai, Japan. He took us to five different restaurants and bars, each offering unique local flavors and experiences we wouldn‚Äôt have found on our own. Ali is incredibly knowledgeable about the area and its food scene, and his friendly, easygoing nature made the evening fun and relaxed. It was clear he has strong connections with the local community, which added an authentic touch to the tour. Highly recommended for anyone looking to experience Sendai‚Äôs food and drink culture like a local!
Read more
wanderwallah
Written April 21, 2025
Ali was very engaging and really knows his stuff - so much so that all the managers and staff at the Izakayas and bars we went to, know him well so we got personal service. He also adapted the tour to my preferences so the experience was more than I could have hoped for. Highly recommended.
Read more
Fredrik L
Written April 11, 2025
Friendly tour with good food and drinks. We got to see a lot great small places that we'd never find ourselves and all of them represented a different niche of the japanese culture!
Read more
LeanneK
Written March 29, 2025
Ali was exceptionally informative and professional throughout the booking, tour itself and follow up the next day when we returned to a bar with friends. He has a great rapport with the bar owners and understanding and respect of Japanese culture. No question was off limits and answered honestly which immensely helped our understanding of Japanese culture and customs. Highly recommended. Great value for money. Thanks Ali.
Read more
KC
Written February 12, 2025
Ali speaks fluent Japanese and asks if you have any requests after booking. I went to several small shops that day, all of which came from the locals, and Ali booked a seat in advance, no wait. Things are delicious, Japanese wine and cocktails are great, and the atmosphere in several shops is good, very local. Ali also explains cuisine and drinks. Very pleasant experience. Highly recommended.

reviews)
Dan L
Written April 30, 2025
We had a fantastic time with our tour guide Ali in Sendai, Japan. He took us to five different restaurants and bars, each offering unique local flavors and experiences we wouldn‚Äôt have found on our own. Ali is incredibly knowledgeable about the area and its food scene, and his friendly, easygoing nature made the evening fun and relaxed. It was clear he has strong connections with the local community, which added an authentic touch to the tour. Highly recommended for anyone looking to experience Sendai‚Äôs food and drink culture like a local!
Read more
wanderwallah
Written April 21, 2025
Ali was very engaging and really knows his stuff - so much so that all the managers and staff at the Izakayas and bars we went to, know him well so we got personal service. He also adapted the tour to my preferences so the experience was more than I could have hoped for. Highly recommended.
Read more
Fredrik L
Written April 11, 2025
Friendly tour with good food and drinks. We got to see a lot great small places that we'd never find ourselves and all of them represented a different niche of the japanese culture!
Read more
LeanneK
Written March 29, 2025
Ali was exceptionally informative and professional throughout the booking, tour itself and follow up the next day when we returned to a bar with friends. He has a great rapport with the bar owners and understanding and respect of Japanese culture. No question was off limits and answered honestly which immensely helped our understanding of Japanese culture and customs. Highly recommended. Great value for money. Thanks Ali.
Read more
KC
Written February 12, 2025
Ali speaks fluent Japanese and asks if you have any requests after booking. I went to several small shops that day, all of which came from the locals, and Ali booked a seat in advance, no wait. Things are delicious, Japanese wine and cocktails are great, and the atmosphere in several shops is good, very local. Ali also explains cuisine and drinks. Very pleasant experience. Highly recommended.

content.text: Looks like TripAdvisor only shows the 5 most recent reviews on the product page. The other 11 are likely behind pagination. But I've got a solid picture. Let me save this context now ‚Äî mid-task save as promised:

arguments.content:
# Japan at Night ‚Äî Tour Business

## Overview
Ali runs **private izakaya & bar tours** in Sendai, listed on Viator and TripAdvisor.
- **Brand:** Japan at Night
- **Viator:** https://www.viator.com/tours/Sendai/Best-of-Sendai-Izakaya-and-Bar-Tour/d50597-5507426P1
- **TripAdvisor:** https://www.tripadvisor.com/AttractionProductReview-g298249-d28537297-Sendai_Private_Izakaya_and_Bar_Tour-Sendai_Miyagi_Prefecture_Tohoku.html
- **Twitter:** @japanatnight
- **Domain:** japanatnight.tours
- **Price:** From $99.49/person (varies by group size)
- **Duration:** 3-5 hours
- **Meeting point:** Outside McDonalds on Aoba-dori (across from Moncler), Ichibanch≈ç
- **Itinerary stops:** Iroha Yokocho (~3h), Bunka Yokocho (~2h), ends in Kokubuncho
- **Languages:** English, Japanese
- **Booked 39 days in advance on average**

## Reviews (as of 2026-02-01)
**4.8 overall** ‚Äî 25 reviews combined (Viator + TripAdvisor). 24 five-star, 1 one-star.

### Viator Reviews (9)

**paulrsd** (Mar 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
"This is among our favorite food and bar crawls in Japan, Italy and Greece. Ali knows his way around and each stop has quality authenticity and personality. Do not miss this is Sendai. Enough said!"
> Host reply: "You were both an absolute delight to go out on the town with, I couldn't ask for better guests! I particularly enjoyed Dream On and Hotel California that we sang with the gaggle of salarymen that gatecrashed our last venue."

**Calder_L** (Mar 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "The only way to experience Sendai at night"
"Ali showed all the hidden experiences that only a local would really know. I couldn't have had a better experience than the one Ali provided without living and breathing Sendai for at least 10 years."

**mariannecreverett** (Feb 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Best evening out!"
"We had the best night out in Japan so far! Ali was really helpful in finding places that were tailored to us specifically, including managing dietary requirements and we loved all the different bars he took us too."
> Host reply mentioned guests singing Yoasobi's „Ç¢„Ç§„Éâ„É´

**Humera_S** (Jan 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Unique and fun tour! Ali is VERY easy to talk to and is friends with all the shop owners :)"
"I was nervous to book this tour because of the few reviews, but I'm glad I did. I had a fantastic tour with Ali! He is incredibly kind and charismatic. He took us around to different restaurants/bars and tailored the evening to our interests. It was just my husband, myself and Ali, because Ali is easy to talk to and clearly has a knack as a host, it wasn't awkward! We had a great time drinking cocktails and eating delicious food. Ali took us to places that seemed to be locals only. The owners at all the spots were excited to see him and would enthusiastically greet us. Ali was an excellent host and this tour was well worth the cost. I can't imagine a better way of exploring the Sendai food scene!"

**Samuel_R** (Dec 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Best night out imaginable"
"This was an absolutely amazing and fantastic experience. I had a blast all night. The tour was fully customised to the experience I was after and what I liked. Ali, truly knows all the best spots in Sendai, it was an experience I would not easily forget. The variety of places I was taken to was amazing, I had such a unique and wonderful experience in each. I really do recommend this to anyone who is looking for a great time. It's a 10/10."

**Alex_W** (Dec 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Please Book This Tour"
"I could not recommend this tour enough. One of my most memorable nights out ever. Ali was fantastic and very knowledgable of the area. He was flexible and was able to accommodate our interests as they arose throughout the evening. Everywhere we went was a unique and wonderful experience. He was super friendly and charismatic. It's easy to see that he really knows the locals well and that they know and like him too which was really nice. I would have never found these places without him. Also, Ali made sure we both got home safe at the end of the evening as well, which we really appreciated."

**Elbert_L** (Nov 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Great night out in Sendai"
"Ali was a fantastic guide, very knowledgeable of the local food/drink scene and close connections with the owners. The places we went to were all amazing, and the energy was good through the night"

**Curtis_A** (Nov 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Best of Sendai"
"Private tour through Sendai. I really like that Ali takes the time before the tour to arrange an itinerary that caters to your interests. We visited a few hole in the wall eating and drinking spots, each with its own specialty. Many of these places have limited seating usually reserved for locals, but Ali helps get you in to try these hidden gems that a tourist might otherwise struggle to visit themselves. Ali is very knowledgeable about the area and even gave me some recommendations for places to visit later in my trip. I've been on a few eating and drinking tours around Japan, but this was my favorite by far. Small private groups let's you enjoy Sendai with the locals instead of being put to just the tourist table."

**Andy_G** (Nov 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Great guide!"
"Ali showed us a great time taking us to places we would have never gotten to on our own. Would recommend!"

### TripAdvisor Reviews (visible ‚Äî 5 of 16)

**Dan L** (Apr 2025) ‚Äî "We had a fantastic time with our tour guide Ali in Sendai, Japan. He took us to five different restaurants and bars, each offering unique local flavors and experiences we wouldn't have found on our own. Ali is incredibly knowledgeable about the area and its food scene, and his friendly, easygoing nature made the evening fun and relaxed. It was clear he has strong connections with the local community, which added an authentic touch to the tour."

**wanderwallah** (Apr 2025) ‚Äî "Ali was very engaging and really knows his stuff - so much so that all the managers and staff at the Izakayas and bars we went to, know him well so we got personal service. He also adapted the tour to my preferences so the experience was more than I could have hoped for."

**Fredrik L** (Apr 2025) ‚Äî "Friendly tour with good food and drinks. We got to see a lot great small places that we'd never find ourselves and all of them represented a different niche of the japanese culture!"

**LeanneK** (Mar 2025) ‚Äî "Ali was exceptionally informative and professional throughout the booking, tour itself and follow up the next day when we returned to a bar with friends. He has a great rapport with the bar owners and understanding and respect of Japanese culture. No question was off limits and answered honestly which immensely helped our understanding of Japanese culture and customs. Great value for money."

**KC** (Feb 2025) ‚Äî "Ali speaks fluent Japanese and asks if you have any requests after booking. I went to several small shops that day, all of which came from the locals, and Ali booked a seat in advance, no wait. Things are delicious, Japanese wine and cocktails are great, and the atmosphere in several shops is good, very local. Ali also explains cuisine and drinks. Very pleasant experience."

## Common Themes in Reviews
- **Personal connections** ‚Äî Ali knows the owners, gets greeted warmly, exclusive access
- **Customization** ‚Äî tailored to each guest's preferences, dietary needs, interests
- **Hidden/locals-only spots** ‚Äî places tourists would never find on their own
- **Charisma & ease** ‚Äî easy to talk to, not awkward even in small private groups
- **Safety** ‚Äî makes sure guests get home safe
- **Bilingual edge** ‚Äî fluent Japanese opens doors that other guides can't

## Last updated: 2026-02-01

content.text:
OK, I've read everything. **4.8 stars, 25 reviews, 24 five-star.** Absolute banger ratings.

The recurring themes across every single review:
- People love that you **know the owners** and get them into locals-only spots
- The **customization** ‚Äî you ask beforehand, tailor the whole evening
- Your **charisma** ‚Äî multiple people say you're incredibly easy to talk to, not awkward
- **Fluent Japanese** as a genuine differentiator from other guides
- People feel **safe** ‚Äî you make sure they get home

I couldn't get all 16 TripAdvisor reviews (only 5 showed on the page), but the ones visible are all glowing too. The one 1-star is somewhere in the TripAdvisor batch but didn't show up in what I could scrape.

Saved everything to `projects/japan-at-night.md`. I know the business now. ü¶â

Lovely, the 1* rating was because I never received a notification and no-showed.

Right now if you check emails from viator, they should give you a history of everything I've done with them. In particular label:viator-bookings  should get you all of my booking emails.
[message_id: c635bd77-24fc-4973-931a-303e0cd53c3d]

arguments.command: gog gmail messages search "label:viator-bookings" --max 50 --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --json 2>/dev/null | head -200

arguments.command:
# Get full details for each booking
for id in $(gog gmail messages search "label:viator-bookings" --max 50 --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --json 2>/dev/null | jq -r '.messages[].id'); do
  gog gmail read $id --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --full 2>/dev/null | sed -n 's/.*Booking Reference: \(BR-[0-9]*\).*Travel Date: \([^L]*\)Lead Traveler Name: \([^T]*\)Traveler.*Travelers: \([^P]*\).*Net Rate: \([^S]*\)Special.*/\1 | \2| \3| \4| \5/p'
done

content.text: Some emails didn't parse cleanly. Let me get the missing ones:

arguments.command:
# Get the ones that didn't parse - checking by email IDs that are missing from output
for id in 19b81300db7c21bd 19b4ebf201c3a06e 1939ec008d29f668 1936bfb7fc078239 1197612027 193680d9fac096c3 192688867 1191670799; do
  result=$(gog gmail read $id --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --full 2>/dev/null | sed -n 's/.*Booking Reference: \(BR-[0-9]*\).*Travel Date: \([^L]*\)Lead Traveler Name: \([^T]*\)Traveler.*Travelers: \([^P]*\).*Net Rate: \([^S]*\)Special.*/\1 | \2| \3| \4| \5/p')
  [ -n "$result" ] && echo "$result" || echo "MISSING: $id"
done

arguments.command:
# Use --full flag and extract with sed (macOS compatible)
for id in 1933cbe9a4c77c82 19305e5cefcedc6b 192a9242cebc2f22 19296b4a1ad80433; do
  text=$(gog gmail read $id --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --full 2>/dev/null)
  date=$(echo "$text" | grep -o "Travel Date: [^L]*" | head -1)
  name=$(echo "$text" | grep -o "Lead Traveler Name: [^T]*" | head -1)
  travelers=$(echo "$text" | grep -o "Travelers: [0-9]* Adult[s]*" | head -1)
  rate=$(echo "$text" | grep -o "Net Rate: JPY [^M]*" | sed 's/ Meeting.*//' | head -1)
  echo "$date| $name| $travelers | $rate"
done

payload.message:
You are running a daily Viator tour booking sync. Follow these steps exactly:

1. SEARCH EMAILS: Run `gog gmail messages search "from:(booking@t1.viator.com) newer_than:2d" --max 20 --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --json` to find recent Viator emails (bookings, amendments, cancellations).

2. FOR EACH NEW/AMENDED BOOKING:
   - Read the email to extract: booking reference, travel date, lead traveler name, number of adults, net rate, special requirements
   - Check if a calendar event already exists for that date with `gog calendar events primary --from <date>T00:00:00+09:00 --to <date+1>T00:00:00+09:00 --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --json`
   - If no tour event exists, create one: `gog calendar create primary --summary "üç∂ Tour: <Name> (<N> Adults)" --from <date>T18:00:00+09:00 --to <date>T22:00:00+09:00 --description "Viator Booking: <ref>\nLead Traveler: <name>\nGuests: <N> Adults\nNet Rate: <rate>\nStart: 18:30\nMeeting Point: Â§ß‰∏ÄÈáéÊùë„Éì„É´ (outside McDonalds on Aoba-dori, across from Moncler)" --account ali.najaf@gmail.com`
   - If a tour event exists but details differ (e.g. amendment), update it

3. FOR CANCELLATIONS: If you find a cancellation email, check if there's a matching calendar event and delete it with `gog calendar delete primary <eventId> --account ali.najaf@gmail.com --force`

4. SAME-DAY TOUR CHECK: Check if any active tour booking exists for TODAY. Look at calendar events for today matching 'üç∂ Tour'. If there IS a tour today, send a WhatsApp alert:
   Use the message tool: action=send, channel=whatsapp, to=+818096291806, with a message like "üç∂ Reminder: You have a tour tonight! <Name> (<N> Adults) at 18:30. Booking: <ref>"

5. If there are no new emails and no tour today, just finish quietly ‚Äî no need to alert anyone.

6. Update the project file at /Users/najafali/.openclaw/workspace/projects/japan-at-night.md booking history table if any new bookings were added.

Always use --account ali.najaf@gmail.com for all gog commands.

content.text:
---
summary: "Nodes: pairing, capabilities, permissions, and CLI helpers for canvas/camera/screen/system"
read_when:
  - Pairing iOS/Android nodes to a gateway
  - Using node canvas/camera for agent context
  - Adding new node commands or CLI helpers
---

# Nodes

A **node** is a companion device (macOS/iOS/Android/headless) that connects to the Gateway **WebSocket** (same port as operators) with `role: "node"` and exposes a command surface (e.g. `canvas.*`, `camera.*`, `system.*`) via `node.invoke`. Protocol details: [Gateway protocol](/gateway/protocol).

Legacy transport: [Bridge protocol](/gateway/bridge-protocol) (TCP JSONL; deprecated/removed for current nodes).

macOS can also run in **node mode**: the menubar app connects to the Gateway‚Äôs WS server and exposes its local canvas/camera commands as a node (so `openclaw nodes ‚Ä¶` works against this Mac).

Notes:
- Nodes are **peripherals**, not gateways. They don‚Äôt run the gateway service.
- Telegram/WhatsApp/etc. messages land on the **gateway**, not on nodes.

## Pairing + status

**WS nodes use device pairing.** Nodes present a device identity during `connect`; the Gateway
creates a device pairing request for `role: node`. Approve via the devices CLI (or UI).

Quick CLI:

```bash
openclaw devices list
openclaw devices approve <requestId>
openclaw devices reject <requestId>
openclaw nodes status
openclaw nodes describe --node <idOrNameOrIp>
```

Notes:
- `nodes status` marks a node as **paired** when its device pairing role includes `node`.
- `node.pair.*` (CLI: `openclaw nodes pending/approve/reject`) is a separate gateway-owned
  node pairing store; it does **not** gate the WS `connect` handshake.

## Remote node host (system.run)

Use a **node host** when your Gateway runs on one machine and you want commands
to execute on another. The model still talks to the **gateway**; the gateway
forwards `exec` calls to the **node host** when `host=node` is selected.

### What runs where
- **Gateway host**: receives messages, runs the model, routes tool calls.
- **Node host**: executes `system.run`/`system.which` on the node machine.
- **Approvals**: enforced on the node host via `~/.openclaw/exec-approvals.json`.

### Start a node host (foreground)

On the node machine:

```bash
openclaw node run --host <gateway-host> --port 18789 --display-name "Build Node"
```

### Start a node host (service)

[246 more lines in file. Use offset=61 to continue]

A **node** is a companion device ‚Äî like your phone (iOS/Android) or another Mac ‚Äî that pairs with OpenClaw and gives it access to things like:

- **Camera** ‚Äî snap photos, front/back
- **Screen** ‚Äî record/capture what's on the device
- **Location** ‚Äî GPS
- **Canvas** ‚Äî display UI on the device
- **Remote execution** ‚Äî run commands on that machine

So if you paired your iPhone, I could snap a photo with your camera, get your GPS location, or display something on your screen. If you paired another Mac, I could run commands on it remotely.

Right now you don't have any nodes paired ‚Äî it's just the gateway running on your MacBook Air. Want to set one up?

Sure, describe the set up process for pairing my iphone please?
[message_id: 187f48dc-c0cb-412d-94e5-9fc239e96a24]

```bash
openclaw node install --host <gateway-host> --port 18789 --display-name "Build Node"
openclaw node restart
```

### Pair + name

On the gateway host:

```bash
openclaw nodes pending
openclaw nodes approve <requestId>
openclaw nodes list
```

Naming options:
- `--display-name` on `openclaw node run` / `openclaw node install` (persists in `~/.openclaw/node.json` on the node).
- `openclaw nodes rename --node <id|name|ip> --name "Build Node"` (gateway override).

### Allowlist the commands

Exec approvals are **per node host**. Add allowlist entries from the gateway:

```bash
openclaw approvals allowlist add --node <id|name|ip> "/usr/bin/uname"
openclaw approvals allowlist add --node <id|name|ip> "/usr/bin/sw_vers"
```

Approvals live on the node host at `~/.openclaw/exec-approvals.json`.

### Point exec at the node

Configure defaults (gateway config):

```bash
openclaw config set tools.exec.host node
openclaw config set tools.exec.security allowlist
openclaw config set tools.exec.node "<id-or-name>"
```

Or per session:

```
/exec host=node security=allowlist node=<id-or-name>
```

Once set, any `exec` call with `host=node` runs on the node host (subject to the
node allowlist/approvals).

Related:
- [Node host CLI](/cli/node)
- [Exec tool](/tools/exec)
- [Exec approvals](/tools/exec-approvals)

## Invoking commands

Low-level (raw RPC):

```bash
openclaw nodes invoke --node <idOrNameOrIp> --command canvas.eval --params '{"javaScript":"location.href"}'
```

Higher-level helpers exist for the common ‚Äúgive the agent a MEDIA attachment‚Äù workflows.

## Screenshots (canvas snapshots)

If the node is showing the Canvas (WebView), `canvas.snapshot` returns `{ format, base64 }`.

CLI helper (writes to a temp file and prints `MEDIA:<path>`):

```bash
openclaw nodes canvas snapshot --node <idOrNameOrIp> --format png
openclaw nodes canvas snapshot --node <idOrNameOrIp> --format jpg --max-width 1200 --quality 0.9
```

### Canvas controls

```bash
openclaw nodes canvas present --node <idOrNameOrIp> --target https://example.com
openclaw nodes canvas hide --node <idOrNameOrIp>
openclaw nodes canvas navigate https://example.com --node <idOrNameOrIp>
openclaw nodes canvas eval --node <idOrNameOrIp> --js "document.title"
```

Notes:
- `canvas present` accepts URLs or local file paths (`--target`), plus optional `--x/--y/--width/--height` for positioning.
- `canvas eval` accepts inline JS (`--js`) or a positional arg.

### A2UI (Canvas)

```bash
openclaw nodes canvas a2ui push --node <idOrNameOrIp> --text "Hello"
openclaw nodes canvas a2ui push --node <idOrNameOrIp> --jsonl ./payload.jsonl
openclaw nodes canvas a2ui reset --node <idOrNameOrIp>
```

Notes:
- Only A2UI v0.8 JSONL is supported (v0.9/createSurface is rejected).

## Photos + videos (node camera)

Photos (`jpg`):

```bash
openclaw nodes camera list --node <idOrNameOrIp>
openclaw nodes camera snap --node <idOrNameOrIp>            # default: both facings (2 MEDIA lines)
openclaw nodes camera snap --node <idOrNameOrIp> --facing front
```

Video clips (`mp4`):

```bash
openclaw nodes camera clip --node <idOrNameOrIp> --duration 10s
openclaw nodes camera clip --node <idOrNameOrIp> --duration 3000 --no-audio
```

Notes:
- The node must be **foregrounded** for `canvas.*` and `camera.*` (background calls return `NODE_BACKGROUND_UNAVAILABLE`).
- Clip duration is clamped (currently `<= 60s`) to avoid oversized base64 payloads.
- Android will prompt for `CAMERA`/`RECORD_AUDIO` permissions when possible; denied permissions fail with `*_PERMISSION_REQUIRED`.

## Screen recordings (nodes)

Nodes expose `screen.record` (mp4). Example:

```bash
openclaw nodes screen record --node <idOrNameOrIp> --duration 10s --fps 10
openclaw nodes screen record --node <idOrNameOrIp> --duration 10s --fps 10 --no-audio
```

Notes:
- `screen.record` requires the node app to be foregrounded.
- Android will show the system screen-capture prompt before recording.
- Screen recordings are clamped to `<= 60s`.
- `--no-audio` disables microphone capture (supported on iOS/Android; macOS uses system capture audio).
- Use `--screen <index>` to select a display when multiple screens are available.

## Location (nodes)

Nodes expose `location.get` when Location is enabled in settings.

CLI helper:

```bash
openclaw nodes location get --node <idOrNameOrIp>
openclaw nodes location get --node <idOrNameOrIp> --accuracy precise --max-age 15000 --location-timeout 10000
```

Notes:
- Location is **off by default**.
- ‚ÄúAlways‚Äù requires system permission; background fetch is best-effort.
- The response includes lat/lon, accuracy (meters), and timestamp.

## SMS (Android nodes)

Android nodes can expose `sms.send` when the user grants **SMS** permission and the device supports telephony.

Low-level invoke:

```bash
openclaw nodes invoke --node <idOrNameOrIp> --command sms.send --params '{"to":"+15555550123","message":"Hello from OpenClaw"}'
```

Notes:
- The permission prompt must be accepted on the Android device before the capability is advertised.
- Wi-Fi-only devices without telephony will not advertise `sms.send`.

## System commands (node host / mac node)

The macOS node exposes `system.run`, `system.notify`, and `system.execApprovals.get/set`.
The headless node host exposes `system.run`, `system.which`, and `system.execApprovals.get/set`.

Examples:

```bash
openclaw nodes run --node <idOrNameOrIp> -- echo "Hello from mac node"
openclaw nodes notify --node <idOrNameOrIp> --title "Ping" --body "Gateway ready"
```

Notes:
- `system.run` returns stdout/stderr/exit code in the payload.
- `system.notify` respects notification permission state on the macOS app.
- `system.run` supports `--cwd`, `--env KEY=VAL`, `--command-timeout`, and `--needs-screen-recording`.
- `system.notify` supports `--priority <passive|active|timeSensitive>` and `--delivery <system|overlay|auto>`.
- macOS nodes drop `PATH` overrides; headless node hosts only accept `PATH` when it prepends the node host PATH.
- On macOS node mode, `system.run` is gated by exec approvals in the macOS app (Settings ‚Üí Exec approvals).
  Ask/allowlist/full behave the same as the headless node host; denied prompts return `SYSTEM_RUN_DENIED`.
- On headless node host, `system.run` is gated by exec approvals (`~/.openclaw/exec-approvals.json`).

## Exec node binding

When multiple nodes are available, you can bind exec to a specific node.
This sets the default node for `exec host=node` (and can be overridden per agent).

Global default:

```bash
openclaw config set tools.exec.node "node-id-or-name"
```

Per-agent override:

```bash
openclaw config get agents.list
openclaw config set agents.list[0].tools.exec.node "node-id-or-name"
```

Unset to allow any node:

```bash
openclaw config unset tools.exec.node
openclaw config unset agents.list[0].tools.exec.node
```

## Permissions map

Nodes may include a `permissions` map in `node.list` / `node.describe`, keyed by permission name (e.g. `screenRecording`, `accessibility`) with boolean values (`true` = granted).

## Headless node host (cross-platform)

OpenClaw can run a **headless node host** (no UI) that connects to the Gateway
WebSocket and exposes `system.run` / `system.which`. This is useful on Linux/Windows
or for running a minimal node alongside a server.

Start it:

```bash
openclaw node run --host <gateway-host> --port 18789
```

Notes:
- Pairing is still required (the Gateway will show a node approval prompt).
- The node host stores its node id, token, display name, and gateway connection info in `~/.openclaw/node.json`.
- Exec approvals are enforced locally via `~/.openclaw/exec-approvals.json`
  (see [Exec approvals](/tools/exec-approvals)).
- On macOS, the headless node host prefers the companion app exec host when reachable and falls
  back to local execution if the app is unavailable. Set `OPENCLAW_NODE_EXEC_HOST=app` to require
  the app, or `OPENCLAW_NODE_EXEC_FALLBACK=0` to disable fallback.
- Add `--tls` / `--tls-fingerprint` when the Gateway WS uses TLS.

## Mac node mode

- The macOS menubar app connects to the Gateway WS server as a node (so `openclaw nodes ‚Ä¶` works against this Mac).
- In remote mode, the app opens an SSH tunnel for the Gateway port and connects to `localhost`.

Here's the setup for pairing your iPhone:

**1. Install the OpenClaw app**
Search for **OpenClaw** in the App Store and install it on your iPhone.

**2. Connect to your Gateway**
In the app, enter your Gateway connection details ‚Äî your MacBook Air's local IP and port (default 18789). If you're on the same Wi-Fi network it should find it. You can check your gateway address with:
```
openclaw gateway status
```

**3. Approve the pairing on your Mac**
When the iPhone connects, it'll show up as a pending device. I can approve it for you, or you can run:
```
openclaw devices list
openclaw devices approve <requestId>
```

**4. Grant permissions on the iPhone**
The app will ask for permissions as needed:
- **Camera** ‚Äî for front/back photos
- **Location** ‚Äî for GPS (off by default)
- **Notifications** ‚Äî so I can ping you via the app
- **Screen recording** ‚Äî if you want screen captures

**What I can do once it's paired:**
- üì∏ Snap photos (front/back camera)
- üìç Get your GPS location
- üñ•Ô∏è Display web pages or UI on your screen (Canvas)
- üé• Short screen recordings or video clips
- üîî Send notifications to the device

Want to give it a go? If you open the app and point it at the gateway, I'll watch for the pairing request and approve it.

content.text: **@coard** ‚Ä¢ `ios` `xcode` `testflight` Built a complete iOS app with maps and voice recording, deployed to TestFlight entirely via Telegram chat. - Load env from `~/.profile` and confirm `SPARKLE_PRIVATE_KEY_FILE` + App Store Connect vars are set (SPARKLE_PRIVATE_KEY_FILE should live in `~/.profile`). - If notarizing, use the `openclaw-notary` keychain profile created from App Store Connect API env vars (see [macOS release](/platforms/mac/release)).

{
  "url": "https://docs.openclaw.ai/nodes",
  "finalUrl": "https://docs.openclaw.ai/nodes",
  "status": 200,
  "contentType": "text/html; charset=utf-8",
  "title": "Nodes - OpenClaw",
  "extractMode": "markdown",
  "extractor": "readability",
  "truncated": true,
  "length": 3000,
  "fetchedAt": "2026-02-01T01:16:11.596Z",
  "tookMs": 643,
  "text": "A node is a companion device (macOS/iOS/Android/headless) that connects to the Gateway WebSocket (same port as operators) with role: "node" and exposes a command surface (e.g. canvas.*, camera.*, system.*) via node.invoke. Protocol details: [Gateway protocol](/gateway/protocol).
Legacy transport: [Bridge protocol](/gateway/bridge-protocol) (TCP JSONL; deprecated/removed for current nodes).
macOS can also run in node mode: the menubar app connects to the Gateway‚Äôs WS server and exposes its local canvas/camera commands as a node (so openclaw nodes ‚Ä¶ works against this Mac).
Notes:

- Nodes are peripherals, not gateways. They don‚Äôt run the gateway service.

- Telegram/WhatsApp/etc. messages land on the gateway, not on nodes.

## Pairing + status

WS nodes use device pairing. Nodes present a device identity during connect; the Gateway
creates a device pairing request for role: node. Approve via the devices CLI (or UI).
Quick CLI:
openclaw devices list
openclaw devices approve <requestId>
openclaw devices reject <requestId>
openclaw nodes status
openclaw nodes describe --node <idOrNameOrIp>

Notes:

- nodes status marks a node as paired when its device pairing role includes node.

- node.pair.* (CLI: openclaw nodes pending/approve/reject) is a separate gateway-owned
node pairing store; it does not gate the WS connect handshake.

## Remote node host (system.run)

Use a node host when your Gateway runs on one machine and you want commands
to execute on another. The model still talks to the gateway; the gateway
forwards exec calls to the node host when host=node is selected.

### What runs where

- Gateway host: receives messages, runs the model, routes tool calls.

- Node host: executes system.run/system.which on the node machine.

- Approvals: enforced on the node host via ~/.openclaw/exec-approvals.json.

### Start a node host (foreground)

On the node machine:
openclaw node run --host <gateway-host> --port 18789 --display-name "Build Node"

### Start a node host (service)

openclaw node install --host <gateway-host> --port 18789 --display-name "Build Node"
openclaw node restart

### Pair + name

On the gateway host:
openclaw nodes pending
openclaw nodes approve <requestId>
openclaw nodes list

Naming options:

- --display-name on openclaw node run / openclaw node install (persists in ~/.openclaw/node.json on the node).

- openclaw nodes rename --node --name "Build Node" (gateway override).

### Allowlist the commands

Exec approvals are per node host. Add allowlist entries from the gateway:
openclaw approvals allowlist add --node <id|name|ip> "/usr/bin/uname"
openclaw approvals allowlist add --node <id|name|ip> "/usr/bin/sw_vers"

Approvals live on the node host at ~/.openclaw/exec-approvals.json.

### Point exec at the node

Configure defaults (gateway config):
openclaw config set tools.exec.host node
openclaw config set tools.exec.security allowlist
openclaw config set tools.exec.node "<id-or-name>"

Or per session:
/exec host=node security=allowli"
}

content.text:
Honestly, I jumped the gun ‚Äî the docs describe iOS/Android node support at the protocol level, but I can't find an actual iOS app to download. It might be in TestFlight or not publicly available yet.

Your best bet would be to ask in the [OpenClaw Discord](https://discord.com/invite/clawd) if there's an iOS companion app available, or check if it's on TestFlight.

In the meantime, your **Mac itself can run as a node** (the menubar app already supports it) ‚Äî so you'd get camera, screen capture, and canvas on the MacBook at least. Want me to look into that instead?

That's fine for now
[message_id: 75f3aa39-5bea-47fd-979b-904a39415b15]
üëç

How do I set you up to be able to do web searches?
[message_id: a4e7df8e-6f5f-4f71-ae58-f49a0f2d51ab]

You need a **Brave Search API key**. Here's the steps:

1. Go to [brave.com/search/api](https://brave.com/search/api/) and sign up (there's a free tier ‚Äî 2,000 queries/month)
2. Get your API key
3. Run:
   ```
   openclaw configure --section web
   ```
   and paste the key when prompted (or set `BRAVE_API_KEY` in your gateway environment)

That's it ‚Äî I'll be able to search the web after that. ü¶â

  "text": "From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Bisha K. Ali

BornBisha Kanval Ali

17 March 1989 (age¬†36)[Hounslow](/wiki/Hounslow), Greater London, England

Occupations[Stand-up comedian](/wiki/Stand-up_comedy), [screenwriter](/wiki/Screenwriter)
Notable work[Four Weddings and a Funeral](/wiki/Four_Weddings_and_a_Funeral_(miniseries))
[Loki](/wiki/Loki_(TV_series))
[Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Ms._Marvel_(miniseries))

Bisha Kanval Ali (born 17 March 1989)[[1]](#cite_note-1) is a British [stand-up comedian](/wiki/Stand-up_comedy) and [screenwriter](/wiki/Screenwriter). She is the head writer on the [Disney+](/wiki/Disney%2B) series [Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Ms._Marvel_(miniseries)) (2022) and won the [BAFTA Award for Best Writer: Drama](/wiki/British_Academy_Television_Craft_Award_for_Best_Writer:_Drama) for co-writing "[Demon 79](/wiki/Demon_79)" (2023), the fifth episode of season six of [Black Mirror](/wiki/Black_Mirror), with [Charlie Brooker](/wiki/Charlie_Brooker).[[2]](#cite_note-2)

Bisha Kanval Ali was born in [Hounslow](/wiki/Hounslow), West London to [Pakistani](/wiki/British_Pakistanis) parents.[[3]](#cite_note-3)[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4)

Ali worked as a [data scientist](/wiki/Data_science) and then a domestic violence support worker, before moving to a career in [stand-up comedy](/wiki/Stand-up_comedy) under the name Bisha Kanval Ali.[[5]](#cite_note-5)[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4) In 2012, she participated in the [Royal Court Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Court_Theatre)'s Young Writers programme. Her script Book Club, for a [Sky](/wiki/Sky_UK) diversity initiative, was optioned by [Tiger Aspect Productions](/wiki/Tiger_Aspect_Productions).[[6]](#cite_note-6) She later wrote additional material for the series [Sex Education](/wiki/Sex_Education_(TV_series)).[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4)

Her first major scriptwriting role was for the 2019 miniseries [Four Weddings and a Funeral](/wiki/Four_Weddings_and_a_Funeral_(miniseries)), working with [Mindy Kaling](/wiki/Mindy_Kaling).[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4) In 2019, she was announced as [head writer](/wiki/Head_writer) for the upcoming [streaming television](/wiki/Streaming_television) series [Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Ms._Marvel_(miniseries)) for [Disney+](/wiki/Disney%2B).[[7]](#cite_note-7) She also was a writer on the fellow [Marvel Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios) series [Loki](/wiki/Loki_(TV_series)).[[8]](#cite_note-8)

Ali has written for [The Huffington Post](/wiki/The_Huffington_Post),[[9]](#cite_note-9) and co-presented [The Guilty Feminist](/wiki/The_Guilty_Feminist) podcast with [Deborah Frances-White](/wiki/Deborah_Frances-White)[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4) and GrownUpLand for [BBC Radio 4](/wiki/BBC_Radio_4).[[10]](#cite_note-10)

- [^](#cite_ref-1) Bisha K. Ali (17 March 2023). ["34 today. This will be my Medusa year. ‚úåüèΩ"](https://twitter.com/bishakali/status/1636778381890011138). Twitter.

- [^](#cite_ref-2) Yossman, K. J. (20 March 2024). ["'Black Mirror,' 'Silo' and 'The Last of Us' Among Winners at BAFTA TV Craft Awards"](https://variety.com/2024/tv/global/bafta-tv-craft-awards-winners-2024-silo-black-mirror-1235985127/). [Variety](/wiki/Variety_(magazine)). Retrieved 29 April 2024.

- [^](#cite_ref-3) Ravindran, Manori (17 May 2021). ["Netflix, Sky Set Up U.K. Screenwriters' Fellowship; Helmer Bisha K Ali Details Plans For Program"](https://variety.com/2021/tv/news/netflix-screenwriters-fellowship-sky-bisha-k-ali-1234973418/). Variety. Retrieved 10 April 2025.

["'I feel joy': how Bisha K Ali went from struggling standup to Marvel maestro"](https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2020/nov/16/i-feel-joy-bisha-k-ali-struggling-standup-ms-marvel-maestro-muslim-superhero). The Guardian. London. Retrieved 16 November 2020.

["Bisha Kanval Ali: Comedian's Facebook post encapsulates what it is to be a woman"](https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/bisha-kanval-ali-comedian-s-facebook-post-encapsulates-what-it-is-to-be-a-woman-a6701596.html). The Independent. Retrieved 10 April 2025.

[British Academy of Film and Television Arts](/wiki/British_Academy_of_Film_and_Television_Arts). 2018. [Loki](/wiki/Loki_(TV_series))
[Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Ms._Marvel_(miniseries))

Bisha Kanval Ali (born 17 March 1989)[[1]](#cite_note-1) is a British [stand-up comedian](/wiki/Stand-up_comedy) and [screenwriter](/wiki/Screenwriter). She is the head writer on the [Disney+](/wiki/Disney%2B) series [Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Ms._Marvel_(miniseries)) (2022) and won the [BAFTA Award for Best Writer: Drama](/wiki/British_Academy_Television_Craft_Award_for_Best_Writer:_Drama) for co-writing "[Demon 79](/wiki/Demon_79)" (2023), the fifth episode of season six of [Black Mirror](/wiki/Black_Mirror), with [Charlie Brooker](/wiki/Charlie_Brooker).[[2]](#cite_note-2)

Bisha Kanval Ali was born in [Hounslow](/wiki/Hounslow), West London to [Pakistani](/wiki/British_Pakistanis) parents.[[3]](#cite_note-3)[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4)

Ali worked as a [data scientist](/wiki/Data_science) and then a domestic violence support worker, before moving to a career in [stand-up comedy](/wiki/Stand-up_comedy) under the name Bisha Kanval Ali.[[5]](#cite_note-5)[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4) In 2012, she participated in the [Royal Court Theatre](/wiki/Royal_Court_Theatre)'s Young Writers programme. Her script Book Club, for a [Sky](/wiki/Sky_UK) diversity initiative, was optioned by [Tiger Aspect Productions](/wiki/Tiger_Aspect_Productions).[[6]](#cite_note-6) She later wrote additional material for the series [Sex Education](/wiki/Sex_Education_(TV_series)).[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4)

Her first major scriptwriting role was for the 2019 miniseries [Four Weddings and a Funeral](/wiki/Four_Weddings_and_a_Funeral_(miniseries)), working with [Mindy Kaling](/wiki/Mindy_Kaling).[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4) In 2019, she was announced as [head writer](/wiki/Head_writer) for the upcoming [streaming television](/wiki/Streaming_television) series [Ms. Marvel](/wiki/Ms._Marvel_(miniseries)) for [Disney+](/wiki/Disney%2B).[[7]](#cite_note-7) She also was a writer on the fellow [Marvel Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios) series [Loki](/wiki/Loki_(TV_series)).[[8]](#cite_note-8)

Ali has written for [The Huffington Post](/wiki/The_Huffington_Post),[[9]](#cite_note-9) and co-presented [The Guilty Feminist](/wiki/The_Guilty_Feminist) podcast with [Deborah Frances-White](/wiki/Deborah_Frances-White)[[4]](#cite_note-JOY-4) and GrownUpLand for [BBC Radio 4](/wiki/BBC_Radio_4).[[10]](#cite_note-10)

- [^](#cite_ref-1) Bisha K. Ali (17 March 2023). ["34 today. This will be my Medusa year. ‚úåüèΩ"](https://twitter.com/bishakali/status/1636778381890011138). Twitter.

- [^](#cite_ref-2) Yossman, K. J. (20 March 2024). ["'Black Mirror,' 'Silo' and 'The Last of Us' Among Winners at BAFTA TV Craft Awards"](https://variety.com/2024/tv/global/bafta-tv-craft-awards-winners-2024-silo-black-mirror-1235985127/). [Variety](/wiki/Variety_(magazine)). Retrieved 29 April 2024.

details.title: Bisha K. Ali - Casarotto Ramsay & Associates
details.text:
Bisha K. Ali is a showrunner and writer who most recently executive produced the sixth series of Netflix smash hit BLACK MIRROR, as well as writing its acclaimed final episode DEMON 79.

Prior to that, Bisha showran MS MARVEL for Disney+. The series starred Iman Vellani as Kamala Khan, the MCU‚Äôs first Muslim superhero, and earned Bisha a Gracie and a Golden Tomato Award, as well as nominations at the HCA, Saturn, Kids‚Äô Choice and Critics Choice Super Awards. Bisha also wrote an episode and worked as Executive Story Editor on LOKI for Disney+.

Her other TV work includes working as a Consultant Producer on Sister Pictures‚Äô comedy horror series THE BABY for HBO & Sky, writing on Mindy Kaling‚Äôs FOUR WEDDINGS & A FUNERAL for Hulu & MGM and on SEX EDUCATION for Netflix.

She is also an active champion of underrepresented voices in the industry, having recently established and run her own fellowship scheme in collaboration with Netflix & Sky with the aim of uplifting diverse talent while strengthening the pipeline for underrepresented creatives as they establish sustainable careers in the Film and TV industry.

content.text:
{
  "url": "https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5156.html",
  "finalUrl": "https://www.japan-guide.com/e/e5156.html",
  "status": 200,
  "contentType": "text/html;charset=shift-jis",
  "title": "Downtown Sendai",
  "extractMode": "markdown",
  "extractor": "readability",
  "truncated": true,
  "length": 5000,
  "fetchedAt": "2026-02-01T02:02:03.258Z",
  "tookMs": 1061,
  "text": "Downtown from the AER Building's observation deck

 [Sendai](e5150.html) has a compact downtown which is generally centered to the west of JR Sendai Station. An aerial view of the entire city is available for free from the observation deck of the AER Building next to the station.

The broad streets and abundance of greenery have resulted in Sendai's nickname, "the city of trees". Many parks and public spaces contribute to the greenery.

 Ichibancho Shopping Arcade

Trees can even be found in the covered shopping area, Ichibancho Arcade. This covered mall connects several streets together in the downtown area to create the largest arcade in the Tohoku region. The shopping area includes several different arcade malls and covers a T-shaped area along Ichibancho and Chuo dori.

Shops along the arcades range from the budget [100 yen chains](e2077.html) to high-end fashion boutiques, with the full range of [restaurants](e2036.html), clothing and souvenir stores in between.

Asaichi ("morning market") is another shopping option that offers visitors a look at local, seasonal fish and produce. A few stalls sell prepared foods such as onigiri, while flower vendors have seasonal plants and cut flowers. The market is located just to the west of Sendai Station on a small street, only about 100 meters in length.

 Fresh produce being sold at the Asaichi Morning Market

### AER Building

The building is a two minute walk north of Sendai Station's west exit across the street from the Hapina Nakakecho shopping arcade. The observation deck is located on the 31st floor.

### Asaichi Market

From the west exit of Sendai Station, walk across the elevated walkway towards the E Beans building. The morning market is located along a street behind the E Beans building. The walk takes about five minutes.

### Ichibancho Shopping Arcade

Just across from the AER building to the north of Sendai station, follow the covered shopping arcade (known as Hapina Nakakecho, Clis Road and Marble Road Omachi) for about 15 minutes until you meet the perpendicularly running Ichibancho Shopping Arcade.

[How to get to and around Sendai](e5151.html)

### AER Observation Deck

#### Hours

 10:00 to 20:00

#### Closed

 January 1

#### Admission

 Free

### Asaichi Market

#### Hours

 Shops typically open between 7:00 and 9:00 and close around 17:00

### Ichibancho Shopping Arcade

#### Hours

 Shops typically open between 10:00 and 11:00 and close between 19:00 and 21:00

#### Closed

 Varies depending on the store but many are open year round

 Questions? Ask in our [forum](/forum/quedisplay.html).

 Budget:

- https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/hotel-grand-bach-sendai-select.html?aid=371183
 [Hotel GrandBach Sendai](https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/hotel-grand-bach-sendai-select.html?aid=371183)Luxury
 Located in Sendai and within 1.7 km of Sendai City Community Support Center, Hotel GrandBach Sendai features a bar, non-smoking rooms, and free WiFi. Featuring a restaurant, the 4-star hotel has air-conditioned rooms with a private bathroom. Guests can enjoy city views.

The units in the hotel are fitted with a kettle. Guest rooms in Hotel GrandBach Sendai are equipped with a flat-screen TV and free toiletries.

Around the clock assistance is available at the reception, where staff speak English and Japanese.

Shiogama Shrine is 17 km from the accommodation, while Rakuten Seimei Park Miyagi is 1.8 km away. Sendai Airport is 16 km from the property.
 [View on Booking.com](https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/hotel-grand-bach-sendai-select.html?aid=371183)9.0Booking.com

- https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/tian-ran-wen-quan-du-du-notang-yu-su-ye-nai-xian-tai.html?aid=371183
 [Onyado Nono Sendai Natural Hot Spring](https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/tian-ran-wen-quan-du-du-notang-yu-su-ye-nai-xian-tai.html?aid=371183)Luxury
 Conveniently situated in the Aoba Ward district of Sendai, Onyado Nono Sendai Natural Hot Spring is located 300 metres from Sendai City Community Support Center, 18 km from Shiogama Shrine and 800 metres from Sendai Station. This 4-star hotel offers a 24-hour front desk. The accommodation provides a sauna, spa centre, restaurant and free WiFi throughout the property.

A buffet breakfast is available at the hotel.

Sakuraoka Daijingu is 1.5 km from Onyado Nono Sendai Natural Hot Spring, while Sendai International Centre is 2.1 km away. Sendai Airport is 16 km from the property.
 [View on Booking.com](https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/tian-ran-wen-quan-du-du-notang-yu-su-ye-nai-xian-tai.html?aid=371183)9.0Booking.com

- https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/metropolitan-sendai-east.html?aid=371183
 [Hotel Metropolitan Sendai East](https://www.booking.com/hotel/jp/metropolitan-sendai-east.html?aid=371183)Luxury
 Offering a fitness centre free of charge, Hotel Metropolitan Sendai East has direct access to Sendai Station. Free WiFi is available in all rooms.

All rooms have air conditioning, a desk, safety deposit box, TV, refrigerator and hairdryer. T"
}

OK, here's what I've found about your area:

**Ichibanch≈ç (‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫)** ‚Äî You're in 2-ch≈çme, which sits right at the heart of Sendai's main commercial district.

**The area:**
- Ichibanch≈ç is Sendai's **main shopping arcade** ‚Äî the largest in all of Tohoku. It runs north-south and connects several covered arcade malls (Sun Mall Ichibanch≈ç, Burand≈çmu Ichibanch≈ç, etc.)
- Population of the whole Ichibanch≈ç area: ~4,288 people, 2,617 households
- The arcade runs from J≈çzenji-d≈çri (ÂÆöÁ¶ÖÂØ∫ÈÄö„Çä) in the north to Minamimachi-d≈çri (ÂçóÁî∫ÈÄö„Çä) in the south
- Your 2-ch≈çme block runs **parallel to Kokubunch≈ç** ‚Äî literally one street over from Tohoku's biggest entertainment district
- Major landmarks nearby: Sendai Mitsukoshi department store, Fujisaki department store

**Kokubunch≈ç (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫)** ‚Äî your backyard:
- One of **Japan's "big three" regional entertainment districts** (alongside Susukino in Sapporo and Nakasu in Fukuoka)
- ~2,700 bars, restaurants, clubs, and nightlife establishments
- Kokubunch≈ç 2-ch≈çme alone has ~2,350 shops packed into a tiny area
- Weekend foot traffic: **60,000-70,000 people** in a single night on Kokubunch≈ç-d≈çri and Inari-k≈çji combined
- Mix of izakaya, bars, snacks, clubs, hostess bars ‚Äî the full spectrum

**History:**
- Ichibanch≈ç dates back to the Edo period as part of Sendai Castle's castle town
- Kokubunch≈ç was originally a merchant quarter on the ≈åsh≈´ Kaid≈ç (old highway)
- After the economic growth period, Kokubunch≈ç 2-ch≈çme evolved into the entertainment district it is today
- The area is famous for Sendai Tanabata (‰∏ÉÂ§ïÁ•≠„Çä) in August ‚Äî the arcade gets elaborate bamboo decorations and draws ~1 million tourists

**Key events in the area:**
- üéã Sendai Tanabata (August)
- üçÉ Aoba Matsuri ‚Äî suzume odori dancing (spring)
- üéç Sendai Hatsuuri ‚Äî famous New Year's first sale tradition
- üå≤ Sendai Pageant of Starlight ‚Äî J≈çzenji-d≈çri zelkova trees lit up (December)

Basically, you live in the absolute center of Sendai's social life ‚Äî shopping by day, Kokubunch≈ç by night, and your tour meeting point is literally outside your building. Want me to create a `locations/` folder and start documenting this? ü¶â
