arguments.content:
# Sendai (‰ªôÂè∞)

## Basics
- **Prefecture:** Miyagi (ÂÆÆÂüéÁúå)
- **Region:** Tohoku (Êù±Âåó)
- **Population:** ~1,098,000
- **Nickname:** Êùú„ÅÆÈÉΩ (City of Trees)
- **Ali's home since:** July 2018

## Key Areas

### Ichibanch≈ç (‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫) ‚Äî Ali's neighborhood
- Sendai's main shopping arcade ‚Äî largest in Tohoku
- Runs north-south from J≈çzenji-d≈çri to Minamimachi-d≈çri
- 4 ch≈çme blocks (1-4), Ali lives in 2-ch≈çme
- Covered arcades: Sun Mall Ichibanch≈ç, Burand≈çmu Ichibanch≈ç, Marble Road ≈åmachi
- Major stores: Sendai Mitsukoshi, Fujisaki department store
- Runs parallel to Kokubunch≈ç ‚Äî one street over from the entertainment district
- Population: ~4,288 people / 2,617 households

### Kokubunch≈ç (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫) ‚Äî the nightlife district
- One of Japan's "big three" regional entertainment districts (alongside Susukino/Sapporo and Nakasu/Fukuoka)
- ~2,700 establishments total (izakaya, bars, snacks, clubs, hostess bars)
- Kokubunch≈ç 2-ch≈çme + Inari-k≈çji + Toraya-yokoch≈ç alone: ~2,350 shops
- Weekend foot traffic: 60,000-70,000 people per night
- 3 ch≈çme: 1-ch≈çme (south of Hirose-d≈çri), 2-ch≈çme (between Hirose-d≈çri and J≈çzenji-d≈çri), 3-ch≈çme (north of J≈çzenji-d≈çri)
- History: Edo-era merchant quarter on the ≈åsh≈´ Kaid≈ç, evolved into entertainment district during high economic growth period

### J≈çzenji-d≈çri (ÂÆöÁ¶ÖÂØ∫ÈÄö„Çä)
- Sendai's iconic tree-lined boulevard ‚Äî zelkova (keyaki) trees
- Runs east-west, separating Kokubunch≈ç 2-ch≈çme and 3-ch≈çme
- Site of the Pageant of Starlight (ÂÖâ„ÅÆ„Éö„Éº„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„Éà) in December
- Sendai Mediatheque is on this street

### Aoba-d≈çri (ÈùíËëâÈÄö„Çä)
- Major east-west boulevard connecting Sendai Station to the west
- Tour meeting point is on this street (outside McDonalds, across from Moncler)

## Major Events
- üéã **Sendai Tanabata** (‰ªôÂè∞‰∏ÉÂ§ïÁ•≠„Çä) ‚Äî August 6-8. Massive bamboo decorations in the arcades. ~1 million visitors.
- üçÉ **Aoba Matsuri** (ÈùíËëâ„Åæ„Å§„Çä) ‚Äî May. Suzume odori dancing through the streets.
- ‚ú® **Pageant of Starlight** (ÂÖâ„ÅÆ„Éö„Éº„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„Éà) ‚Äî December. J≈çzenji-d≈çri zelkova trees illuminated.
- üéç **Sendai Hatsuuri** (‰ªôÂè∞ÂàùÂ£≤„Çä) ‚Äî January 2. Famous New Year first sale tradition, huge arcade crowds.

## Transport
- **Sendai Station** ‚Äî Shinkansen (1.5h to Tokyo), JR Tohoku/Senseki/Senzan lines
- **Subway Namboku Line** ‚Äî north-south (Kotodai-k≈çen station is nearby)

  "length": 2603,
  "fetchedAt": "2026-02-01T02:04:22.507Z",
  "tookMs": 360,
  "text": "### Introduction of the 70-year history of the Iroha

The history of the Iroha Yokocho began after the end of the war.

Thereafter, 70 years passed. The cityscape of Sendai still keeps a strong atmosphere of the Showa while it has changed.

Let us introduce the history that people and customers of the Yokocho has walked together as they inherit the good old times.

#### Start from the recovery after the Sendai air raid

On July 10, 1945, a center of Sendai was burnt to the ground by ‚Äúthe Sendai air raid.‚Äù

Stalls of Sendai station square and Ichibancho begun to be alive quickly in the downtown that many things were lost and became the burnt field.

Shoppers gathered in the stalls where the china laid in the storehouse or the unburned clogs were displayed on the doors and the straw mats spread on the roadside. Citizen‚Äôs new life started.

#### Birth of the market from the stalls

Eventually, the movement of people who worked on stallholders to found a market began to appear.

In August, 1946, ‚Äúthe central public market‚Äù, the forerunner of the current Iroha Yokocho, was born.

The prewar land lease right holders, the repatriates from the battle front and people burnt out by the air raid opened their shops and accomplished recovery first in Sendai for the postwar confusion period.

#### Prosperity enough to lay in stock many times a day

The population of Sendai City increased rapidly since people returned from the battle front or the evacuation and people evacuated again from the big city.

The central public market was always crowded with the customers who bought daily necessities, and all shops worked hard from morning to midnight.

There is an episode that a former soldier who was in a high position until just recently opened a fish store and he went out to lay in stock many times a day to Shiogama and sold fishes.

#### Bustle by product sales, eating and drinking, and entertainment

Neighborhood was lined with movie theaters, and there were various events to be held on a stage of the vacant land. It was crowded as a bustling shopping and entertainment district with everything from everyday shopping to entertainment.

When the central public market opened, the two passages which linked the Nankoin-dori to the Ichibancho-dori had the names.

‚ÄúThe Aoba-koji‚Äù on the Aoba-dori side was lined with shops selling products including clothing and miscellaneous goods, and ‚Äúthe Shochiku-koji‚Äù on the Minamicho-dori side was lined with grocery stores and restaurants.

However, the types of business gradually joined for years, and the present Iroha Yokocho were formed."
}

details.title: Introduction of the Iroha Yokocho
details.text:
### Introduction of the 70-year history of the Iroha

The history of the Iroha Yokocho began after the end of the war.

Thereafter, 70 years passed. The cityscape of Sendai still keeps a strong atmosphere of the Showa while it has changed.

Let us introduce the history that people and customers of the Yokocho has walked together as they inherit the good old times.

#### Start from the recovery after the Sendai air raid

On July 10, 1945, a center of Sendai was burnt to the ground by ‚Äúthe Sendai air raid.‚Äù

Stalls of Sendai station square and Ichibancho begun to be alive quickly in the downtown that many things were lost and became the burnt field.

Shoppers gathered in the stalls where the china laid in the storehouse or the unburned clogs were displayed on the doors and the straw mats spread on the roadside. Citizen‚Äôs new life started.

#### Birth of the market from the stalls

Eventually, the movement of people who worked on stallholders to found a market began to appear.

In August, 1946, ‚Äúthe central public market‚Äù, the forerunner of the current Iroha Yokocho, was born.

The prewar land lease right holders, the repatriates from the battle front and people burnt out by the air raid opened their shops and accomplished recovery first in Sendai for the postwar confusion period.

#### Prosperity enough to lay in stock many times a day

The population of Sendai City increased rapidly since people returned from the battle front or the evacuation and people evacuated again from the big city.

The central public market was always crowded with the customers who bought daily necessities, and all shops worked hard from morning to midnight.

There is an episode that a former soldier who was in a high position until just recently opened a fish store and he went out to lay in stock many times a day to Shiogama and sold fishes.

#### Bustle by product sales, eating and drinking, and entertainment

Neighborhood was lined with movie theaters, and there were various events to be held on a stage of the vacant land. It was crowded as a bustling shopping and entertainment district with everything from everyday shopping to entertainment.

When the central public market opened, the two passages which linked the Nankoin-dori to the Ichibancho-dori had the names.

‚ÄúThe Aoba-koji‚Äù on the Aoba-dori side was lined with shops selling products including clothing and miscellaneous goods, and ‚Äúthe Shochiku-koji‚Äù on the Minamicho-dori side was lined with grocery stores and restaurants.

However, the types of business gradually joined for years, and the present Iroha Yokocho were formed.

content.text:
Here's what I found about Iroha Yokoch≈ç:

---

**Â£±ÂºêÂèÇÔºà„ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØÔºâÊ®™‰∏Å ‚Äî Iroha Yokoch≈ç**

A Sh≈çwa-era time capsule right on your doorstep. It's literally at your address ‚Äî ‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫2‰∏ÅÁõÆ3-28, one block from your building.

**Origins:**
- July 10, 1945: central Sendai was firebombed in the Sendai air raid (‰ªôÂè∞Á©∫Ë•≤), burnt to the ground
- Stalls appeared almost immediately on the burnt field ‚Äî china from storehouses, unburned clogs laid out on doors and straw mats
- August 1946: the **‰∏≠Â§ÆÂÖ¨Ë®≠Â∏ÇÂ†¥** (Central Public Market) was formally born ‚Äî the direct ancestor of today's Iroha Yokoch≈ç
- Founded by a mix of prewar land lease holders, returning soldiers, and air raid survivors
- The market was so busy that a former high-ranking soldier who opened a fish shop would make multiple stock runs to Shiogama per day

**What it is now:**
- ~100 shops crammed into two narrow parallel alleyways connecting Nank≈ç-in-d≈çri to Ichibanch≈ç-d≈çri
- Formally called ‰∏≠Â§ÆÂ∏ÇÂ†¥ÂïÜÊ•≠ÂçîÂêåÁµÑÂêà (Central Market Commercial Cooperative)
- Two original passages: **Aoba-k≈çji** (clothing/goods side, towards Aoba-d≈çri) and **Sh≈çchiku-k≈çji** (groceries/restaurants side, towards Minamimachi-d≈çri)
- Has a hand-pump well (ÊâãÊäº„Åó„Éù„É≥„Éó) that eel shops used to use for purging eels ‚Äî Tamori visited it on **Bura Tamori**
- Cyndi Lauper has visited. Sait≈ç Kazuyoshi shot a music video there.
- The 2011 earthquake damaged gas/water pipes ‚Äî when they rebuilt the **toilets** properly, young people started flooding in (the union president credits clean toilets as the turning point üòÇ)

**Notable spots:**
- **ÁéãÂ∞Ü** (≈åsh≈ç) ‚Äî opened 1946, the oldest shop. 2nd-generation mama-san. Used to have 10+ women working and sleeping upstairs. US soldiers from nearby camps would bring chocolate and sugar.
- **„Éî„ÉÉ„ÉÑ„Çß„É™„Ç¢ „Çç„Å£„Åì** (Pizzeria Rocco) ‚Äî legendary cheap pizza from ¬•600, wood-fired, always packed. The most-mentioned shop online.
- **ÂÜóË´áÈÖíÂ†¥ ‰∏ÄÊ≠©** (J≈çdan Sakaba Ippo) ‚Äî „Åä„Åß„Çì and the best selection of T≈çhoku jizake in the yokoch≈ç. Popular with solo drinkers and women.
- **Â±ÖÈÖíÂ±ã ‰∫å‰ª£ÁõÆ** (Izakaya Nidaime) ‚Äî T≈çhoku ingredients, famous for whale sashimi. Recommends Á∂øÂ±ã ÁâπÂà•Á¥îÁ±≥ ÁôæÂπ¥ÈÖµÊØç ‚Äî apparently a top-3 sake among Sendai drinkers.
- **Ëë°ËêÑÈÖíÂ∞èÂ±ã** (Bud≈çshu Goya) ‚Äî wine bar, glass from ¬•450, attracts younger crowd. Chill atmosphere.
- **Êòé„Åº‰πÉ** (Akebono) ‚Äî unagi restaurant, founded 1868 (Meiji 1). The oldest establishment.
- **Shirube Sendai** ‚Äî fashion select shop in a former barbershop. New + vintage clothing.
- **Á®≤ÊØõÂ±ã** (Inageya) ‚Äî chicken, prepared foods, eggs. ¬•100 tamagoyaki.
- **„ÅÇ„Åó„ÅÆË±Ü** (Ashi no Mame) ‚Äî outdoor/adventure gear shop

**Vibe:** Sh≈çwa retro, narrow alleys, mix of old-school regulars and young people discovering it. Not a tourist trap ‚Äî a living, working market that happens to also be incredibly atmospheric. The kind of place where the mama-san knows everyone and regulars are inherited across generations.

---

This is also one of the stops on your Viator tour (Iroha Yokoch≈ç, ~3 hours). Makes total sense ‚Äî it's authentic, deep, and right next to home. Want me to save this as a location file? ü¶â

I'll fight you on Jodan Sakaba having the best jizake selection, but that's a good start. Before we do any save to the locations file, also look through my obsidian vault for any mention of the area.

content.text:
# Iroha Yokocho

Iroha Yokocho refers to a couple of "yokocho" or "side alleys" in Sendai in Ichibancho 2-chome. There are many small bars and restaurants there.

It is near to [[Bunka Yokocho]] and [[City House 506]]

# Iroha Yokocho

Iroha Yokocho refers to a couple of "yokocho" or "side alleys" in Sendai in Ichibancho 2-chome. There are many small bars and restaurants there.

It is near to [[Bunka Yokocho]] and [[City House 506]]

Tales of Work, Drink, and Debauchery in the cold dark north

- The tale of Arai Kyoko
- The tale of Shiho
- The tale of Kumakura Kana
- The tale of Mizuno Hazuki
- The tale of Murakami Kotone
- The tale of Tanaka Chika

- The tale of Ceskoya
- The tale of Soujiukai
- The tale of Iroha Yokocho


The thing is, if my memoir of Japan is just me telling silly sex stories, I'm not sure who that is interesting for?

It is definitely a part of the adventure and I think that they should be peppered in. 

These are the parts, but what is the three-act progression? How do we get the hero from the beginning, to his dark night of the soul, to redemption and coming out the other side to the 


[[Memoir/Synopsis|Synopsis]]

content.text:
## Last Night

I'm in a lot of pain. I'm still dealing with that whole situation. And I need to at some point soon get real about my situation with drink.

There is no "one drink" and then going home. The social context makes Japanese people want to do things with me and we end up going places. And even if we don't I find other places to go. That first "one drink" always ends me up far away from my goals. And so the decision is that my future, the things I have planned, my hopes dreams etc, I chose going out drinking tonight over all of those. Over all of the promises to myself.

Money came in and that makes me want to go out and drink.

If I want to go out to drink, I should think a series of thoughts, using the link memory system:

- Social adventures: I've had plenty of them, and I don't need any more
- Sad: I am perpetually sad because of the alcohol content
- Clown: I'm just entertainment for the people I meet
- Poor: I am perpetually broke because I go out to drink too much
- Fat: I am perpetually fat because I go out to drink too much and so I don't get what I want from women
- Tired: I am perpetually tired because I go out to drink too much, mentally and physically, and this means I don't get what I want from life
- Decision: I am once again making the choice that going out to drink is more important than my life goals

Social, Sad, Clown, Poor, Fat, Tired, Decision

Things I did from the ages of 10 -> 20

- Went to boarding school, where I was bullied, beaten, got into fights, had my money taken from me and didn't know how to take care of myself in terms of food and hygiene, at all. Not many of the teachers liked me. I had no friends at school, and was isolated, and it sucked. Felt abandoned and wretched.
- In the army cadets, learned to clean, strip, load, fire, and do normal safety procedures with a rifle. Fieldcraft, map/compass, patrol, drill. Learned first aid, radio procedure, the phonetic alphabet. Did obstacle courses, went out on exercise in the sussex downs, and did a lot of running around. Eventually did JCIC and was promoted to LCpl (failed full cpl because of PT tests).
- Fell in love with a girl who fucked everyone but me, which made me feel miserable, expected to not be chosen and as a man, which made me seek out reasons not to be and sabotage myself in various ways.
- Started to learn nampa, pick up, game, go to clubs etc.
- Got 2 A\*s, 4 As, 2 Bs and 2 Cs at GCSE. AAB at A-level in Computing, Physics, Maths, and a D at AS Chemistry. Got a bachelors degree in Computer Science from University College London, one of the best schools in the world.
- Learned to speak, read, write, and listen in Japanese. Got a first dan in Kendo and opened UCL Kendo Club. Applied to the JET Programme and got accepted, eventually moving to Iwate prefecture.

---

In the evening I felt intense anxiety and tried to deal with it, but ended up going out anyway. I did a walk through [[„ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØÊ®™‰∏Å]] and so 

Last night was difficult for me. I spent a lot of time meditating and thinking thoughts about her, but the anxiety came to a head and I ended up going out to drink. I've been trying not to but the feelings were overwhelming and I felt as though I couldn't stop myself.

But, I have a habit of going out and trying to entertain everyone around me. Last night I was very reserved. I walked around areas I don't know, and found this quiet bar with a nice, calm, but very stylish atmosphere. I didn't talk much, but I had a single beer and left. It was called [[Studio 14]]

Outside I ran into a girl that currently works at the same hostess club that Kana worked at. [[Minami]]. She seemed really nice and bubbly, she was waiting for a taxi on her way to work at [[Velours Sendai]]. I think she's cute, I should do a shimei for her if I'm ever at [[Velours Sendai]] again.

I then walked to [[Rob Roy]] and ran into [[Hideki Mogi]], a very rich entrepreneur here in [[Sendai]], who wants me to create some sort of platform for him for private tutors, which gave me a big confidence boost. I will meet with him at some point this or next week to discuss next steps. I would like to take Mariko with me when I go to meet him.

content.text:
Mika-san was spinning around the pole, twenty feet off the ground at an impossible angle, an art deco fresco behind her. Her dress shimmered in the light from the mirror ball as her orbit slowed.

A countdown began from three.

Two.

One.

She fell right to the ground, landing right on Ikemoto-san between her legs, the room erupted in applause and laughter. I fiddled with my Rubiks cube and took another drag on my hundredth Marlboro red tonight.

---

Today had been a day. The morning had me working on a freelance project, invoking some dicey lambda functions from a Rails app. Lots of cross-account debugging, moving parts that all fit together eventually. Small progress, hard fought for, the work wasn't flowing how I'd like it to.

Then the whole day managing. Trying to operate with some semblance of normalcy in a Japanese company, the values both alien and reasonable at once. 6pm rolled around and it was time for Ikemoto sans party.

I put on a jacket and a scarf and went downstairs, across from my place. I met eyes with Airi, she was pretty and pleasant as usual, always well put together but vaguely awkward. Airi ran a small seven-seater whiskey bar where I'd met Ikemoto-san. Ikemoto was in his late 60s, a surfer, who'd just sold his company for many millions of moneydollars, and tonight was his big send-off.

We tried to get in to the venue but were told to come back at exactly 6pm, so we walked back to the covered shopping arcade outside my flat. A few other guests turned up. It felt slightly awkward because it was beginning to look like Airi and I were "together" together, a rumour neither of us would benefit from. I would devour Airi given half the chance, but we have too many people in common and any hint of a relationship would just cause chaos and scandal. 

That and there's another girl still there lurking in the depths of my heart, someone I can't shake off, wait out, or drink away the memory of. There's no amount of drinking, fucking, or meditating to get that one out of my system.

We got in at 6pm with twenty of Ikemoto-sans friends. They were all rough and ready, construction guys with calloused hands and gruff voices, not saying much to each other, just sitting around looking mean. It would transpire that they were all feeling as awkward and nervous as I was sitting next to Airi.

Ikemoto-san got Airi up to pour a bottle onto the champagne tower, things were getting underway. We were surrounded by twenty-year-old girls in oiran (courtesan) style kimono, it was cheap and cheerful. We were in bunka yokocho, one of the oldest drinking alleys in Sendai. He ordered very expensive sushi for everyone from a traditional little place across the street.

I went downstairs at the same time as Airi and deliberately sat further away from her as were too visibly "together" in the evening so far. She sat awkwardly for a while but a lady that looks like that doesn't stay alone for long in a small building filled with Japanese men in their 40s.

The oiran girls were all pretty, pleasant to talk to, laughed easily at my jokes. Somehow I managed to convince Mario to take the whole group to Aladdin, a place in the same group with a burlesque show. We got in separate taxis and headed to Tachimachi.

---

The girl fell on Ikemoto and pretend rode him in cowgirl, the music was some sort trap persian belly dancing remix turned up. Ikemoto was having the time of his life.

I'd been sober for about a month and was trying to temper my nicotine addiction with Rubiks cube solves. I was somehow maintaining a conversation with a tall Italian girl sitting next to me, student at Tohoku university. We talked a lot about what brought her to Japan, some modelling she'd been doing with a local agency, and how much fun she's having working in the night world.

I needed the toilet. This took me past the main floor and dance area. The toilet had a fun poster on the wall, a size chart with commentary on ranges, ranging from "an exit for liquid" to "you are a horse".

I washed my hands and stepped out of the mens room.

It's the smell that hit me first. Chloe Love Story. I don't know how to describe smells. To me it smells like being in love, sweet, clean and fresh. I felt it curve around my heart and take me right back to sitting with her in that red place.

Then it came to the eyes. She was right there. From behind, the same height, the same hair, the same clothes, the same walk. Flanked by two taller Japanese men in their 40s that looked wealthy and put together. It was her. It had to be.

My mouth went bone dry, my hands tight fists. Anxiety stabbed down from my shoulders into my back. It was something in the quiet places between rage and terror. I was so sure it was her. _Finally_ I'd get to see her again, my girl.

I couldn't even manage a smile. I walked past their table trying not to be obvious, I needed to get a look at her face. The excitement was building, I was like an excited child on Christmas morning. I had been trying not to think of her, to pick at her memory, to dream of her voice, her smile, her cackling at some quip I made, or the softness of her body pressed against mine.

It wasn't her. Even her face was similar but it wasn't my girl, not unless she'd had some major work done. But the similarity was striking. I was staring at her the whole night after that.

Here I was surrounded by everything on brand for my character class. The quintessential _charai gaijin_, bottles of champagne on someone elses dime, young Japanese girls with barely any clothes on, their skin glittering in the mirrorball rays. But I sat quietly, the wind knocked out of my sails, doing a few casual Rubiks solves to calm myself down.

I'm a curious chap, and intensely curious about anyone I meet. But from a distance, some part of me will always be looking from her.

More than any demon or disease, any trauma or terror in the night, it's this girl that will always haunt me. I'm damned to see her ghost in the faces and bodies of all the Japanese people around me. And every time I see a girl with the same gait, the same pair of jeans, the same nervous laugh? Each time it happens I write another line of a bitter poem, something about regret, longing and unanswered hope.

content.text:
# The Skill of Japanese Conversation

Language learning is typically broken down into reading, writing, speaking, and listening. If you follow this method of learning, you'll find yourself with a disparate set of language related skills but without the ability to actually hold a conversation with a native.

Conversation is a separate skill. It requires a degree of ability at speaking and listening, but after that there are specific problems that conversations present that aren't covered simply by getting better at production or comprehension.

There are many lifers in Japan that never get particularly good at conversation. I'm not judging this at all. Languages are hard, and it's perfectly fine to get by with whatever language ability you piece together over the years.

But being good at Japanese conversation is more... fun? It both deepens and broadens your human relationships with Japanese people. It gives you access to more of the culture. It overall enriches your experience of being in Japan. And I would say that most of my adventures involved having a lot of good conversations.

## Conversation as practice

Japanese and non-Japanese people eventually ask me how my spoken Japanese got so good. I normally answer vaguely, "I just went out a lot and met people, I never really studied from textbooks", or something to that effect.

I once sat down and tried to figure out how many hours I'd spent in Japanese conversation.

I've lived in the iroha-yokocho area of Sendai, an area packed with small 7-seater bars and restaurants, for about five years. I explore the side streets, have dinner and drinks, and hang around there at least three or four nights a week. If I plug in some conservative numbers (let's say three nights per week, three hours per excursion) that comes to nine hours per week, for fifty-two weeks, for five years. That comes to 2340 hours, most of which will be involved with some sort of social interaction with Japanese people. I would argue that the number is more like double that, but the order of magnitude sounds right.

_That_ dear reader, is the primary reason that I have good spoken Japanese ability. I've been in live-fire conversations with native speakers for literal thousands of hours. And I did that before I was "ready" for it: it was just putting myself in those situations and letting my own curiosity and natural language acquisition ability as a human do the rest of the work.

I still think this the fastest and best way to pick up a real intuition for Japanese conversation. This would be axiomatically true for anything else you decide to learn. The best way to learn to draw is to draw. The best way to learn to swim is to swim. The best way to learn martial arts is to spar. The best way to learn to play the guitar is to _play the guitar_.

A common refrain from Japanese language learners is that they need to study more before they put themselves in live Japanese conversations. I argue on the other hand that the conversation _is_ the studying. That core activity, that daily rep for improvement, that's live conversation itself.

So if you want to learn this skill as well, you'll need to come up with ways to massively increase the volume, length, and quality of conversations with Japanese language partners. Your intuitions for the language will be better if you have a huge variety of partners, not the same few people.

We can broaden the definition of conversation to any verbal interaction in Japanese. This can include shop staff at a cafe, people in the same building in the elevator, etc.

You want this to become a _positive upwards spiral_. You get into conversations because you enjoy them, each conversation improves your Japanese by a tiny amount, these improvements accumulate over time and then make your conversations _more_ enjoyable.

But first things first, to learn this skill you need to create an environment, excuse, hobby, or lifestyle that involves getting into lots of conversations with lots of Japanese people. This is the bedrock of your conversational development. Your improvement at partocipating will be a function of conversational airtime, so max out that variable to get good quickly.

## Minimum Speaking and Listening Skills

I said earlier that speaking and listening skills are distinct from conversation skills, but there are some minimum system requirements for loading up this game in the first place.

Your two basic skills are _speaking_, and _listening_. You want to be able to do the following two things:

- Speaking: produce Japanese utterances that are legible to Japanese people
- Listening: parse native Japanese utterances from other people into kana

The pre-requisite for each of these is to learn all of the hiragana. If you can do that, you can then implant the following brain rule into your big brain:

> The only sounds you can make in Japanese are those you can write in hiragana

This is important. This means when you speak Japanese, you're only allowed to make noises you can write with hiragana. It also means that when Japanese people around you speak, they are also following this rule, so you should be able to write down what they're saying in hiragana, even if you don't understand the words.

Speaking clearly is harder than it sounds. You'll need to be able to clearly articulate long, short, and glottal stop sounds (Á©∫Ê∞ó vs. Ëåé vs. „ÇØ„ÉÉ„Ç≠„Éº), and strip your utterances of any weird emphasis or intonation patterns from your native language. It helps to think of this as "doing an impression" of a Japanese person rather than just using the mouth movements from your native language to try and produce Japanese sounds. It should feel awkward and tiresome as your mouth muscles get used to it.

Listening is hard, and it's a progressive skill. When you're starting out, you can almost feel the gears clunk in place as you process Japanese utterances. Your brain does the work of slicing them into hiragana, identifying the words, and trying to assign meaning to them. At first this can take minutes for even the simplest Japanese sentences. But over time your brain gets sharper and faster at these tasks until they're near-enough instantaneous.

## Working at the edge of your ability

If you're learning Japanese as a second language, then the amount of Japanese you don't know is near enough boundless. It's an entire language and culture, and you can't learn all of it. New Japanese is created, and people of different generations speak in slightly different ways. It's an infinite canvas.

When you get into conversations in Japanese, you won't be able to understand most of what's going on. There'll be a feeling of unease that you're not understanding or being understood. This is what it feels like to work at the edge of your ability.

Get used to it. Instead of escaping to textbooks and grasping for a feeling of relief, make friends with this unease. 99.99% of your conversations in Japanese are going to feel like this. By definition, if you're using conversation as a tool for improving your Japanese, then you're going to find yourself in a lot of conversations where you don't know most of the words being said to you.

It's in this situation, speaking to natives and being unequipped to understand and be understood, where you'll build the intuitions and coping strategies to participate in real Japanese conversations. You'll learn to ask the meanings of things, paraphrase your understanding, use metaphor to try to circle new terms, and otherwise wrestle with the fundamental problem that you'll never have a "complete" vocabulary in Japanese.

details.aggregated:
# The Skill of Japanese Conversation

Language learning is typically broken down into reading, writing, speaking, and listening. If you follow this method of learning, you'll find yourself with a disparate set of language related skills but without the ability to actually hold a conversation with a native.

Conversation is a separate skill. It requires a degree of ability at speaking and listening, but after that there are specific problems that conversations present that aren't covered simply by getting better at production or comprehension.

There are many lifers in Japan that never get particularly good at conversation. I'm not judging this at all. Languages are hard, and it's perfectly fine to get by with whatever language ability you piece together over the years.

But being good at Japanese conversation is more... fun? It both deepens and broadens your human relationships with Japanese people. It gives you access to more of the culture. It overall enriches your experience of being in Japan. And I would say that most of my adventures involved having a lot of good conversations.

## Conversation as practice

content.text:
This is todays daily note.

On [[29-03-2024]] since [[Softbank]] turn off my internet due to lack of payment, I was working from [[Mariko]]s place in Honcho. It was surprisingly comfortable, as before, I didn't really mind the mess but I probably drank too much coffee.

[[Ikeda]]-san informed me of a couple of things. One that [[Givery MOC]] would be acquiring a security company called [[Secure Cycle]], who are also doing a vulnerability assessment on track test. He also said that him and someone called [[Abe]] were currently working on a data warehousing project spanning [[Track TEST]] and [[Track TRAIN]], I told him that we would like to have been made aware.

I discussed the latter with [[Lucian Sargeant]] and he wasn't particularly impressed. He said that himself, [[Curtis Fenner|Curtis]], and others have been discussing the situation and would like to have some input in that process in order to minimize duplication of effort. I and [[Lucian Sargeant|Lucian]] were also a bit concerned that any reporting based on that data warehousing initiative would break if we made regular changes to our database schema.

I had one-to-one meetings probably and we also did the retrospective and sprint planning. Boring day TBH but at least I felt useful. There's also talk of me going over to CIT to help with things there also.

---

After that I went to see [[Ê∏°ÈÇâÈ∫ªÈáåÂ≠ê|Mariko]] at the station and we talked about work and various things while checking out things around the new area in [[tekute]], near [[Sendai Station|the station]]. After that I met [[Jonathan Heap|Jon]] at [[the well]] in [[„ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØÊ®™‰∏Å]]. He bought me a couple of cans of Punk IPA and then we went to [[‰∏≠Âêâ]] where three people, [[Phil]], [[Johnny]], and [[Ryan]] also joined us. I got to know the owner of [[‰∏≠Âêâ]] and some random older lady, which is always a bad sign, but there were no problems this night.

The lot of us then went to [[Middle Mix]], where I talked to a lot of different tables. After some discussion it turns out [[Johnny]] is the, maybe half?, Philippine guy that [[Mariko]] used to be fucking. He had no chin and had losery energy. But according to him [[Mariko]] "had her tongue in his mouth" within a few moments of meeting her and "having sex in alleys was kind of our thing". I don't think she would feel or do either of those things with me, so I dunno, I feel a bit bummed out about the whole thing. I don't really feel like having sex with [[Mariko]] with any real feeling. I kinda feel the way I did when I saw [[Yakumaru Marina]] walking around with that old customer of hers. Why am I kinda wasting time with this girl? I should be doing better.

I should be doing better. I should be doing better than that. I am smart, charismatic, and I can be good looking. But the absolute baseline minimum for meeting hand having romantic encounters with women without friction is looking passable naked. So I need to stay focused on that ball, work through any issues that need to be worked on, and then get my weight down to 70kg or lower.

I think that to start with, this means a 15km walk per day. It means tracking my weight. It means having some semblence of an idea about my diet, eating relatively healthily. But I'm somewhat relying on the 15-20km per day to get me most of the way there.

---

To make the scale go from 94kg to 92.9kg, I will need to burn 1kg of body fat. I can do that by doing the following things:
- Eating at my base metabolic rate: (around 1800kcal)
- Walking 100km (burning about 1000 kcal * 10 => )

```math
# Basics

calories_in_one_gram_of_fat = 9
calories_in_one_kilo_of_fat = calories_in_one_gram_of_fat * 1000

# Weight + Required calorie loss
current_weight = 94
target_weight = 93
fat_loss_required = current_weight - target_weight
excess_calories_to_burn = fat_loss_required * calories_in_one_kilo_of_fat

#Walking
estimated_calories_burned_walking_one_km = 100
estimated_calories_burned_walking_ten_km = estimated_calories_burned_walking_one_km * 10

walking_required_to_burn_one_kilo = calories_in_one_kilo_of_fat / estimated_calories_burned_walking_one_km

estimated_tdee = 2100
```


Hmm, the more I use it, the more I realize that Obsidian is a far more powerful tool than reflect and that I actually quite like all the things I can do with it. It doesn't hurt that it's free!

---

I wrote [[How to be a hard worker|this post about hard work today]], doing the work in the way I describe in the post!
