content.text:
I've lived in [[Sendai]] for nearly five years, out of a total of nearly seven in Japan. [[Sendai]] is my adopted home. I just got back from a trip to Tokyo this weekend and I have... thoughts.

I live in central Sendai, on a shopping arcade street the kind of which is common across all of Japan. My flat is a 4LDK at 98m¬≤, and is right in the middle of the [[Sendai]] central business district, so people assume I'm fabulously wealthy (narrator: he is not fabulously wealthy). My building is filled with retired couples and a small handful of families.

If I step out of my building there's a Tomods (national pharmacy chain store) on the ground floor. To my left there's a Family Mart and above that is my gym. It has 8 power racks, lots of machines, very spacious and is rarely crowded. Further in that direction is a McDonalds on my left, and across the street the arcade continues with Moncler and Louis Vuitton [[Sendai]] stores flanking me.

Out of my mansion, if instead of turning left I go straight across the arcade, I have bunka yokocho and iroho yokocho in front of me (yokocho just means "side street"). These are picturesque Japanese side-streets packed with tiny little bars and restaurants that can only fit seven or eight people. There around 370 establishments like this in the yokochos. As I write this, if I look left from my screen and out of the window, I can see the glass canopy of the arcade a few meters in front of me and the tin roofs over the yokochos beyond it.

If we go back to the original left past the designer stores, walk straight through the arcade for about seven minutes, we end up in Kokubuncho, the central entertainment area in Sendai. Kokubuncho is a relatively safe area¬π to walk around in. As a foreigner the kyacchi won't bother you much, and getting drugged and tricked out of huge sums of money is practically unheard of. The area is filled with hostess clubs, girls bars, snack bars and regular drinking establishments. More than you could visit if you went out every night for an year, but not enough to keep you busy for three.

## Exploration

After my divorce in 2019 I spent many of my evenings exploring Sendai. My basic MO was to walk into a small bar or restaurant, inevitably start chatting with the owner or other customers, and then ask for recommendations for other places to go.

People in [[Sendai]] are intrigued when foreigners end up in bars with a typically Japanese only clientele. I try to ask lots of questions, and everyone likes to talk about themselves. They're also happy that they can speak freely in Japanese with me and there isn't much friction in communication.

Sometimes I'll take their recommendations and go there immediately. [[Sendai]] is small enough that you can just hear directions and just walk over to wherever the place is. Other times I'd note it down and start the night there some other time. I kept going out like this until there was no more "fog of war" in Sendai. I know the main roads, the back streets, which bar owner has some beef with some other bar owner, who is who's sempai/kohai etc.

Doing all of this exploring gave me extremely strong social skills in Japanese. I was able to relate to and converse with a huge variety of characters. Your regular salaryman away from his family on ÂçòË∫´Ëµ¥‰ªª, 22yo university students, 2nd generation company owners, real estate magnates, bartenders and restaurant owner/operators running their place for 30 years like something out of shinya shokudo. Part of me wanted to _deeply_ understand people and Japanese culture on a human level, rather than just enjoy the food and the aesthetic like a tourist.

I somehow got a reputation for knowing everyone and everywhere. I got very good at lending an ear and getting people to share their secrets, worries, and desires. I can walk through central [[Sendai]] on the average day and run into two or three people I know. Along the way I made many acquaintances, a few friends, and a handful of enemies.

Many of those skills, connections, and adventures started and ended in the world of mizu shobai.

## The Water Business‚Ñ¢

I would be lying if I said that the only reason I'm interested in mizu shobai was out of a deep interest in Japanese culture. But I'm going to try and say it anyway, so bear with me.

I've never really liked anime or manga. And Japanese food, or should I say, Japanese culinary skill, is second to none. I'm extremely happy with the food here. Japanese history is interesting. Some Japanese movies and TV shows are good (I was young in the 90s so I particularly like Beat Takeshi yakuza movies and that era in general).

There are many, many foreigners in Japan that are here because they like anime, manga, or some aspect of Japanese culture. In Japanese you might call them _otaku_, or even _hentai_, which in this context means someone who is obsessed with something to an extreme degree.

I do not judge this at all. If you really freaking love anime and you managed to make it over to Japan and spend all your time immersed in anime, watching it, talking about it, going to events, living that anime fan life, then more power to you. If anything, I'm jealous of that level of passion and that you get to live your best life out here.

I however, am just not that into anime. But I am however obsessed with the water business, specifically hostess clubs, girls bars, and sometimes snacks.

From [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Host_and_hostess_clubs):

> _A _**_hostess club_**_ is a type of _[_night club_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_club)_ found primarily in Japan. They employ primarily female staff and cater to men seeking drinks and attentive conversation... Host and hostess clubs are considered part of _[_mizu sh≈çbai_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mizu_sh%C5%8Dbai) _(literally "water trade"), the night-time entertainment business in Japan._

_Note that you can read that article in wikipedia and get a general idea of what it is, but there are many generalizations that are misleading or plain incorrect. As with everything, there's a lot of nuance, regional variation etc._

Like any _otaku _I'm obsessed with the details_. The hand signals the girls/kurofuku use to communicate without words, and how they differ from one place to the next. The interpersonal dynamics between girls earning at different levels. How you're treated differently depending on whether the shop has revenue-based or point-based compensation for the girls. The decor, uniforms, types of customers, etc.

It's an extremely rich and detailed culture that is specific to Japan, that not even Japanese people on the whole know very much about. So for my programmer brain that lives on distinguishing and categorising fine details, hanging out at these places and absorbing everything about it is my nerd crack.

Of course, _of course,_ it's also just a lot of fun. Sitting next to insanely beautiful, model-level women while they serve you drinks and give you a lot of attention is just, fun. Provided you don't get needy and just enjoy the experience for what it is, depending on the people involved it _can_ be an extremely fun experience.

And like my other adventures, it gave me lots of time and space to develop my social skills. I made a game of trying to make girls laugh as hard as possible (five points for getting them to spray their drink, because they won't fake that). Through all of this my Japanese conversational ability skyrocketed even more.

While at first while I was still getting used to all this, there were a couple of one-itis situations. Once I got that out of my system I ended up fooling around with a couple of hostesses outside of their shop, and then dating one of them longer term. This taught me even _more_ about their world, perhaps more than I wanted to know.

For example, many of their customers invite girls to meet „Éó„É©„Ç§„Éô„Éº„Éà„Åß, on their day off, typically Sunday. A lot of the girls reply that they have beauty appointments, or just want to sleep in on Sunday. The customers doubt these excuses. They accuse the girls of having boyfriends and berate them for being unresponsive.

But if you actually start spending time with some of these girls outside of work, you'll see that they have at least three, maybe four beauty related appointments per week. Hair, hair removal, skincare, nails, eyelashes, gym, buying clothes, and so on. And when they're not at those appointments, they need to catch up on sleep, simply because of how bad their sleep is with the amount of [[Alcohol]] they're consuming. I saw one sleep 18 hours straight on my futon, Sunday morning through night. And they drink gallons of water every day to counterract the effects of the gallons of Veuve yellow they have to drink during work.

## The Pattern

So this sets some of the scene for my life at night in Sendai. Let's walk through what a typical evening in [[Sendai]] has been like for me over the past few years. In this example I will weave together a handful of events that actually happened, and change the names of people and places to protect the not so innocent.

***

This night starts the same way as most nights start in [[Sendai]] for me: it's the evening, I'm not with my boys, and I'm both hungry and a bit lonely, so I'll go out to one of the yokochos for a bite to eat and maybe a drink or two. The first place I try is a shochu place with a wiry master is his late fifties, it's cheap, the food is amazing and the regular customers are all friends.

It's full, and decide I feel like eating beef so head to bunyoko a one minute walk away. The 80yo mama died last year so her son (maybe grandson?) had taken over. Here some of the customers can get a bit shouty with me so I take a look to make sure there are no abjectly terrible drunks in tonights line up. The interior is something out of a showa-era manga, analogue tv on a shelf, photos and newspaper clippings taped to the wall, all deep brown through decades of smoke thanks to the coal-fired barbecues bought to your table. They know me here, but I don't remember anyone's names.

To my left sits Satoru-san (I forget his last name). My memory throws an exception and reminds me that I once had a one-night stand with the girl he's dating now, and that he was a bit salty about it, but then I remember we talked about it and I took him to a hostess club to bury the hatchet. Anyway I catch up with him, he's in his non-work clothes so probably had the day off today. I order a bottle of beer and short rib and liver for the barbecue. The owner brings me my beer and opens it. Satoru pours it for me and I pour his back.

Sitting on the other side of Satoru are two Japanese salarymen in their forties. They overhear this conversation and decide to talk to me. Once they get over praising my Japanese and I crack a few jokes, we exchange personal information. One is a mid-level manager at Tohoku Electrical and the other is a salesman from one of their vendors. Neither are [[Sendai]] natives, but business is done and they're somewhat interested in exploring [[Sendai]] at night.

"There is no one on Earth that knows [[Sendai]] at night better than this guy?" says Satoru, gesturing at me.

"That's a bit of an exaggeration" I respond, not really believing it

"No it's not" cuts in the owner of the shop, his eyes not moving from the meat he's flipping on the barbecue

They ask me where they should go next and I ask them what their budget is and what sort of place they want to go to. They said they're interested in exploring but want to just have a few drinks somewhere cheap and then figure out where they want to go after talking for a bit more.

Satoru decides he doesn't have the appetite for a night out with me, but the salarymen are down. Once we settle the bill at venue 1 we leave the yokochos and head up to Toichi ichiba. I start getting to know them. One of them is a sales director and is worried about an overall economic downturn. This one strikes me as a particularly bad drunk. The other one is here on tanshin funin and misses his family back in Chiba prefecture.

I take them to an extremely cheap standing izakaya. Every customer there already knows me too and the owner recognises me, shuffles our group to an open space near the bar. There's a girl working at the bar who takes our order.

"Ali!?" she says, recognising me, her eyes wide.

"Have we met?" I ask. I didn't recognise her with her mask on.

"You don't remember me?" she asks. She lowers her mask.

I recognise her from somewhere, instantly. Her hair is different, but that face is unmistakable. It used to be short/bob cut and dyed brown, now it's long but tied up for work. Same massive elephant ears. I jump back in surprise.

"Mana-chan!" I say.

"Who the hell is Mana-chan?" says some customer next to me.

"It's been, what, five years? I thought I'd never see you again." I say, incredulous.

Mana was a girl at a girls bar that I was frequenting many years ago. I had spent many nights drinking into the early hours with Mana. I was never interested in her romantically, never even learned her real name or invited her out outside of work. She had a very controlling (ÊùüÁ∏õ) boyfriend at the time, so when she stopped working at a girls bar he forced her to delete all contacts out of her phone, including mine.

At the time of course this gave me a brief moment of pause, but it's par for the course in that world. Can't be helped. I had resigned her to the annals of people I once knew so its fun and interesting to see her in real life and catch up. The other customers and two salarymen I brought with me are bewildered, assuming we used to be a romantic couple, we quickly change the subject. She tells me she works shifts Sunday and Thursday so I make a note to catch up with her one on one at some point in the future.

I also run into my good friends Tim and James there with a gaggle of new JETs in their twenties, still excited to have finally arrived in Japan. Tim is a chemical engineer and James is researching autonomous vehicle AI at Tohoku university. Both are out to socialize, learn Japanese, meet girls, and do young guy stuff. I try to meet all of the JET's and introduce myself.

We order high balls. The salarymen are surprised that everyone knows me. I ask them more about their individual situations, what they do at their companies. They're both well-educated so I absorb a handful of new vocab and new cultural knowledge from the conversation. We have a few more drinks, I introduce them to the people around me. They say the want to go to maybe one more place and then maybe call it a night.

I tell them that there's a world-class "authentic bar" about a minute away. The bartender is an absolute demon, and strawberries are in season. You're going to have the best strawberry cocktail of your life.

The three of us settle up and head to the bar. As usual Kurihara-san (the demon bartender) is friendly and chatty. We all ask for some kind of strawberry concoction, leaving the details to him. The decor, vibe, and level of skill is worthy of it's own Netflix documentary. Watching him go, polishing ice, washing it, arranging ingredients, pouring out measures, is watching a master at work. And the finished product perfect in flavour and texture. Thick, velvety, very strawberry, you can barely taste the [[Alcohol]] from the champagne.

We talk more and the salarymen ask me what's the weirdest place I've been to is in Sendai. I tell them they wouldn't believe me, but I'll try to explain.

There's a very high-end snack bar in kokubuncho, it doesn't show up on maps. It's run by a 42-year old mama who wears a kimono, sings old songs on the karaoke machine and occasionally plays the shamisen. She's known for her beauty and hospitality. However her husband died a few years ago, and her boyfriend (who she didn't actually stop seeing while married) passed away a few months after that. A third man in her life passed away within the same year. Her snack is bar is dark, with expensive whiskeys, rare blended shochus and kokubuncho yakuza and company directors (line is blurry there) as her customers.

They're intrigued, or perhaps just have a morbid curiosity. They no longer want to go home. They ask me how I know about this place and I tell them it's a long story (it's a very long story, involving a whole other cast of characters). The bar is literally called "the den of evil".

What I don't tell them is that the mama tells that story openly and also has a habit of taking home her customers, as a handful of people I took there have reported back to me. Good for her I think, but her stories and the nonchalantness with which she tells them scare me.

We walk over to her bar in kokubuncho and she greets me at the door. She's not in a kimono, but I remember she told me it's because her excema was playing up. I ask about that and after her six-year old daughter, who she keeps in a night nursery while she works (very common set up for night workers who are also mothers).

Once we're in I notice the company owner of a local izakaya chain with an account manager from one of the two big alcohhol distributors sitting in a box seat. The izakaya shacho is Jabba-the-hutt fat, smoking a fat cigar wearing a polo shirt looking like an enormous smoky marshmallow. I go over and greet them. I can't remember what happened but it's likely we went out drinking at one point, maybe I introduced him to this snack? He has an expensive bottle of champagne at his table. Once the salarymen and I are sat at the counter, Jabba gestures to the mama to pour us a glass each of the nice champagne.

I am completely tone-deaf but I decide to sing some Aerosmith and „Éâ„É©„Ç§„Éï„É©„ÉØ„Éº which I'm into in the moment. The salarymen are amazed by this place but are now completely drunk, so we decide to leave in an hour.

Guy sitting directly to my left is Sasaki san. He starts talking to me. He's in his early, maybe mid sixties. It turns out he is my ex-wife's next door neighbour. I buy him a drink and apologise for my youngest screaming and crying so much. He says not to worry, he misses the sounds of kids running around.

The original two salarymen are fully cooked, decide to leave early. They thank me for a great night, I tell them to be safe on the way home. Sasaki-san says he has one more venue left in him for the night, maybe a hostess club, and do I have any suggestions? I laugh. Sure, I can think of a few places.

We leave the den of evil and head a bit further down Kokubuncho-dori. Some of the experienced kyacchi greet me and ask me what I'm up to tonight. We know each other by name at this point. I've drunk with a handful of them at very sketchy places over the years.

The club I'm going to take him to is on the second floor of the building in front of us. The elevator opens onto a dark entrance, red velvet on the walls. The DJ is playing "I Feel it Coming" by The Weeknd. The doorman greets me by name and asks if it'll be the same as usual. I tell him yes please.

After checking over the radio the doorman escorts us to our our seat. The walk to our seats is like a the one-shot walk through scene in goodfellas. The girls waiting in the corridor door nod/bow in my direction while fidgeting with their phones. The store head, a big former judo guy who's known me for years bows deep and gestures to the main floor. It's a busy night, lots of customers notice me walk in, a one or two of them know my face. Mostly they're still just surprised that a foreigner visits a place like this.

We ask for shochu on the rocks and one of the floor staff makes it for us. The girl I nominated, Hanako, is set here, so I don't really get a choice in the matter unless I make a point of it. A few minutes later a couple of girls I don't know are brought to our table. I'm pretty drunk, and Sasaki-san is pretty wasted too, but he's still talking to the girls and having a good time.

A few moments later, Hanako is brought over to our table and one of the other girls leaves. Hanako is 27. The easiest way to describe Hanako is that she's like a Japanese Ariana Grande. Stunningly beautiful but also offensively good at her job. In a club of about forty girls she consistently takes a top 4 spot in the revenue/point rankings while still only working three or four nights a week, and balancing a day job. She's also a law-school graduate.

Sasaki-san is busy talking to his girl who gets changed out every twenty minutes. Hanako is happy to see me as usual. She's vaping while keeping a keen eye on our drinks. One of the best things about Hanako is she's a complete hardass on everyone she works with to make sure her customers have not a single hiccup in service, the girl makes the trains run on time. I'd been seeing her at this club for maybe two years.

I try to be a good listener and give people as much room to talk as possible, but she is excellent at doing the same to me, paraphrasing what I say, using _active listening_ to get me to verbalise things I didn't even know I wanted to verbalise. The only times I do get her to talk about herself, she talks primarily about her obsessive addiction to Monster Hunter. We also talk a lot about health and fitness, I'd say 80% of our recent conversations centre on things I learned listening to the Huberman Lab podcast. While she's filling up my eighth glass of shochu. It is what it is.

The DJ is great. 90s hip-hop, lots of 2Pac and Biggie, modern pop too, it's like he is in my on repeat playlist. After an hour I decide I'm tired and I'm ready to go home. We settle up and the girls see us off at the elevator. Sasaki-san decides to go home so I wave goodbye to him. I walk back down Kokubuncho street on the way back to my place.

As I'm approaching the same building as the den of evil, I notice Tim and James in line at a new club that opened recently (by club I mean like, drinks and music and dancing, not hostess club). They say I should join them. I tell them I'm too old for that kind of thing, but I'll wait with them in line a bit. I tell them they should start talking to some of the groups in front/behind them. They're too shy to do this, so I start talking to those groups, and then mix them in with Tim and James so everyone is having a good time.

As we get to the door of the club I'm about to take off, when out of somewhere a somewhat rotund older Japanese guy in a baseball cap grabs my collar and starts shouting something at me in heavy Sendai-ben. I am startled and my fight-or-flight response goes into overdrive.

I've been trying recently to get better at emotional regulation. I know in these situations, the best outcomes happen when I use my rational brain, my prefrontal-cortex, but for that part of me to come to the fore I've got to a) at least be aware of my biological response to the situation and b) quiet my first, ego-driven response. However, with this much [[Alcohol]] in me, my pre-frontal cortex being depressed, it was difficult to get there.

But I try. My "inner child" sent up the bat signal to my rational self, asking for help. I tried to stay calm. First I strip his grip to get me out of immediate danger. Then I take stock of the situation.

To guys right was a younger guy, covered in tattoos holding guys wallet and bag. All gucci. I felt guys hands in mine and noticed something odd. He had no pinky or ring fingers on either hand. LV sunglasses and irezumi peaking up out of his t-shirt.

At that point my memory kicks in.

"Hey, we've met before. You go that girls bar, the Honeybee Club right?" I ask, trying to keep my voice steady.

"Yeah I remember you! You're friends with Genki-san right?" he asks, his face cracking a smile.

We chat for a bit. He was going into the same club as Tim and James but didn't have to wait the line. I tell him these two are my friends so let's all try to have fun.

Just then a small woman in a kimono in her 80s shuffles past.

"Seiji, did I just see you put your hands on Ali-san?" she asks.

The old man sobers up immediately.

"Do you know him?" he asks the lady, in suddenly very measured Japanese.

"Yes. He's a member and an important customer" she says, looking directly at him.

"I'm very sorry. Please accept my apologies" he says to her as she walked on.

She looks over at me briefly and I bow deep.

"How the hell do you know Retsuko-mama?" he asks, astonished.

"It's a long story" I respond.

Retsuko-mama is the aforementioned "last boss" of Kokubuncho. Politicians curry favour with her, she is the "fixer" behind the scenes and no big deals get done in [[Sendai]] without her knowing about them. Her exploits and wealth are of legend. Godmother, don, powerbroker, call her what you will, but a good business card to have in your wallet, let's put it that way.

My heart is still racing at this point and sit down in front of a convenience store for a moment to catch my breath. I don't really enjoy fighty situations, but think at the moment that this is going to be one hell of a story, how could anyone believe this?

I check my phone and Hanako sent me a quick thank you note. I send her a note back thanking her again for today. I tell her a fun thing just happened, I'll tell her about it next time.

Just then I get a text from Kaede. I'm both happy that she's contacting me and also tired thinking about what the next six hours are going to be like, especially if she's had a lot to drink. She says she's just finishing up work and wants to hang out and maybe stay over at mine tonight.

I wait for a bit but I get no response from her, so go to a late-night tonkotsu ramen place. It's a bit rowdy near the entrance, someone just threw up. I go inside and get my tonkotsu ramen. While I'm there Kaede texts me and asks me to wait around until 3am because one of her customers bought some champagne and she has to go on an after with them.

I say OK, but decide I'll head back to mine first and maybe fall asleep. About 90m later she calls me, she's very drunk and clearly not well. I come back to Kokubuncho street and meet her walking in the opposite direction. She has a miserable look on her face, her makeup is smeared as though she's been crying, and there's a red stain on her all-white top.

She's not a very huggy girl but I decide to hug her anyway and she starts crying. I take my coat off and drape it on her shoulders, grab her bag, and walk her back to my place. It turns out she had a particularly bad group of customers on the after who went out of their way to make fun of her for being a dumb, ugly, "countryside hostess", and one of them went so far as to deliberately spill Tabasco over her clothes.

(For the record she's one of the prettiest girls I've ever met both inside and outside of her club, and is very intelligent, creative, and bright.)

We go back to my place, we put her clothes in the wash and she wears things she pulls out of my closet. She tells me all about what happened, and manage to get back into good spirits. We sing some disney songs. We're both too drunk to have sex but try anyway. The result is a somewhat sloppy but otherwise enjoyable mess. After we go out onto my balcony, sipping chu-hais and talking for the next four hours as we watch the sun come up.

When I wake up the next day she's gone. Did I imagine her? I have a terrible but serviceable hangover, but not much energy to do anything else. What a bonkers night, how did that happen?

***

Sounds unbelievable? Dear reader, this is not a once-in-a-lifetime experience for me, **it's a Tuesday**. Or maybe this sort of night is normal for you, I don't know. I have no frame of reference.

## [[Sendai]] at night as a Rogue-like

I never played Rogue itself but I've played a couple of modern Rogue-likes, like _Dead Cells _and _Hades. _You play the same levels from the start on each "run" of the game. In modern games like this, each run allows you to take some items, experience, skills into the next run. Rooms or enemies may be placed differently each time, but you get to know more of the characters as you progress further into the game on each run. And there are items, prizes, high scores to be attained, and challenges to overcome and skills to learn.

That, is what a night out in [[Sendai]] is like to me. Each time I go out I might go over familiar territory or I might explore new dungeons. All types of challenges might be thrown my way that I have to overcome, learning something about myself in the process. I get to use and improve my Japanese social ability. Old characters rotate in and out, I discover new connections, and new side-quests appear. Gaining some skill and recognition is a huge ego boost.

But like any Rogue-like you spend hundreds of hours of your life in, a point comes when you look at the hours played counter and ask yourself, isn't this just about enough? There are a few counterarguments:
- I'm having an incredible amount of fun. I don't know anyone that is having as much fun in Japan as I am. And it is getting more fun on each run, not less.
- I am improving, both in Japanese conversational ability and ability to network, at an increasingly rapid rate. I've always been a relatively good networker but my skills are much tighter and more refined after these past few years.

There isn't much I can point to as an achievement that's come out of all of this. Part of me wanted to make [[Sendai]] more used to foreigners and foreigners more used to Sendai. So I used my social ability, connections, etc to start [[Sendai]][ International Meetups](https://www.meetup.com/sendai-international-meetups-the-new-era/), an international exchange event that me and a friend have worked up to getting a regular attendance of about fifty people, which for [[Sendai]] is not insignificant.

This allows me to bring together a lot of the characters I've met and take them to a lot of the places I've discovered. I also like that I've been able to introduce people to each other and create friendships and romantic engagements, if not relationships.

But there are three problems that playing this particular Rogue-like has brought into my life that are getting in the way of other things:
- [[Alcohol]] consumption. I don't like drinking alone so I'm not sure that I'm physically addicted to alcohol, but it's become a very, very regular fixture in my life. I should probably drink less.
- Sex addiction. Not much more to say about that, it is what it is. Obviously very fun and not sure I'm going to stop, but it's definitely a distraction.
- Time and energy. Dealing with all of these adventures takes a lot out of your physically, and just recovering from hangovers leaves very little time for basically anything else.

Recent events have made me question how much many more runs I have left in me. I haven't made any decisions yet but I'm definitely sitting and thinking about whether it may be it's time for a new season.

## Planet-scale success

It's March 2023 and I'm very unemployed. Three things happened:
- SVB Bank something something. I think the correct term is "imploded" but I don't have the knowledge to speak about this intelligently.
- OpenAI unleashed ChatGPT, sending many programmers and tech leadership people into an existential crisis.
- There were tens of thousands of layoffs in bigtech, flooding the market with senior engineering talent

I'm on OK senior Ruby on Rails developer, and I work freelance, in Japan. However, I had stopped networking entirely since Happy Bear Software wrapped up, so I have no options in front of me. I briefly attempted a cold-emailing campaign but decided that I'll just stick to what I do best: networking, starting with my friends back in London.

I got back in touch with very many people, getting on zoom calls and it was great to be able to talk shop with people in English. It was also good to see where everyone had got to in their careers after all this time.

As a part of this an old friend suggested visiting him in Tokyo. He, like an unnamed member of my family, is professionally successful on a planet-wide scale. But having a conversation with either of these two people throws into sharp relief what I might have achieved had I focused more on creating things.

And it's not just those two. Any cursory glance through Indie Hackers podcast guest list or even other people I've been on calls with over the past few weeks and you have countless examples of people with a similar professional background as me going on to attain enviable levels of success. This all hit hard when after my conversation with my good friend in Tokyo.

For now, I need to put money in the bank somehow and finding new work via networking is the only way I know how to do that. And whatever I do next will involve me being sociable and networking and collaborating with people.

There will be more speed-runs through [[Sendai]] and many adventures to come, but after spending time with so many monstrously successful people, I think it's time for me to make a good attempt at other things. At goals and dreams I've neglected for almost twenty years. Part of me was worried that these things would never happen for me, but another part of me thinks that maybe everything happened the way it did for a reason.

#### Footnotes

_[1]: One day buy me a drink and I will regale you with some anecdotes to the contrary._

details.aggregated:
I've lived in [[Sendai]] for nearly five years, out of a total of nearly seven in Japan. [[Sendai]] is my adopted home. I just got back from a trip to Tokyo this weekend and I have... thoughts.

I live in central Sendai, on a shopping arcade street the kind of which is common across all of Japan. My flat is a 4LDK at 98m¬≤, and is right in the middle of the [[Sendai]] central business district, so people assume I'm fabulously wealthy (narrator: he is not fabulously wealthy). My building is filled with retired couples and a small handful of families.

If I step out of my building there's a Tomods (national pharmacy chain store) on the ground floor. To my left there's a Family Mart and above that is my gym. It has 8 power racks, lots of machines, very spacious and is rarely crowded. Further in that direction is a McDonalds on my left, and across the street the arcade continues with Moncler and Louis Vuitton [[Sendai]] stores flanking me.

Out of my mansion, if instead of turning left I go straight across the arcade, I have bunka yokocho and iroho yokocho in front of me (yokocho just means "side street"). These are picturesque Japanese side-streets packed with tiny little bars and restaurants that can only fit seven or eight people. There around 370 establishments like this in the yokochos. As I write this, if I look left from my screen and out of the window, I can see the glass canopy of the arcade a few meters in front of me and the tin roofs over the yokochos beyond it.

If we go back to the original left past the designer stores, walk straight through the arcade for about seven minutes, we end up in Kokubuncho, the central entertainment area in Sendai. Kokubuncho is a relatively safe area¬π to walk around in. As a foreigner the kyacchi won't bother you much, and getting drugged and tricked out of huge sums of money is practically unheard of. The area is filled with hostess clubs, girls bars, snack bars and regular drinking establishments. More than you could visit if you went out every night for an year, but not enough to keep you busy for three.

## Exploration

After my divorce in 2019 I spent many of my evenings exploring Sendai. My basic MO was to walk into a small bar or restaurant, inevitably start chatting with the owner or other customers, and then ask for recommendations for other places to go.

People in [[Sendai]] are intrigued when foreigners end up in bars with a typically Japanese only clientele. I try to ask lots of questions, and everyone likes to talk about themselves. They're also happy that they can speak freely in Japanese with me and there isn't much friction in communication.

Sometimes I'll take their recommendations and go there immediately. [[Sendai]] is small enough that you can just hear directions and just walk over to wherever the place is. Other times I'd note it down and start the night there some other time. I kept going out like this until there was no more "fog of war" in Sendai. I know the main roads, the back streets, which bar owner has some beef with some other bar owner, who is who's sempai/kohai etc.

Doing all of this exploring gave me extremely strong social skills in Japanese. I was able to relate to and converse with a huge variety of characters. Your regular salaryman away from his family on ÂçòË∫´Ëµ¥‰ªª, 22yo university students, 2nd generation company owners, real estate magnates, bartenders and restaurant owner/operators running their place for 30 years like something out of shinya shokudo. Part of me wanted to _deeply_ understand people and Japanese culture on a human level, rather than just enjoy the food and the aesthetic like a tourist.

I somehow got a reputation for knowing everyone and everywhere. I got very good at lending an ear and getting people to share their secrets, worries, and desires. I can walk through central [[Sendai]] on the average day and run into two or three people I know. Along the way I made many acquaintances, a few friends, and a handful of enemies.

Many of those skills, connections, and adventures started and ended in the world of mizu shobai.

## The Water Business‚Ñ¢

I would be lying if I said that the only reason I'm interested in mizu shobai was out of a deep interest in Japanese culture. But I'm going to try and say it anyway, so bear with me.

I've never really liked anime or manga. And Japanese food, or should I say, Japanese culinary skill, is second to none. I'm extremely happy with the food here. Japanese history is interesting. Some Japanese movies and TV shows are good (I was young in the 90s so I particularly like Beat Takeshi yakuza movies and that era in general).

There are many, many foreigners in Japan that are here because they like anime, manga, or some aspect of Japanese culture. In Japanese you might call them _otaku_, or even _hentai_, which in this context means someone who is obsessed with something to an extreme degree.

I do not judge this at all. If you really freaking love anime and you managed to make it over to Japan and spend all your time immersed in anime, watching it, talking about it, going to events, living that anime fan life, then more power to you. If anything, I'm jealous of that level of passion and that you get to live your best life out here.

I however, am just not that into anime. But I am however obsessed with the water business, specifically hostess clubs, girls bars, and sometimes snacks.

From [wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Host_and_hostess_clubs):

> _A _**_hostess club_**_ is a type of _[_night club_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Night_club)_ found primarily in Japan. They employ primarily female staff and cater to men seeking drinks and attentive conversation... Host and hostess clubs are considered part of _[_mizu sh≈çbai_](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mizu_sh%C5%8Dbai) _(literally "water trade"), the night-time entertainment business in Japan._

_Note that you can read that article in wikipedia and get a general idea of what it is, but there are many generalizations that are misleading or plain incorrect. As with everything, there's a lot of nuance, regional variation etc._

Like any _otaku _I'm obsessed with the details_. The hand signals the girls/kurofuku use to communicate without words, and how they differ from one place to the next. The interpersonal dynamics between girls earning at different levels. How you're treated differently depending on whether the shop has revenue-based or point-based compensation for the girls. The decor, uniforms, types of customers, etc.

It's an extremely rich and detailed culture that is specific to Japan, that not even Japanese people on the whole know very much about. So for my programmer brain that lives on distinguishing and categorising fine details, hanging out at these places and absorbing everything about it is my nerd crack.

Of course, _of course,_ it's also just a lot of fun. Sitting next to insanely beautiful, model-level women while they serve you drinks and give you a lot of attention is just, fun. Provided you don't get needy and just enjoy the experience for what it is, depending on the people involved it _can_ be an extremely fun experience.

And like my other adventures, it gave me lots of time and space to develop my social skills. I made a game of trying to make girls laugh as hard as possible (five points for getting them to spray their drink, because they won't fake that). Through all of this my Japanese conversational ability skyrocketed even more.

While at first while I was still getting used to all this, there were a couple of one-itis situations. Once I got that out of my system I ended up fooling around with a couple of hostesses outside of their shop, and then dating one of them longer term. This taught me even _more_ about their world, perhaps more than I wanted to know.

For example, many of their customers invite girls to meet „Éó„É©„Ç§„Éô„Éº„Éà„Åß, on their day off, typically Sunday. A lot of the girls reply that they have beauty appointments, or just want to sleep in on Sunday. The customers doubt these excuses. They accuse the girls of having boyfriends and berate them for being unresponsive.

But if you actually start spending time with some of these girls outside of work, you'll see that they have at least three, maybe four beauty related appointments per week. Hair, hair removal, skincare, nails, eyelashes, gym, buying clothes, and so on. And when they're not at those appointments, they need to catch up on sleep, simply because of how bad their sleep is with the amount of [[Alcohol]] they're consuming. I saw one sleep 18 hours straight on my futon, Sunday morning through night. And they drink gallons of water every day to counterract the effects of the gallons of Veuve yellow they have to drink during work.

## The Pattern

So this sets some of the scene for my life at night in Sendai. Let's walk through what a typical evening in [[Sendai]] has been like for me over the past few years. In this example I will weave together a handful of events that actually happened, and change the names of people and places to protect the not so innocent.

***

This night starts the same way as most nights start in [[Sendai]] for me: it's the evening, I'm not with my boys, and I'm both hungry and a bit lonely, so I'll go out to one of the yokochos for a bite to eat and maybe a drink or two. The first place I try is a shochu place with a wiry master is his late fifties, it's cheap, the food is amazing and the regular customers are all friends.

It's full, and decide I feel like eating beef so head to bunyoko a one minute walk away. The 80yo mama died last year so her son (maybe grandson?) had taken over. Here some of the customers can get a bit shouty with me so I take a look to make sure there are no abjectly terrible drunks in tonights line up. The interior is something out of a showa-era manga, analogue tv on a shelf, photos and newspaper clippings taped to the wall, all deep brown through decades of smoke thanks to the coal-fired barbecues bought to your table. They know me here, but I don't remember anyone's names.

To my left sits Satoru-san (I forget his last name). My memory throws an exception and reminds me that I once had a one-night stand with the girl he's dating now, and that he was a bit salty about it, but then I remember we talked about it and I took him to a hostess club to bury the hatchet. Anyway I catch up with him, he's in his non-work clothes so probably had the day off today. I order a bottle of beer and short rib and liver for the barbecue. The owner brings me my beer and opens it. Satoru pours it for me and I pour his back.

Sitting on the other side of Satoru are two Japanese salarymen in their forties. They overhear this conversation and decide to talk to me. Once they get over praising my Japanese and I crack a few jokes, we exchange personal information. One is a mid-level manager at Tohoku Electrical and the other is a salesman from one of their vendors. Neither are [[Sendai]] natives, but business is done and they're somewhat interested in exploring [[Sendai]] at night.

"There is no one on Earth that knows [[Sendai]] at night better than this guy?" says Satoru, gesturing at me.

"That's a bit of an exaggeration" I respond, not really believing it

"No it's not" cuts in the owner of the shop, his eyes not moving from the meat he's flipping on the barbecue

They ask me where they should go next and I ask them what their budget is and what sort of place they want to go to. They said they're interested in exploring but want to just have a few drinks somewhere cheap and then figure out where they want to go after talking for a bit more.

Satoru decides he doesn't have the appetite for a night out with me, but the salarymen are down. Once we settle the bill at venue 1 we leave the yokochos and head up to Toichi ichiba. I start getting to know them. One of them is a sales director and is worried about an overall economic downturn. This one strikes me as a particularly bad drunk. The other one is here on tanshin funin and misses his family back in Chiba prefecture.

I take them to an extremely cheap standing izakaya. Every customer there already knows me too and the owner recognises me, shuffles our group to an open space near the bar. There's a girl working at the bar who takes our order.

"Ali!?" she says, recognising me, her eyes wide.

"Have we met?" I ask. I didn't recognise her with her mask on.

"You don't remember me?" she asks. She lowers her mask.

I recognise her from somewhere, instantly. Her hair is different, but that face is unmistakable. It used to be short/bob cut and dyed brown, now it's long but tied up for work. Same massive elephant ears. I jump back in surprise.

"Mana-chan!" I say.

"Who the hell is Mana-chan?" says some customer next to me.

"It's been, what, five years? I thought I'd never see you again." I say, incredulous.

Mana was a girl at a girls bar that I was frequenting many years ago. I had spent many nights drinking into the early hours with Mana. I was never interested in her romantically, never even learned her real name or invited her out outside of work. She had a very controlling (ÊùüÁ∏õ) boyfriend at the time, so when she stopped working at a girls bar he forced her to delete all contacts out of her phone, including mine.

At the time of course this gave me a brief moment of pause, but it's par for the course in that world. Can't be helped. I had resigned her to the annals of people I once knew so its fun and interesting to see her in real life and catch up. The other customers and two salarymen I brought with me are bewildered, assuming we used to be a romantic couple, we quickly change the subject. She tells me she works shifts Sunday and Thursday so I make a note to catch up with her one on one at some point in the future.

I also run into my good friends Tim and James there with a gaggle of new JETs in their twenties, still excited to have finally arrived in Japan. Tim is a chemical engineer and James is researching autonomous vehicle AI at Tohoku university. Both are out to socialize, learn Japanese, meet girls, and do young guy stuff. I try to meet all of the JET's and introduce myself.

We order high balls. The salarymen are surprised that everyone knows me. I ask them more about their individual situations, what they do at their companies. They're both well-educated so I absorb a handful of new vocab and new cultural knowledge from the conversation. We have a few more drinks, I introduce them to the people around me. They say the want to go to maybe one more place and then maybe call it a night.

I tell them that there's a world-class "authentic bar" about a minute away. The bartender is an absolute demon, and strawberries are in season. You're going to have the best strawberry cocktail of your life.

The three of us settle up and head to the bar. As usual Kurihara-san (the demon bartender) is friendly and chatty. We all ask for some kind of strawberry concoction, leaving the details to him. The decor, vibe, and level of skill is worthy of it's own Netflix documentary. Watching him go, polishing ice, washing it, arranging ingredients, pouring out measures, is watching a master at work. And the finished product perfect in flavour and texture. Thick, velvety, very strawberry, you can barely taste the [[Alcohol]] from the champagne.

We talk more and the salarymen ask me what's the weirdest place I've been to is in Sendai. I tell them they wouldn't believe me, but I'll try to explain.

There's a very high-end snack bar in kokubuncho, it doesn't show up on maps. It's run by a 42-year old mama who wears a kimono, sings old songs on the karaoke machine and occasionally plays the shamisen. She's known for her beauty and hospitality. However her husband died a few years ago, and her boyfriend (who she didn't actually stop seeing while married) passed away a few months after that. A third man in her life passed away within the same year. Her snack is bar is dark, with expensive whiskeys, rare blended shochus and kokubuncho yakuza and company directors (line is blurry there) as her customers.

They're intrigued, or perhaps just have a morbid curiosity. They no longer want to go home. They ask me how I know about this place and I tell them it's a long story (it's a very long story, involving a whole other cast of characters). The bar is literally called "the den of evil".

What I don't tell them is that the mama tells that story openly and also has a habit of taking home her customers, as a handful of people I took there have reported back to me. Good for her I think, but her stories and the nonchalantness with which she tells them scare me.

We walk over to her bar in kokubuncho and she greets me at the door. She's not in a kimono, but I remember she told me it's because her excema was playing up. I ask about that and after her six-year old daughter, who she keeps in a night nursery while she works (very common set up for night workers who are also mothers).

Once we're in I notice the company owner of a local izakaya chain with an account manager from one of the two big alcohhol distributors sitting in a box seat. The izakaya shacho is Jabba-the-hutt fat, smoking a fat cigar wearing a polo shirt looking like an enormous smoky marshmallow. I go over and greet them. I can't remember what happened but it's likely we went out drinking at one point, maybe I introduced him to this snack? He has an expensive bottle of champagne at his table. Once the salarymen and I are sat at the counter, Jabba gestures to the mama to pour us a glass each of the nice champagne.

I am completely tone-deaf but I decide to sing some Aerosmith and „Éâ„É©„Ç§„Éï„É©„ÉØ„Éº which I'm into in the moment. The salarymen are amazed by this place but are now completely drunk, so we decide to leave in an hour.

Guy sitting directly to my left is Sasaki san. He starts talking to me. He's in his early, maybe mid sixties. It turns out he is my ex-wife's next door neighbour. I buy him a drink and apologise for my youngest screaming and crying so much. He says not to worry, he misses the sounds of kids running around.

The original two salarymen are fully cooked, decide to leave early. They thank me for a great night, I tell them to be safe on the way home. Sasaki-san says he has one more venue left in him for the night, maybe a hostess club, and do I have any suggestions? I laugh. Sure, I can think of a few places.

We leave the den of evil and head a bit further down Kokubuncho-dori. Some of the experienced kyacchi greet me and ask me what I'm up to tonight. We know each other by name at this point. I've drunk with a handful of them at very sketchy places over the years.

The club I'm going to take him to is on the second floor of the building in front of us. The elevator opens onto a dark entrance, red velvet on the walls. The DJ is playing "I Feel it Coming" by The Weeknd. The doorman greets me by name and asks if it'll be the same as usual. I tell him yes please.

After checking over the radio the doorman escorts us to our our seat. The walk to our seats is like a the one-shot walk through scene in goodfellas. The girls waiting in the corridor door nod/bow in my direction while fidgeting with their phones. The store head, a big former judo guy who's known me for years bows deep and gestures to the main floor. It's a busy night, lots of customers notice me walk in, a one or two of them know my face. Mostly they're still just surprised that a foreigner visits a place like this.

We ask for shochu on the rocks and one of the floor staff makes it for us. The girl I nominated, Hanako, is set here, so I don't really get a choice in the matter unless I make a point of it. A few minutes later a couple of girls I don't know are brought to our table. I'm pretty drunk, and Sasaki-san is pretty wasted too, but he's still talking to the girls and having a good time.

A few moments later, Hanako is brought over to our table and one of the other girls leaves. Hanako is 27. The easiest way to describe Hanako is that she's like a Japanese Ariana Grande. Stunningly beautiful but also offensively good at her job. In a club of about forty girls she consistently takes a top 4 spot in the revenue/point rankings while still only working three or four nights a week, and balancing a day job. She's also a law-school graduate.

Sasaki-san is busy talking to his girl who gets changed out every twenty minutes. Hanako is happy to see me as usual. She's vaping while keeping a keen eye on our drinks. One of the best things about Hanako is she's a complete hardass on everyone she works with to make sure her customers have not a single hiccup in service, the girl makes the trains run on time. I'd been seeing her at this club for maybe two years.

I try to be a good listener and give people as much room to talk as possible, but she is excellent at doing the same to me, paraphrasing what I say, using _active listening_ to get me to verbalise things I didn't even know I wanted to verbalise. The only times I do get her to talk about herself, she talks primarily about her obsessive addiction to Monster Hunter. We also talk a lot about health and fitness, I'd say 80% of our recent conversations centre on things I learned listening to the Huberman Lab podcast. While she's filling up my eighth glass of shochu. It is what it is.

The DJ is great. 90s hip-hop, lots of 2Pac and Biggie, modern pop too, it's like he is in my on repeat playlist. After an hour I decide I'm tired and I'm ready to go home. We settle up and the girls see us off at the elevator. Sasaki-san decides to go home so I wave goodbye to him. I walk back down Kokubuncho street on the way back to my place.

As I'm approaching the same building as the den of evil, I notice Tim and James in line at a new club that opened recently (by club I mean like, drinks and music and dancing, not hostess club). They say I should join them. I tell them I'm too old for that kind of thing, but I'll wait with them in line a bit. I tell them they should start talking to some of the groups in front/behind them. They're too shy to do this, so I start talking to those groups, and then mix them in with Tim and James so everyone is having a good time.

As we get to the door of the club I'm about to take off, when out of somewhere a somewhat rotund older Japanese guy in a baseball cap grabs my collar and starts shouting something at me in heavy Sendai-ben. I am startled and my fight-or-flight response goes into overdrive.

I've been trying recently to get better at emotional regulation. I know in these situations, the best outcomes happen when I use my rational brain, my prefrontal-cortex, but for that part of me to come to the fore I've got to a) at least be aware of my biological response to the situation and b) quiet my first, ego-driven response. However, with this much [[Alcohol]] in me, my pre-frontal cortex being depressed, it was difficult to get there.

But I try. My "inner child" sent up the bat signal to my rational self, asking for help. I tried to stay calm. First I strip his grip to get me out of immediate danger. Then I take stock of the situation.

To guys right was a younger guy, covered in tattoos holding guys wallet and bag. All gucci. I felt guys hands in mine and noticed something odd. He had no pinky or ring fingers on either hand. LV sunglasses and irezumi peaking up out of his t-shirt.

At that point my memory kicks in.

"Hey, we've met before. You go that girls bar, the Honeybee Club right?" I ask, trying to keep my voice steady.

"Yeah I remember you! You're friends with Genki-san right?" he asks, his face cracking a smile.

We chat for a bit. He was going into the same club as Tim and James but didn't have to wait the line. I tell him these two are my friends so let's all try to have fun.

Just then a small woman in a kimono in her 80s shuffles past.

"Seiji, did I just see you put your hands on Ali-san?" she asks.

The old man sobers up immediately.

"Do you know him?" he asks the lady, in suddenly very measured Japanese.

"Yes. He's a member and an important customer" she says, looking directly at him.

"I'm very sorry. Please accept my apologies" he says to her as she walked on.

She looks over at me briefly and I bow deep.

"How the hell do you know Retsuko-mama?" he asks, astonished.

"It's a long story" I respond.

Retsuko-mama is the aforementioned "last boss" of Kokubuncho. Politicians curry favour with her, she is the "fixer" behind the scenes and no big deals get done in [[Sendai]] without her knowing about them. Her exploits and wealth are of legend. Godmother, don, powerbroker, call her what you will, but a good business card to have in your wallet, let's put it that way.

My heart is still racing at this point and sit down in front of a convenience store for a moment to catch my breath. I don't really enjoy fighty situations, but think at the moment that this is going to be one hell of a story, how could anyone believe this?

I check my phone and Hanako sent me a quick thank you note. I send her a note back thanking her again for today. I tell her a fun thing just happened, I'll tell her about it next time.

Just then I get a text from Kaede. I'm both happy that she's contacting me and also tired thinking about what the next six hours are going to be like, especially if she's had a lot to drink. She says she's just finishing up work and wants to hang out and maybe stay over at mine tonight.

I wait for a bit but I get no response from her, so go to a late-night tonkotsu ramen place. It's a bit rowdy near the entrance, someone just threw up. I go inside and get my tonkotsu ramen. While I'm there Kaede texts me and asks me to wait around until 3am because one of her customers bought some champagne and she has to go on an after with them.

I say OK, but decide I'll head back to mine first and maybe fall asleep. About 90m later she calls me, she's very drunk and clearly not well. I come back to Kokubuncho street and meet her walking in the opposite direction. She has a miserable look on her face, her makeup is smeared as though she's been crying, and there's a red stain on her all-white top.

She's not a very huggy girl but I decide to hug her anyway and she starts crying. I take my coat off and drape it on her shoulders, grab her bag, and walk her back to my place. It turns out she had a particularly bad group of customers on the after who went out of their way to make fun of her for being a dumb, ugly, "countryside hostess", and one of them went so far as to deliberately spill Tabasco over her clothes.

(For the record she's one of the prettiest girls I've ever met both inside and outside of her club, and is very intelligent, creative, and bright.)

We go back to my place, we put her clothes in the wash and she wears things she pulls out of my closet. She tells me all about what happened, and manage to get back into good spirits. We sing some disney songs. We're both too drunk to have sex but try anyway. The result is a somewhat sloppy but otherwise enjoyable mess. After we go out onto my balcony, sipping chu-hais and talking for the next four hours as we watch the sun come up.

When I wake up the next day she's gone. Did I imagine her? I have a terrible but serviceable hangover, but not much energy to do anything else. What a bonkers night, how did that happen?

***

Sounds unbelievable? Dear reader, this is not a once-in-a-lifetime experience for me, **it's a Tuesday**. Or maybe this sort of night is normal for you, I don't know. I have no frame of reference.

## [[Sendai]] at night as a Rogue-like

I never played Rogue itself but I've played a couple of modern Rogue-likes, like _Dead Cells _and _Hades. _You play the same levels from the start on each "run" of the game. In modern games like this, each run allows you to take some items, experience, skills into the next run. Rooms or enemies may be placed differently each time, but you get to know more of the characters as you progress further into the game on each run. And there are items, prizes, high scores to be attained, and challenges to overcome and skills to learn.

That, is what a night out in [[Sendai]] is like to me. Each time I go out I might go over familiar territory or I might explore new dungeons. All types of challenges might be thrown my way that I have to overcome, learning something about myself in the process. I get to use and improve my Japanese social ability. Old characters rotate in and out, I discover new connections, and new side-quests appear. Gaining some skill and recognition is a huge ego boost.

But like any Rogue-like you spend hundreds of hours of your life in, a point comes when you look at the hours played counter and ask yourself, isn't this just about enough? There are a few counterarguments:
- I'm having an incredible amount of fun. I don't know anyone that is having as much fun in Japan as I am. And it is getting more fun on each run, not less.
- I am improving, both in Japanese conversational ability and ability to network, at an increasingly rapid rate. I've always been a relatively good networker but my skills are much tighter and more refined after these past few years.

There isn't much I can point to as an achievement that's come out of all of this. Part of me wanted to make [[Sendai]] more used to foreigners and foreigners more used to Sendai. So I used my social ability, connections, etc to start [[Sendai]][ International Meetups](https://www.meetup.com/sendai-international-meetups-the-new-era/), an international exchange event that me and a friend have worked up to getting a regular attendance of about fifty people, which for [[Sendai]] is not insignificant.

This allows me to bring together a lot of the characters I've met and take them to a lot of the places I've discovered. I also like that I've been able to introduce people to each other and create friendships and romantic engagements, if not relationships.

But there are three problems that playing this particular Rogue-like has brought into my life that are getting in the way of other things:
- [[Alcohol]] consumption. I don't like drinking alone so I'm not sure that I'm physically addicted to alcohol, but it's become a very, very regular fixture in my life. I should probably drink less.
- Sex addiction. Not much more to say about that, it is what it is. Obviously very fun and not sure I'm going to stop, but it's definitely a distraction.
- Time and energy. Dealing with all of these adventures takes a lot out of your physically, and just recovering from hangovers leaves very little time for basically anything else.

Recent events have made me question how much many more runs I have left in me. I haven't made any decisions yet but I'm definitely sitting and thinking about whether it may be it's time for a new season.

## Planet-scale success

It's March 2023 and I'm very unemployed. Three things happened:
- SVB Bank something something. I think the correct term is "imploded" but I don't have the knowledge to speak about this intelligently.
- OpenAI unleashed ChatGPT, sending many programmers and tech leadership people into an existential crisis.
- There were tens of thousands of layoffs in bigtech, flooding the market with senior engineering talent

I'm on OK senior Ruby on Rails developer, and I work freelance, in Japan. However, I had stopped networking entirely since Happy Bear Software wrapped up, so I have no options in front of me. I briefly attempted a cold-emailing campaign but decided that I'll just stick to what I do best: networking, starting with my friends back in London.

I got back in touch with very many people, getting on zoom calls and it was great to be able to talk shop with people in English. It was also good to see where everyone had got to in their careers after all this time.

As a part of this an old friend suggested visiting him in Tokyo. He, like an unnamed member of my family, is professionally successful on a planet-wide scale. But having a conversation with either of these two people throws into sharp relief what I might have achieved had I focused more on creating things.

And it's not just those two. Any cursory glance through Indie Hackers podcast guest list or even other people I've been on calls with over the past few weeks and you have countless examples of people with a similar professional background as me going on to attain enviable levels of success. This all hit hard when after my conversation with my good friend in Tokyo.

For now, I need to put money in the bank somehow and finding new work via networking is the only way I know how to do that. And whatever I do next will involve me being sociable and networking and collaborating with people.

There will be more speed-runs through [[Sendai]] and many adventures to come, but after spending time with so many monstrously successful people, I think it's time for me to make a good attempt at other things. At goals and dreams I've neglected for almost twenty years. Part of me was worried that these things would never happen for me, but another part of me thinks that maybe everything happened the way it did for a reason.

#### Footnotes

_[1]: One day buy me a drink and I will regale you with some anecdotes to the contrary._

content.text:
# Tue, March 21st, 2023

- ü§¢ Very drunk wake up. Hangover terrible.
- üëü I need to hold fast and stay off [[Alcohol]] until my mind clears. And get back on the grind of looking for work.
- üåä Keep tabs on [[Masturbation]] and the [[Dopamine Wave Pool]] as they are all flattened out now.
- I went to [[Lapis and Delica]], a new onigiri cafe in the yokochos, near [[Pizzeria Rocco]]
- [[Health and Fitness]]
- üõ£Ô∏è Life path and behaviour
  - Why don't I just start recording YouTube videos? It's not like I don't have the time.
    -
  - I have identified a few things to be true that I'm thinking about at the moment.
    - üßπ What I call [[Adulting]] is the absolute basline activity that has to happen for me to function in society. Brushing my teeth, taking out trash, etc. These have to happen or quality of life decreases drastically. or slows to a halt, and everythig depends on these basic adulting things. Getting good at these basics is fundamental to everythign else.
    - üéØ I also know that if I don't narrow my focus, I won't be able to achieve anything. So I can't be focusing on several things at once, I need to be narrowing it down and getting better at the important things.
    - üßæ In that vein, this means that while before my focus was split across many different areas, in reality I need to pair it down to just the fundamental things that are important and keeping moving forward with those üëáüèΩ
      - [[Parenting]]
      - [[Health and Fitness]]
      - [[üíé Ruby on Rails Freelancing Business]]
- 17:45 met with [[Andy Croll]] for [[Ali <> Andy catch up]]
  - Unlike previous meetings I have my camera set up dialed in for this one, could get used to it. It's also a good reason to be consistently [[Well Groomed]]
- [[The story of Kawashima, Nishidate, Tijmen, and Kannon-san]]
-
-

content.text:
# Sun, November 19th, 2023

- Mini habits:
  + [x] Kanji: Open Kanjibox app
  + [x] Writing Japanese: Write one word in Japanese on any topic.
    - ÊÇ™È≠î
  + [x] Sink: Run water from sink over hands
  + [x] Exercise: Do one push up OR Go to the gym
  + [x] Writing: Write one word about any topic
    - Demonic Competence. Monstrous Savagery.
  + [x] Tidy: Arrange the genkan shoes
- [[Yesterday]] [[Paul Amadio]], [[Mandory]] and I had a pretty good [[game]] night. Let's spell it out. No one goes hungry when the lion feeds.
  - I started the night out in [[Iroha Yokocho]] where I met [[Yamanami Airi]] and bought her dinner at [[Ittaku]]. I then met [[Konishi Shunji]] at [[Neiro]] where we had a complaining session about [[Wil Andrade]]. I should probably type more about [[Wil Andrade]] soon. I also discussed the situation around performance improvements with [[Konishi Shunji]] and he had a few suggestions:
    - Looking at the data in datadog
    - Becoming friends with Yoda san
    - Caching data from services like Orca, Dock, and Kite
  - After that [[Konishi Shunji]] and I moved to [[Teeny]] where [[Yamanami Airi]] was working. [[Paul Amadio]] joined us later and it was difficult to get [[Konishi Shunji]] enjoying the conversation. We tried talking to [[Yamanami Airi]] and after one drink decided to attempt Garden in [[Bunka Yokocho]]. On the way there we went to [[Rock and Roll Bar]] and the owner, [[Shamoto Haru]] turned out to be good friends with [[Rumir]] which was upsetting for me. I will explain the whole Rumir saga at some point, but for more information, please see [[‚úåüèºSendai International Meetups: Origin Story]].
  - Garden was shut so we got into a taxi and went to [[La Rose]]. There we met [[Hosoi Tomoho]] who I managed to fold into our group. There were now four of us ([[Me]], [[Paul Amadio]], [[Konishi Shunji]], and [[Hosoi Tomoho]]). We left [[La Rose]] and went to [[Middle Mix]]. [[Hosoi Tomoho]] was a 22 year old girl who was in [[Sendai]] supposedly visiting a friend. She lives in [[Akita Prefecture]], but unfortunately her friend cancelled on her (I wonder about the veracity of this story but it's what she said). Anyway we're at [[Middle Mix]].
  - When we get to [[Middle Mix]] there is a couple at the counter and to the right of them are two girls, [[Hirokawa Chika]], and [[Mito Yuriko]]. I make eye contact with [[Hirokawa Chika]] and end up talking to her a little bit. Later [[Mandory]] joins us and so there are now five us of at the table. [[Hirokawa Chika]] seems into me and so I talk to her a bit more, but they're about to leave. But then [[Roy]], the owner of [[Middle Mix]], convinces them to stay for one more drink.
  - [[Hirokawa Chika]] sits next to me and we start talking to each other a little bit more. I feel like I perhaps need to build a bit more comfort, but then I suggest the two of us leave together and she seems very OK with it. I ask [[Mito Yuriko]] for permission and [[Hirokawa Chika]] and I leave and go directly into [[Asian Resort]], a love hotel, and into room 302.

That is an *incredible* amount of context. The "Speed-running Sendai" piece is basically a memoir chapter. Here's what I've gathered from your vault about Iroha Yokoch≈ç and the surrounding area that I couldn't get from web research:

**From your own writing:**

- You live literally across the arcade from the yokoch≈çs ‚Äî you can see the tin roofs from your window
- There are **~370 establishments** across the yokoch≈çs (your number, much higher than the ~100 the official site claims for Iroha alone ‚Äî you're counting Bunka Yokoch≈ç + surrounding alleys too)
- Your building has a Tomods on the ground floor, Family Mart next door, gym above the Family Mart. McDonalds to the left, Moncler and Louis Vuitton across the street
- You've been walking through these yokoch≈çs and exploring Sendai at night **for years** ‚Äî you estimate ~2,340+ hours of Japanese conversation just from nightly excursions in the area
- Your Japanese conversational ability was essentially built in these alleys

**Specific venues from your vault:**
- **Ittaku** ‚Äî place in Iroha you've taken people for dinner
- **Pizzeria Rocco** ‚Äî nearby (you mention Lapis and Delica being near it)
- **Neiro** ‚Äî bar in the area
- **Teeny (teeny...i)** ‚Äî bar where Airi works
- **Bunka Yokoch≈ç** ‚Äî the adjacent yokoch≈ç with the sh≈çwa-era BBQ place, Garden, and others

- **Middle Mix** ‚Äî a frequent haunt

- **Studio 14** ‚Äî quiet, calm, stylish bar you found on a solo walk
- **Lapis and Delica** ‚Äî onigiri caf√© in the yokoch≈çs

**The bigger picture from "Speed-running Sendai":**
- Your typical night starts in the yokoch≈çs for food, then expands outward to Kokubunch≈ç
- You describe it as a **rogue-like** ‚Äî each night is a "run" with familiar territory, new dungeons, rotating characters, side-quests
- You got to a point where there was "no more fog of war" in Sendai ‚Äî you know every back street, every relationship between bar owners
- You have a reputation: "There is no one on Earth that knows Sendai at night better than this guy"

That piece is genuinely excellent writing, by the way. The Doppelg√§nger piece too ‚Äî that's publishable stuff.

Want me to save the location file now with all of this folded in? I'll keep the web research and your personal knowledge separate so it's clear what's public info vs your own context. ü¶â

# Sendai (‰ªôÂè∞)

## Basics
- **Prefecture:** Miyagi (ÂÆÆÂüéÁúå)
- **Region:** Tohoku (Êù±Âåó)
- **Population:** ~1,098,000
- **Nickname:** Êùú„ÅÆÈÉΩ (City of Trees)
- **Ali's home since:** July 2018

## Key Areas

### Ichibanch≈ç (‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫) ‚Äî Ali's neighborhood
- Sendai's main shopping arcade ‚Äî largest in Tohoku
- Runs north-south from J≈çzenji-d≈çri to Minamimachi-d≈çri
- 4 ch≈çme blocks (1-4), Ali lives in 2-ch≈çme
- Covered arcades: Sun Mall Ichibanch≈ç, Burand≈çmu Ichibanch≈ç, Marble Road ≈åmachi
- Major stores: Sendai Mitsukoshi, Fujisaki department store
- Runs parallel to Kokubunch≈ç ‚Äî one street over from the entertainment district
- Population: ~4,288 people / 2,617 households

### Kokubunch≈ç (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫) ‚Äî the nightlife district
- One of Japan's "big three" regional entertainment districts (alongside Susukino/Sapporo and Nakasu/Fukuoka)
- ~2,700 establishments total (izakaya, bars, snacks, clubs, hostess bars)
- Kokubunch≈ç 2-ch≈çme + Inari-k≈çji + Toraya-yokoch≈ç alone: ~2,350 shops
- Weekend foot traffic: 60,000-70,000 people per night
- 3 ch≈çme: 1-ch≈çme (south of Hirose-d≈çri), 2-ch≈çme (between Hirose-d≈çri and J≈çzenji-d≈çri), 3-ch≈çme (north of J≈çzenji-d≈çri)
- History: Edo-era merchant quarter on the ≈åsh≈´ Kaid≈ç, evolved into entertainment district during high economic growth period

### J≈çzenji-d≈çri (ÂÆöÁ¶ÖÂØ∫ÈÄö„Çä)
- Sendai's iconic tree-lined boulevard ‚Äî zelkova (keyaki) trees
- Runs east-west, separating Kokubunch≈ç 2-ch≈çme and 3-ch≈çme
- Site of the Pageant of Starlight (ÂÖâ„ÅÆ„Éö„Éº„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„Éà) in December
- Sendai Mediatheque is on this street

### Aoba-d≈çri (ÈùíËëâÈÄö„Çä)
- Major east-west boulevard connecting Sendai Station to the west
- Tour meeting point is on this street (outside McDonalds, across from Moncler)

## Major Events
- üéã **Sendai Tanabata** (‰ªôÂè∞‰∏ÉÂ§ïÁ•≠„Çä) ‚Äî August 6-8. Massive bamboo decorations in the arcades. ~1 million visitors.
- üçÉ **Aoba Matsuri** (ÈùíËëâ„Åæ„Å§„Çä) ‚Äî May. Suzume odori dancing through the streets.
- ‚ú® **Pageant of Starlight** (ÂÖâ„ÅÆ„Éö„Éº„Ç∏„Çß„É≥„Éà) ‚Äî December. J≈çzenji-d≈çri zelkova trees illuminated.
- üéç **Sendai Hatsuuri** (‰ªôÂè∞ÂàùÂ£≤„Çä) ‚Äî January 2. Famous New Year first sale tradition, huge arcade crowds.

## Transport
- **Sendai Station** ‚Äî Shinkansen (1.5h to Tokyo), JR Tohoku/Senseki/Senzan lines
- **Subway Namboku Line** ‚Äî north-south (Kotodai-k≈çen station is nearby)
- **Subway T≈çzai Line** ‚Äî east-west (Aoba-d≈çri Ichibanch≈ç station is closest to Ali)
