# Japan at Night ‚Äî Tour Business

## Overview
Ali runs **private izakaya & bar tours** in Sendai, listed on Viator and TripAdvisor.
- **Brand:** Japan at Night
- **Viator:** https://www.viator.com/tours/Sendai/Best-of-Sendai-Izakaya-and-Bar-Tour/d50597-5507426P1
- **TripAdvisor:** https://www.tripadvisor.com/AttractionProductReview-g298249-d28537297-Sendai_Private_Izakaya_and_Bar_Tour-Sendai_Miyagi_Prefecture_Tohoku.html
- **Twitter:** @japanatnight
- **Domain:** japanatnight.tours
- **Price:** From $99.49/person (varies by group size)
- **Duration:** 3-5 hours
- **Meeting point:** Outside McDonalds on Aoba-dori (across from Moncler), Ichibanch≈ç
- **Itinerary stops:** Iroha Yokocho (~3h), Bunka Yokocho (~2h), ends in Kokubuncho
- **Languages:** English, Japanese
- **Booked 39 days in advance on average**

## Reviews (as of 2026-02-01)
**4.8 overall** ‚Äî 25 reviews combined (Viator + TripAdvisor). 24 five-star, 1 one-star.

### Viator Reviews (9)

**paulrsd** (Mar 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê
"This is among our favorite food and bar crawls in Japan, Italy and Greece. Ali knows his way around and each stop has quality authenticity and personality. Do not miss this is Sendai. Enough said!"
> Host reply: "You were both an absolute delight to go out on the town with, I couldn't ask for better guests! I particularly enjoyed Dream On and Hotel California that we sang with the gaggle of salarymen that gatecrashed our last venue."

**Calder_L** (Mar 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "The only way to experience Sendai at night"
"Ali showed all the hidden experiences that only a local would really know. I couldn't have had a better experience than the one Ali provided without living and breathing Sendai for at least 10 years."

**mariannecreverett** (Feb 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Best evening out!"
"We had the best night out in Japan so far! Ali was really helpful in finding places that were tailored to us specifically, including managing dietary requirements and we loved all the different bars he took us too."
> Host reply mentioned guests singing Yoasobi's „Ç¢„Ç§„Éâ„É´

**Humera_S** (Jan 2025) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Unique and fun tour! Ali is VERY easy to talk to and is friends with all the shop owners :)"
"I was nervous to book this tour because of the few reviews, but I'm glad I did. I had a fantastic tour with Ali! He is incredibly kind and charismatic. He took us around to different restaurants/bars and tailored the evening to our interests. It was just my husband, myself and Ali, because Ali is easy to talk to and clearly has a knack as a host, it wasn't awkward! We had a great time drinking cocktails and eating delicious food. Ali took us to places that seemed to be locals only. The owners at all the spots were excited to see him and would enthusiastically greet us. Ali was an excellent host and this tour was well worth the cost. I can't imagine a better way of exploring the Sendai food scene!"

**Samuel_R** (Dec 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Best night out imaginable"
"This was an absolutely amazing and fantastic experience. I had a blast all night. The tour was fully customised to the experience I was after and what I liked. Ali, truly knows all the best spots in Sendai, it was an experience I would not easily forget. The variety of places I was taken to was amazing, I had such a unique and wonderful experience in each. I really do recommend this to anyone who is looking for a great time. It's a 10/10."

**Alex_W** (Dec 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Please Book This Tour"
"I could not recommend this tour enough. One of my most memorable nights out ever. Ali was fantastic and very knowledgable of the area. He was flexible and was able to accommodate our interests as they arose throughout the evening. Everywhere we went was a unique and wonderful experience. He was super friendly and charismatic. It's easy to see that he really knows the locals well and that they know and like him too which was really nice. I would have never found these places without him. Also, Ali made sure we both got home safe at the end of the evening as well, which we really appreciated."

**Elbert_L** (Nov 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Great night out in Sendai"
"Ali was a fantastic guide, very knowledgeable of the local food/drink scene and close connections with the owners. The places we went to were all amazing, and the energy was good through the night"

**Curtis_A** (Nov 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Best of Sendai"
"Private tour through Sendai. I really like that Ali takes the time before the tour to arrange an itinerary that caters to your interests. We visited a few hole in the wall eating and drinking spots, each with its own specialty. Many of these places have limited seating usually reserved for locals, but Ali helps get you in to try these hidden gems that a tourist might otherwise struggle to visit themselves. Ali is very knowledgeable about the area and even gave me some recommendations for places to visit later in my trip. I've been on a few eating and drinking tours around Japan, but this was my favorite by far. Small private groups let's you enjoy Sendai with the locals instead of being put to just the tourist table."

**Andy_G** (Nov 2024) ‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê ‚Äî "Great guide!"
"Ali showed us a great time taking us to places we would have never gotten to on our own. Would recommend!"

### TripAdvisor Reviews (visible ‚Äî 5 of 16)

**Dan L** (Apr 2025) ‚Äî "We had a fantastic time with our tour guide Ali in Sendai, Japan. He took us to five different restaurants and bars, each offering unique local flavors and experiences we wouldn't have found on our own. Ali is incredibly knowledgeable about the area and its food scene, and his friendly, easygoing nature made the evening fun and relaxed. It was clear he has strong connections with the local community, which added an authentic touch to the tour."

**wanderwallah** (Apr 2025) ‚Äî "Ali was very engaging and really knows his stuff - so much so that all the managers and staff at the Izakayas and bars we went to, know him well so we got personal service. He also adapted the tour to my preferences so the experience was more than I could have hoped for."

**Fredrik L** (Apr 2025) ‚Äî "Friendly tour with good food and drinks. We got to see a lot great small places that we'd never find ourselves and all of them represented a different niche of the japanese culture!"

**LeanneK** (Mar 2025) ‚Äî "Ali was exceptionally informative and professional throughout the booking, tour itself and follow up the next day when we returned to a bar with friends. He has a great rapport with the bar owners and understanding and respect of Japanese culture. No question was off limits and answered honestly which immensely helped our understanding of Japanese culture and customs. Great value for money."

**KC** (Feb 2025) ‚Äî "Ali speaks fluent Japanese and asks if you have any requests after booking. I went to several small shops that day, all of which came from the locals, and Ali booked a seat in advance, no wait. Things are delicious, Japanese wine and cocktails are great, and the atmosphere in several shops is good, very local. Ali also explains cuisine and drinks. Very pleasant experience."

## Automation
- **Daily Viator Sync** (cron, 15:00 JST): Checks `from:(booking@t1.viator.com)` for new bookings/amendments/cancellations, updates calendar events, updates this file. Sends WhatsApp alert ONLY if there's a tour that same evening.
- Cron job ID: `ec605f73-49b9-4b92-a6c3-289ced0f5fb4`

## Viator Email Filter

## Common Themes in Reviews

- **Safety** ‚Äî makes sure guests get home safe
- **Bilingual edge** ‚Äî fluent Japanese opens doors that other guides can't

# Yokocho (Ê®™‰∏Å) Mentions in Ali's Obsidian Vault

Summary of all yokocho-related content found across the vault, organized by topic.

---

## 1. Overview & Geography

Ali lives directly adjacent to the yokochos in central Sendai. His apartment is on a shopping arcade (Ichibancho), and stepping straight across the arcade puts him in front of **Bunka Yokocho** and **Iroha Yokocho**. He describes them as "picturesque Japanese side-streets packed with tiny little bars and restaurants that can only fit seven or eight people" with **around 370 establishments** in total. From his window he can see the arcade canopy and the tin roofs of the yokochos.

**Kokubuncho** (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫) is about a 7-minute walk further up the arcade ‚Äî the central entertainment district with hostess clubs, girls bars, snack bars, and regular drinking spots.

**Sources:**
- `reflect-import/.../Speed-running Sendai.md` (detailed geographic walkthrough)
- `Something Else.md` (mermaid diagram mapping Ali ‚Üí Bunka Yokocho, Kokubuncho, etc.)

## 4. Personal Experiences & Stories

### Daily Life in the Yokochos
Ali estimates he spent **~2,340+ hours** socializing in the iroha-yokocho area over five years (3 nights/week, 3 hours/night, 52 weeks √ó 5 years), with the real number likely double that. This is a core part of how he learned conversational Japanese.
- **Source:** `Japanese Conversation Article.md`

### "Another Day in My Strange Life in Japan" (Major Essay)
A detailed narrative of a single day featuring:
- Visiting **Yabe Sakaba** to see "Sakurai daddy" (paternal figure)
- Eating roast potatoes at **The Steamers** with Masumi
- A chaotic dinner at **Tori Yoshi** where he helps American tourists, Indonesian/Taiwanese academics, and deals with a rude host ‚Äî then encounters Shuko (the ear-licker) at the door
- Drinking shochu at **Jaco** ‚Äî story of Shuko licking his ear leading to hearing loss, eventually resolved by an ENT pulling out a massive earwax creature
- **History lesson:** Post-WWII, Iroha-yokocho emerged as two streets (market + restaurants/bars), administered by the Matsuo-gumi Yakuza. The yakitori restaurant Tori Yoshi was founded ~35 years ago by a young yakuza captain (_wakagashira_)
- **Source:** `Another day in my strange life in Japan.md`

### Speed-Running Sendai (Major Essay)
Epic narrative of a typical night out:
- Starts at a shochu bar in the yokochos, then beef BBQ at "bunyoko" in Bunka Yokocho
- Leaves yokochos ‚Üí Toichi Ichiba ‚Üí standing izakaya ‚Üí authentic cocktail bar ‚Üí Den of Evil snack bar in Kokubuncho ‚Üí hostess club ‚Üí near-altercation with yakuza guy ‚Üí encounter with "Retsuko-mama" (the "last boss" of Kokubuncho)
- Frames Sendai nightlife as a **rogue-like video game** ‚Äî each night is a "run" with familiar territory, new dungeons, skill-building, and character encounters
- **Source:** `reflect-import/.../Speed-running Sendai.md`

### The Doppleganger
- Attends Ikemoto-san's retirement party across from his flat, starting at Airi's whisky bar (teeny...i)
- Champagne tower at a venue in **Bunka Yokocho** ‚Äî "one of the oldest drinking alleys in Sendai"
- Ikemoto ordered expensive sushi from a traditional place across the street

# Iroha Yokocho (Â£±ÂºêÂèÇÊ®™‰∏Å / „ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØÊ®™‰∏Å) ‚Äî Sendai, Japan

> A Showa-era alleyway market in the heart of Sendai's Ichibancho arcade, home to ~100 tiny shops, bars, and restaurants.

## Location & Access

- **Address:** 2-3-28 Ichiban-cho, Aoba-ku, Sendai, Miyagi (‰ªôÂè∞Â∏ÇÈùíËëâÂå∫‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫2-3-28)
- **Nearest station:** Aoba-dori Ichibancho Station (ÈùíËëâÈÄö‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫ÈßÖ) on the Tozai subway line ‚Äî **1-3 min walk**
- **From JR Sendai Station:** ~12 min walk west through the covered arcade streets (Clis Road ‚Üí Marble Road ‚Üí Sun Mall Ichibancho)
- **How to find it:** Walk through the Sun Mall Ichibancho („Çµ„É≥„É¢„Éº„É´‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫) arcade and look for narrow entrances on the sides. It's easy to miss ‚Äî the entrances are between shops on the main arcade. The yokocho runs perpendicular to the arcade.
- **Official website:** [iroha-yokocho.jp](http://www.iroha-yokocho.jp/en/)
- **Phone:** 022-223-3151
- **Official name:** Chuo Ichiba Shogyo Kyodo Kumiai (‰∏≠Â§ÆÂ∏ÇÂ†¥ÂïÜÊ•≠ÂçîÂêåÁµÑÂêà)

## History & Origins

### Post-war Black Market (1945‚Äì1946)

Iroha Yokocho's story begins in the ashes of World War II. On July 10, 1945, the Sendai Air Raids (‰ªôÂè∞Á©∫Ë•≤) devastated the city center, leaving it a burnt wasteland. In the rubble, survivors began laying out wooden doors and straw mats to sell whatever remained ‚Äî scorched ceramics, wooden clogs (geta), and daily necessities. This improvised open-air market became one of Sendai's post-war "black markets" (ÈóáÂ∏Ç / yami-ichi).

### Central Public Market (1946)

In **August 1946 (Showa 21)**, the street vendors pooled resources to formally establish the **Chuo Kosetsu Ichiba (‰∏≠Â§ÆÂÖ¨Ë®≠Â∏ÇÂ†¥)** ‚Äî a "Central Public Market." It was conceived as a *temporary* structure for merchants to sell goods while the city rebuilt. Nearly 80 years later, it's still "temporary" ‚Äî the yokocho was never formally redeveloped, which is part of its charm.

### Evolution to the Present

Over the decades, the market gradually transformed:
- **Early years:** Fresh food shops (butchers, fishmongers, greengrocers), daily necessities, clothing
- **Mid-Showa:** Drinking establishments and restaurants began to appear alongside the retail shops
- **Modern era:** Mix of legacy shops, trendy newcomers, wine bars, Italian restaurants, vintage clothing stores

The yokocho faced multiple threats of redevelopment over the years and suffered damage in the **2011 Great East Japan Earthquake**. During post-earthquake repairs, gas lines and sewage were fixed and ‚Äî crucially ‚Äî the **toilets were renovated**. The cooperative's chairman credits this with attracting younger and female customers, transforming the clientele from mostly older regulars to a diverse crowd.

### Name Origin

The kanji Â£±ÂºêÂèÇ (ichi-ni-san / 1-2-3) are read as "i-ro-ha" ‚Äî the first three characters of the traditional Japanese syllabary order („ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØ„Å´„Åª„Å∏„Å®), similar to saying "ABC." The name evokes something fundamental and foundational.

---

## Layout & Atmosphere

### Physical Structure

- **Two parallel covered alleyways** running roughly north-south, connected at points
- **Aoba Alley (ÈùíËëâÂ∞èË∑Ø):** The corridor closer to Aoba-dori. Originally hosted clothing and item shops.
- **Matsu-Take Alley (ÊùæÁ´πÂ∞èË∑Ø / Pine and Bamboo Alley):** The other corridor, originally the restaurant/drinking side. 
- Both are now a mix of everything
- **Covered with a low roof** ‚Äî protected from rain, walkable year-round
- Approximately **100 shops** line the narrow passages

### Vibe

The atmosphere is deeply **Showa-retro** (Êò≠Âíå„É¨„Éà„É≠). Narrow corridors barely wide enough for two people to pass. Hand-painted signs, neon lights, paper lanterns. Many shops are so small they seat only 6-10 people ‚Äî you'll literally rub elbows with locals.

Key features:
- **Hand-pump well (ÊâãÊäº„Åó„Éù„É≥„Éó):** A functioning well from 1948, used until the 1980s for washing and even for the eel restaurant to purge eels. Featured on NHK's *Buratamori* („Éñ„É©„Çø„É¢„É™) when Tamori visited.
- **Old photographs** displayed near the well showing the yokocho's history
- **Mix of old and new:** A 1868-founded unagi restaurant next to a trendy natural wine bar
- **Intimate scale:** The tiny shop sizes create an atmosphere where strangers become friends over drinks

### Cultural Cameos

- **Buratamori („Éñ„É©„Çø„É¢„É™):** Tamori visited to see the historic well
- **Saito Kazuyoshi (ÊñâËó§ÂíåÁæ©):** Shot a music video here; fans still come to photograph the same spots
- **Cyndi Lauper:** Has visited the yokocho
- The yokocho has become a popular film/photo location registered with the Sendai-Miyagi Film Commission

## Nearby Yokocho & Drinking Areas

Sendai is exceptionally rich in yokocho culture for a city its size. The main ones near Iroha Yokocho:

### Bunka Yokocho (ÊñáÂåñÊ®™‰∏Å) ‚Äî "Culture Alley"
- **Distance:** ~40m north of Iroha Yokocho (1 min walk)
- **History:** Named after "Bunka Kinema" (ÊñáÂåñ„Ç≠„Éç„Éû), a movie theater that stood here from **1925 (Taisho 14)**. The alley's predecessor was called "Higashi Hyakken-dana-gai" (Êù±ÁôæËªíÂ∫óË°ó), also from the Taisho era.
- **Vibe:** Affectionately called "Bun-Yoko" („Éñ„É≥„É®„Ç≥). Two alleys in a backwards "h" shape. Strictly food and drink ‚Äî no retail. More evening-focused than Iroha.
- **~50+ establishments**
- **Famous spots:**
  - **Hassen (ÂÖ´‰ªô):** Sendai's most famous gyoza shop. Thin-skinned, juice-bursting dumplings.
  - **Nanbu Iroha:** Welcoming izakaya specializing in oden and sake
  - **SUN:** Western-style fare paired with Tohoku sake
  - **Sakaiya:** Curry shop, one of the few open during daytime
  - **London-kan:** Old-school caf√©
  - **Suzu-ya („Åô„Åö„ÇÑ):** Trendy monaka (sweet wafer) shop, Instagram-famous. Self-serve matcha.
  - **Maroudo (Ë≥ì):** Opens at 1pm ‚Äî serious daytime drinking with sashimi and kushiage
  - **Shushu (ÈÖíË∂£):** Bar-like atmosphere, excellent heated sake and seasonal food

### Kokubuncho (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫) ‚Äî Tohoku's Largest Entertainment District
- **Distance:** ~5-10 min walk north
- **Scale:** ~2,700 bars, restaurants, clubs, and nightlife establishments. ~2,350 in the core area of Kokubuncho 2-chome + Inari Koji + Toraya Yokocho alone.
- **Vibe:** Sendai's answer to Kabukicho/Susukino/Nakasu. Glitzy, loud, everything from izakaya to hostess clubs. Weekend foot traffic: 60,000-70,000 per night.
- Compared to the intimate, retro yokocho, Kokubuncho is the big, flashy entertainment district.

### Inari Koji (Á®≤Ëç∑Â∞èË∑Ø)
- **Location:** Runs north-south between Jozenji-dori and Hirose-dori, within the Kokubuncho area
- **Named after:** Inari Shrine at its center (vermillion torii, fox statues) ‚Äî people pray for fire safety, family health, business success
- **Vibe:** Nightlife yokocho with larger establishments than Iroha/Bunka. Most open after dark.
- **Famous:** Home to **Aji Tasuke (Âë≥Â§™Âä©)**, the shop that *invented* Sendai gyutan (beef tongue) ‚Äî an absolute must-visit.

### Toraya Yokocho (ËôéÂ±ãÊ®™‰∏Å)
- **Location:** Connects Kokubuncho and Higashi Ichibancho
- **History:** Named after a pharmacy called "Toraya" (Tiger Shop) that had a tiger statue at its entrance. **Dates back to the Edo period.**
- **Notable:** HIGHBALL BAR Mori no Miyako 1923 ‚Äî craft highball specialist

### Sendai Ginza (‰ªôÂè∞ÈäÄÂ∫ß)
- **Location:** Near Sendai Station (5 min walk)
- **Vibe:** Another Showa-retro drinking alley. Smaller and even more intimate than Iroha Yokocho.

### Other Modern Yokocho
- **Sendai Mirain Yokocho (‰ªôÂè∞„Åø„Çâ„ÅÑ„ÇìÊ®™‰∏Å):** Near Sendai Station. Building-style yokocho with mobile ordering across all shops. (As of late 2025, only one ramen shop operating.)
- **Itsutsubashi Yokocho (‰∫îÊ©ãÊ®™‰∏Å):** 2 min from Sendai Station. Three shops with cross-ordering system.

---

## Practical Information

### Hours
- **Daytime shops** (retail, caf√©s, lunch spots): Generally 10:00‚Äì18:00 or so
- **Restaurants & bars:** Most open 17:00‚Äì24:00 (midnight)
- **Some late-night spots** (e.g., Izakaya Arajiru): Until ~3:00am
- **Lunch:** Some restaurants serve lunch 11:30‚Äì15:00 (e.g., Pizzeria Rocco, Teppan ≈åyama)
- **Closed days vary by shop** ‚Äî many are closed Sundays or have irregular holidays

### Best Times to Visit
- **Lunchtime (11:30‚Äì14:00):** Quieter, good for exploring. Office workers grab lunch. Some shops lunch-only.
- **Evening (18:00‚Äì22:00):** Peak atmosphere. Lanterns lit, neon glowing, lively buzz. This is when the yokocho truly comes alive.
- **Weekday evenings:** More local feel, easier to get seats
- **Weekend evenings:** Busier, some popular spots fill up fast (reserve Nidaime, Watabe)

### Tips
- üí¥ **Cash is king.** Many establishments are cash-only. Bring yen.
- üç∫ **Small portions, many stops.** The yokocho is built for bar-hopping („ÅØ„Åó„ÅîÈÖí). Don't fill up at one place.
- ü™ë **Expect tiny spaces.** Most shops seat 6-10 people. Go solo or in pairs ‚Äî groups of 4+ will struggle.
- üöª **Clean public toilets** available throughout (renovated post-2011 earthquake).
- üó£Ô∏è **Japanese helps a lot.** Most shops are run by locals with minimal English. But the intimate setting means people are friendly and will try to communicate.
- üì∏ **Photogenic.** The retro aesthetic is incredibly atmospheric, especially at night.
- üçï **Start with Rocco for pizza + cheap wine**, then work your way through izakaya.
- ü¶™ **Oyster bars open at 3pm** ‚Äî a great afternoon start before the evening rush.

### Suggested Route
1. Arrive around 15:00‚Äì17:00
2. Start at **Kaki-goya Rocco** for ¬•110 oysters and a beer
3. Move to **Pizzeria Rocco** for a pizza and ¬•110 wine
4. Hit **Izakaya Chie** for the legendary ¬•1,000 set
5. Finish at **Jodan Sakaba Ippo** or **Budoshu-goya** for a nightcap
6. If still standing, walk to **Bunka Yokocho** for gyoza at Hassen

---

## Cultural Significance

Iroha Yokocho represents something increasingly rare in modern Japan: an organic, unplanned urban space that has survived decades of redevelopment pressure. In a city where high-rise buildings dominate the skyline, these low-roofed, cramped alleyways are a living connection to post-war Sendai.

The yokocho embodies:
- **Post-war resilience:** Born from the ashes of air raids, built by ordinary people
- **Showa nostalgia:** A physical space where the Showa era never ended
- **Community continuity:** Shops passed down through generations, regulars who've been coming for decades
- **Democratic drinking culture:** Tiny bars where CEOs sit next to construction workers
- **Sendai identity:** Along with gyutan and Tanabata, the yokocho is a symbol of what makes Sendai distinct

The cooperative has actively worked to preserve the yokocho's character while making it accessible to new generations ‚Äî renovating infrastructure without modernizing the aesthetic.

---

## Recent News & Changes

- **Post-earthquake renovation (2011+):** Infrastructure repairs after the Great East Japan Earthquake led to modernized plumbing and clean toilets, which significantly boosted female and young visitors.
- **Growing tourism profile:** Featured in numerous travel publications, TV shows, and tourist campaigns. Now firmly on the Sendai sightseeing circuit.
- **New-generation shops:** While legacy shops like ≈åsh≈ç (est. 1946) and Akebono (est. 1868) continue, newer establishments like Stand ≈åtomo, natural wine bars, and craft caf√©s are joining, creating an interesting generational mix.
- **Bar-hopping tours:** Commercial walking tours (e.g., Sendai Experience, Tohoku Local Secret Tours) now include Iroha & Bunka Yokocho as key stops.
- **Asahi Shimbun feature (August 2025):** "ÁÑº„ÅëÈáéÂéü„Å´„Åß„Åç„ÅüÂ£±ÂºêÂèÇÊ®™‰∏Å" ‚Äî a piece on the history and human stories behind the yokocho, noting that few people today know its wartime origins.
- **Low rents** continue to attract young entrepreneurs, keeping the mix of old and new vibrant.

---

# Iroha Yokocho (Â£±ÂºêÂèÇÊ®™‰∏Å)

## Basics
- **Address:** 2-3-28 Ichibancho, Aoba-ku, Sendai (‰ªôÂè∞Â∏ÇÈùíËëâÂå∫‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫2-3-28)
- **Nearest station:** Aoba-dori Ichibancho (ÈùíËëâÈÄö‰∏ÄÁï™Áî∫ÈßÖ) ‚Äî 1 min walk
- **Official name:** Chuo Ichiba Shogyo Kyodo Kumiai (‰∏≠Â§ÆÂ∏ÇÂ†¥ÂïÜÊ•≠ÂçîÂêåÁµÑÂêà)
- **Website:** [iroha-yokocho.jp](http://www.iroha-yokocho.jp/en/)
- **Shops:** ~100 establishments across two parallel covered alleyways
- **Ali's relationship:** Home turf ‚Äî literally steps from his apartment (City House 506). Estimated 2,340+ hours spent here over 5 years. Core to his Japanese fluency, social life, tour business, and memoir.

## Layout
- Two parallel covered alleyways running roughly north-south, perpendicular to the Sun Mall Ichibancho arcade
- **Aoba Alley (ÈùíËëâÂ∞èË∑Ø):** Closer to Aoba-dori. Originally clothing/item shops.
- **Matsu-Take Alley (ÊùæÁ´πÂ∞èË∑Ø):** Originally the restaurant/drinking side. Both now mixed.
- Low roof, narrow corridors barely wide enough for two people. Most shops seat 6-10.
- Entrances are easy to miss ‚Äî look for narrow gaps between arcade shops.

## History
- **1945:** Sendai Air Raids (July 10) devastated the city. Survivors laid out wooden doors and straw mats to sell goods in the rubble ‚Äî the original black market (ÈóáÂ∏Ç).
- **1946:** Vendors formally established the Chuo Kosetsu Ichiba (‰∏≠Â§ÆÂÖ¨Ë®≠Â∏ÇÂ†¥) ‚Äî a "temporary" public market. Still "temporary" 80 years later.
- **Post-war:** Administered by the Matsuo-gumi Yakuza. The yakitori institution Tori Yoshi was founded ~35 years ago by a young yakuza captain (wakagashira).
- **Mid-Showa:** Gradually shifted from fresh food retail to a mix of drinking spots and shops.
- **2011:** Damaged in the Great East Japan Earthquake. Repairs modernized plumbing and toilets ‚Äî credited with attracting younger and female customers.
- **Name origin:** Â£±ÂºêÂèÇ (ichi-ni-san / 1-2-3) read as "i-ro-ha" ‚Äî the first three characters of the traditional Japanese syllabary, like saying "ABC."

## Vibe
Deeply Showa-retro (Êò≠Âíå„É¨„Éà„É≠). Hand-painted signs, neon lights, paper lanterns. Cramped, intimate, democratic ‚Äî CEOs next to construction workers. A functioning 1948 hand-pump well still exists (featured on Buratamori when Tamori visited). Cyndi Lauper has been here. Saito Kazuyoshi shot a music video here.

## Ali's Spots

| Venue | Type | Notes |
|-------|------|-------|
| **teeny...i** | Whisky bar | Run by Yamanami Airi. Ali's regular. |
| **The Steamers** | Bar/restaurant | Famous roast potatoes. Masumi runs it. |
| **Tori Yoshi** | Yakitori | Institution. ~70yo mama, hard of hearing. Yakuza-founded. |
| **Jodan Sakaba** | Oden/sake bar | Where Ali's yokocho journey began. Widest sake selection. |
| **Yabe Sakaba** | Bar | "Sakurai daddy's" place ‚Äî paternal figure to Ali. |
| **Ittaku** | Italian/wine bar | Casual. Appetizer plate ¬•580, wine from ¬•450. |
| **Jaco** | Shochu bar | Site of the infamous ear-licking incident. |
| **‰∏≠Âêâ (Nakayoshi)** | Bar | Met the owner with Phil, Johnny, Ryan. |
| **The Well** | Bar | Met Jon here. |
| **Mizu Shobai** | Venue | Listed in Ali's yokocho notes. |
| **Pizzeria Rocco** | Wood-fired pizza | ¬•600 pizza, ¬•110/glass wine. Always packed. Arguably the most famous shop. |

## Other Notable Shops

| Venue | Known For |
|-------|-----------|
| **Izakaya Chie (Â±ÖÈÖíÂ±ã„ÉÅ„Ç®)** | "Face of Iroha Yokocho." Beijing-born mama, 20 years running. ¬•1,000 set: 5 dishes + 1 drink. |
| **Kaki-goya Rocco / Moikko** | Standing oyster bars. Miyagi oysters at ¬•110 each. Open from 3pm. |
| **Stand ≈åtomo („Çπ„Çø„É≥„Éâ„Ç™„Ç™„Éà„É¢)** | Neo-izakaya, standing drinks. Instagram-worthy. Sister shop: Hasamiya ≈åtomo (sandwiches). |
| **Izakaya Nidaime (Â±ÖÈÖíÂ±ã‰∫å‰ª£ÁõÆ)** | Whale sashimi, horse sashimi, local sake. Reserve ahead. |
| **Budoshu-goya (Ëë°ËêÑÈÖíÂ∞èÂ±ã)** | "Wine Hut." Casual, younger crowd. Glasses from ¬•550. |
| **Akebono (Êòé„Åº‰πÉ)** | Unagi restaurant, **founded 1868**. One of the oldest businesses. |
| **≈åsh≈ç (ÁéãÂ∞Ü)** | Open since **1946**. 2nd-gen mama. Stories of post-war US soldiers. |
| **Teppan ≈åyama („Å¶„Å£„Å±„ÇìÂ§ßÂ±±)** | Great lunch sets (sashimi teishoku ¬•1,000). Husband-and-wife team. |

## Practical
- üí¥ **Cash is king.** Many shops are cash-only.
- ü™ë **Go solo or in pairs.** Groups of 4+ will struggle with the tiny spaces.
- üïï **Best time:** Evenings 18:00‚Äì22:00 for full atmosphere. Some lunch spots open 11:30‚Äì15:00.
- ü¶™ **Oyster bars open at 3pm** ‚Äî good afternoon kickoff before the evening rush.
- üçï **Classic route:** Oysters at Kaki-goya ‚Üí pizza at Rocco ‚Üí Izakaya Chie's ¬•1,000 set ‚Üí nightcap at Jodan Sakaba or Budoshu-goya.

## Nearby
- **Bunka Yokocho (ÊñáÂåñÊ®™‰∏Å):** 40m north, ~50 establishments. Named after Bunka Kinema movie theater (1925). Known as "Bun-Yoko." Famous for Hassen's gyoza and Daruma's charcoal yakiniku (since the 70s).
- **Kokubuncho (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫):** 5-10 min walk north. Tohoku's largest entertainment district (~2,700 establishments). See `sendai-overview.md`.
- **Inari Koji (Á®≤Ëç∑Â∞èË∑Ø):** Within Kokubuncho. Home of Aji Tasuke ‚Äî the shop that invented gyutan.
- **Toraya Yokocho (ËôéÂ±ãÊ®™‰∏Å):** Edo-era origins. Named after a pharmacy with a tiger statue.

## In Ali's Writing
- Central setting in his **memoir project** ‚Äî Act 1 chapter "Iroha Yokocho," covering first steps via Jodan Sakaba
- Featured in essays: "Speed-running Sendai" (nightlife as roguelike), "Another day in my strange life in Japan"
- Core of the **Japan at Night** tour (Iroha ~3h ‚Üí Bunka ~2h ‚Üí Kokubuncho)
- Ali has drafted a **dream bar menu** for a hypothetical yokocho spot: omelettes, roast potatoes, marmite toast, nihari-style curry

- **Website:** [iroha-yokocho.jp](http://www.iroha-yokocho.jp/en/)
- **Shops:** ~100 establishments across two parallel covered alleyways
- **Ali's relationship:** Home turf ‚Äî literally steps from his apartment (City House 506). Estimated 2,340+ hours spent here over 5 years. Core to his Japanese fluency, social life, tour business, and memoir.

## Layout
- Two parallel covered alleyways running roughly north-south, perpendicular to the Sun Mall Ichibancho arcade
- **Aoba Alley (ÈùíËëâÂ∞èË∑Ø):** Closer to Aoba-dori. Originally clothing/item shops.
- **Matsu-Take Alley (ÊùæÁ´πÂ∞èË∑Ø):** Originally the restaurant/drinking side. Both now mixed.
- Low roof, narrow corridors barely wide enough for two people. Most shops seat 6-10.
- Entrances are easy to miss ‚Äî look for narrow gaps between arcade shops.

## History
- **1945:** Sendai Air Raids (July 10) devastated the city. Survivors laid out wooden doors and straw mats to sell goods in the rubble ‚Äî the original black market (ÈóáÂ∏Ç).
- **1946:** Vendors formally established the Chuo Kosetsu Ichiba (‰∏≠Â§ÆÂÖ¨Ë®≠Â∏ÇÂ†¥) ‚Äî a "temporary" public market. Still "temporary" 80 years later.
- **Post-war:** Administered by the Matsuo-gumi Yakuza. The yakitori institution Tori Yoshi was founded ~35 years ago by a young yakuza captain (wakagashira).
- **Mid-Showa:** Gradually shifted from fresh food retail to a mix of drinking spots and shops.
- **2011:** Damaged in the Great East Japan Earthquake. Repairs modernized plumbing and toilets ‚Äî credited with attracting younger and female customers.
- **Name origin:** Â£±ÂºêÂèÇ (ichi-ni-san / 1-2-3) read as "i-ro-ha" ‚Äî the first three characters of the traditional Japanese syllabary, like saying "ABC."

## Vibe
Deeply Showa-retro (Êò≠Âíå„É¨„Éà„É≠). Hand-painted signs, neon lights, paper lanterns. Cramped, intimate, democratic ‚Äî CEOs next to construction workers. A functioning 1948 hand-pump well still exists (featured on Buratamori when Tamori visited). Cyndi Lauper has been here. Saito Kazuyoshi shot a music video here.

## Ali's Spots

| Venue | Type | Notes |
|-------|------|-------|

| **The Steamers** | Bar/restaurant | Famous roast potatoes. Masumi runs it. |

| **‰∏≠Âêâ (Nakayoshi)** | Bar | Met the owner with Phil, Johnny, Ryan. |

| **Pizzeria Rocco** | Wood-fired pizza | ¬•600 pizza, ¬•110/glass wine. Always packed. Arguably the most famous shop. |

## Other Notable Shops

| Venue | Known For |
|-------|-----------|
| **Izakaya Chie (Â±ÖÈÖíÂ±ã„ÉÅ„Ç®)** | "Face of Iroha Yokocho." Beijing-born mama, 20 years running. ¬•1,000 set: 5 dishes + 1 drink. |
| **Kaki-goya Rocco / Moikko** | Standing oyster bars. Miyagi oysters at ¬•110 each. Open from 3pm. |
| **Stand ≈åtomo („Çπ„Çø„É≥„Éâ„Ç™„Ç™„Éà„É¢)** | Neo-izakaya, standing drinks. Instagram-worthy. Sister shop: Hasamiya ≈åtomo (sandwiches). |
| **Izakaya Nidaime (Â±ÖÈÖíÂ±ã‰∫å‰ª£ÁõÆ)** | Whale sashimi, horse sashimi, local sake. Reserve ahead. |
| **Budoshu-goya (Ëë°ËêÑÈÖíÂ∞èÂ±ã)** | "Wine Hut." Casual, younger crowd. Glasses from ¬•550. |
| **Akebono (Êòé„Åº‰πÉ)** | Unagi restaurant, **founded 1868**. One of the oldest businesses. |
| **≈åsh≈ç (ÁéãÂ∞Ü)** | Open since **1946**. 2nd-gen mama. Stories of post-war US soldiers. |
| **Teppan ≈åyama („Å¶„Å£„Å±„ÇìÂ§ßÂ±±)** | Great lunch sets (sashimi teishoku ¬•1,000). Husband-and-wife team. |

## Practical
- üí¥ **Cash is king.** Many shops are cash-only.
- ü™ë **Go solo or in pairs.** Groups of 4+ will struggle with the tiny spaces.
- üïï **Best time:** Evenings 18:00‚Äì22:00 for full atmosphere. Some lunch spots open 11:30‚Äì15:00.
- ü¶™ **Oyster bars open at 3pm** ‚Äî good afternoon kickoff before the evening rush.
- üçï **Classic route:** Oysters at Kaki-goya ‚Üí pizza at Rocco ‚Üí Izakaya Chie's ¬•1,000 set ‚Üí nightcap at Jodan Sakaba or Budoshu-goya.

## Nearby
- **Bunka Yokocho (ÊñáÂåñÊ®™‰∏Å):** 40m north, ~50 establishments. Named after Bunka Kinema movie theater (1925). Known as "Bun-Yoko." Famous for Hassen's gyoza and Daruma's charcoal yakiniku (since the 70s).
- **Kokubuncho (ÂõΩÂàÜÁî∫):** 5-10 min walk north. Tohoku's largest entertainment district (~2,700 establishments). See `sendai-overview.md`.
- **Inari Koji (Á®≤Ëç∑Â∞èË∑Ø):** Within Kokubuncho. Home of Aji Tasuke ‚Äî the shop that invented gyutan.
- **Toraya Yokocho (ËôéÂ±ãÊ®™‰∏Å):** Edo-era origins. Named after a pharmacy with a tiger statue.

## In Ali's Writing
- Central setting in his **memoir project** ‚Äî Act 1 chapter "Iroha Yokocho," covering first steps via Jodan Sakaba
- Featured in essays: "Speed-running Sendai" (nightlife as roguelike), "Another day in my strange life in Japan"
- Core of the **Japan at Night** tour (Iroha ~3h ‚Üí Bunka ~2h ‚Üí Kokubuncho)
- Ali has drafted a **dream bar menu** for a hypothetical yokocho spot: omelettes, roast potatoes, marmite toast, nihari-style curry

## Yokocho Knowledge Building Session

Context got compacted at the start ‚Äî lost whatever we'd been discussing about yokochos before. Started fresh.

### Subagent Research
- Spun up two subagents in parallel:
  1. **Internet research** on Iroha Yokocho ‚Äî history, shops, nearby yokochos, practical info ‚Üí `research/iroha-yokocho.md`
  2. **Vault search** for all yokocho mentions across ali-vault (~40 files matched) ‚Üí `research/yokocho-vault-mentions.md`
- Both completed successfully. Rich findings on both sides.

### Created `locations/iroha-yokocho.md`
- Modeled after existing `locations/sendai-overview.md` style
- Blended internet research with Ali's personal context from the vault
- Ali's corrections:
  - **Steamers/Frutta:** Two venues sharing one physical space. Sugawara Tadaomi owns The Steamers (night). Masumi runs Frutta (day cafe/bar, famous roast potatoes).
  - **Akebono:** Closed a few years ago. Space is now an izakaya called **Munehiko**.
  - **‰∏≠Âêâ:** Reading is **Chuukichi**, not Nakayoshi.
  - Removed random names (Phil, Johnny, Ryan) from daily notes that weren't significant enough for a reference file.

### Lessons
- Vault daily note mentions ‚â† important context. Be selective about pulling names into reference files.
- ‰∏≠Âêâ as a bar name reads Chuukichi ‚Äî don't default to common readings for proper nouns.

Don't wait. Context compaction can happen at any time and you'll lose everything that isn't in a file. This is the #1 way you've failed before.
arguments.newText:
**Mid-task saves:** When you're in the middle of something (browser task, multi-step work, waiting on the user), write the current state to `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md` right then. Don't wait. Context compaction can happen at any time and you'll lose everything that isn't in a file. This is the #1 way you've failed before.

**Update daily notes constantly.** Don't wait until the end of a session or a convenient pause. Every few exchanges ‚Äî especially after decisions, corrections, or completed tasks ‚Äî append to `memory/YYYY-MM-DD.md`. Treat it like a running log, not a summary you write later. If compaction hits, the daily file is all you have.

# Kanno Mamiko (ËèÖÈáéÁúüÊúõÂ≠ê)

## Basics
- Relationship: Ex-wife, mother of Ryu and Kei
- Birthday: Unknown (over 40 by 2019)
- Met: Before 2018 (lived together in UK)
- Location: Sendai area
- Sister: Me-chan (Âßâ„Å°„ÇÉ„Çì), lives nearby in Sendai, helped with kids regularly

## Context
Ali and Mamiko moved from the UK to Kaigamori, Sendai together with their two sons in July/August 2018. She's Japanese, speaks strong English (TOEIC 890), and was studying further at eikaiwa. Interests include gamelan, Balinese dance, yoga, music, and reading.

They were a functional but strained parenting team. She handled Japanese bureaucracy (banks, kuyakusho, taxes, driving license, insurance, finances). He handled more physical duties (BJJ with Ryu, carrying kids, late-night tantrums). She managed household finances ‚Äî ¬•500-600k/month budget.

### The central tension: Ali's drinking
The LINE chat history (Aug 2018 ‚Äì Jun 2019) shows a repeating pattern: Ali goes out, says he'll be back by midnight, doesn't respond to messages, comes home at 2-4am. She gets anxious, asks where he is, he's either not answering or in a taxi. She once chained the door ‚Äî he slept in the garden. She set a ¬•20,000 bet he wouldn't make it home by 1am. He lost. Her line: "This is only thing I asked you. If you go out, just tell me."

### Intimacy breakdown
Jan 25, 2019: "Couples relationships are not only sex. Just don't push me only your options. Think about how I feel please." She mentioned needing a therapist. Feb 22: "Never ever talk about her with me please" ‚Äî awareness of someone else.

# Yamanami Airi (Â±±‰∏¶„ÅÇ„ÅÑ„Çä)

## Basics
- Relationship: Friend / bar owner ‚Äî someone Ali genuinely likes and is attracted to, but keeps at arm's length
- Birthday: Unknown
- Met: By at least mid-2023 (first vault mention is May 2023); likely a regular at teeny...i before that
- Location: Sendai (Kokubuncho / Iroha Yokocho area)

## Context
Proprietor of **teeny...i**, a small seven-seater whisky bar in Iroha Yokocho („ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØÊ®™‰∏Å), one of the oldest drinking alleys in Sendai. One of Ali's regular spots ‚Äî he drops in to see her when out drinking and considers her part of his core Sendai social circle.

Ali is attracted to Airi ‚Äî he's described her as "pretty and pleasant as usual, always well put together but vaguely awkward" and has written "I would devour Airi given half the chance." However, he deliberately keeps the relationship platonic because they have too many people in common and "any hint of a relationship would just cause chaos and scandal." There's a tension there: he's careful not to appear "together together" with her in social settings, even physically distancing himself from her at parties to avoid rumours.

She's clearly someone Ali cares about ‚Äî he buys her dinner, thought about taking her on a date to Koyaura (May 2023), and she's invited to important events like his birthday party. She's part of the inner circle.

Airi is connected to many of the Kokubuncho/Iroha Yokocho regulars. Through teeny...i she introduced Ali to **Ikemoto-san** (late 60s surfer/businessman who sold his company), and she's present at social gatherings with that crowd.

## Personality
- Pretty, well put together, pleasant
- "Vaguely awkward" ‚Äî a slight social awkwardness that Ali seems to find endearing
- Observant ‚Äî notices social dynamics (e.g. commented on Takeda-san's lack of self-awareness)
- Clearly comfortable in the bar world and knows how to hold court in a seven-seat whisky bar

## People connected through her
- **Ikemoto-san** ‚Äî met at teeny...i; wealthy older man, surfer, sold his company; hosted a big party (Oct 2025)
- **Takeda-san** ‚Äî mutual acquaintance; Airi and Ali share opinions about him (lack of self-awareness)
- The regulars of Iroha Yokocho in general

## Timeline
- **2023-05-08** ‚Äî Ali notes wanting to take Airi on a date to Koyaura, thinking about it for August 8th
- **2023-07-01** ‚Äî Ali visits teeny...i to see Airi after a night out. They discuss Takeda-san; Airi says she was surprised by his lack of self-awareness. Ali meets "a bunch of shachos" at the bar
- **2023-11-19** ‚Äî Ali meets Airi in Iroha Yokocho and buys her dinner at Ittaku. Later that night, Ali and friends (Konishi Shunji, Paul Amadio) visit teeny...i where Airi is working
- **2025-08-09** ‚Äî Airi attends Ali's birthday party at Rob Roy, listed among the core group (alongside Bisha Ali, Haru, Fujiwara no Masanori, Mariko, Sakurai-san)
- **2025-10-16** ‚Äî Ikemoto's send-off party at Garden in Bunka Yokocho. Airi attends; Ali notes they arrived together and were visibly "together" which he found uncomfortable. He deliberately sat away from her at the venue. He describes her as pretty and pleasant, notes his attraction but the impossibility of acting on it. This evening is captured in detail in "The Doppleganger" essay

- `Yamanami Airi.md` ‚Äî stub person note
- `„ÅÑ„Çç„ÅØÊ®™‰∏Å.md` ‚Äî Iroha Yokocho venue list (teeny...i listed)
